content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I bought this game, I though that it would be something different than what it is; and, I feel many of those not recommending this game made that same mistake. What this game is NOT is an economic/city builder simulation where you continually grow (ie a 4X). What it IS is a resource management RTS (others have gone into further detail) - probably the first of its kind (at least the first that I've played). In any case, it is very innovative and very good for what it is, in my opinion.I read through the other reviews to see if there was anything that I could add to what others have said, because I agree with most of the things that have been said about the game. One thng that I others haven't really talked about is how much strategy is actually involved in the game. First of all, others haven't really talked about how important the stock market actually is. As others have said, the ultimate goal of the game is to buy out your oponents stock; and conversely you must defend your own stock. Your stock price (and I might be a litttle bit wrong here) is based off of your net assets; that is the value of all your resources, buildings (including your home colony), minus any debt that you may have accrued; but more importantly, it also includes the value of any stock you buy in other (your opponent's) companies (also maybe your own?). The part I'm not sure about is how much the actual buying/selling of shares actually influences price. At the beginning everyone's stock price is low but it rises as the game progresses. If you can buy shares early on, not only will it make it easier for you to defeat your opponents in the end, you will make it much harder for them to beat you, since the progress they have made during the game has driven up your own stock price. Secondly, the fundamental question that the game asks the player is what is the the best/most profitable way for me to use my limited resources. By resources I mean the game's 12? resources (basic like iron or water, or advanced like electronics or chemicals), your cash, and most importantly the number of claims you have. Your claims equal the number of buidlings you can have and so are the limiting factor to your profit; that is you must maximize the profit from your limited number of claims. this raises a number of interesting questions and decisions. It may be profitable to scrap buildings for others if market prices for an output are much higher than the input, if you can buy a stockpile at a low price, or if you already have a stockpile. You may want to turn off a building if the input is more expensive than the output. Another result of this is that you are always (or should be) watching the prices on the market, and be aware of how they relate to the other resources.  Another result is that watching what your opponents are doing is important - they are working in the same market as you so, if they over or underproduce certain resources you can use that to your advantage. This is where the black market comes in. I agree with others that some of the sabotages are overpowered - but you need to remember, this game is still in early access so balancing issues should be ironed out. However, what they are not is underpriced; if the price is low, that just means that the players aren't using the market to their full advantage. The prices grows incrementally, so by the late game they should already be expensive. And as I said above, what your opponents produce - or don't, in this case - affects the prices you buy and sell at, so you can use sabotages to help you as well as hinder your opponents.Anyways, this got much longer than I intended, and I'm not sure how clear it was; but, I just want to say that I'm enjoying the game as it is, and eagerly await any improvements.

Early Access Review
								I'm reviewing this in its current state.  I'll keep updating this review as updates get released.Decent game - has tons of potential, but it's just too bland and predictable to recommend right now.  I agree with other reviewers that say that it just needs an extra "something" to be fun (differing AI, more varied games, much better balancing, definitely optimization).  The part that I dislike the most is the balancing of the black market.  It's way too easy to buy an EMP to use on your opponents (and likewise for your opponents to use on you).  The only games I've won have been games where I constantly buy EMP's and disable my opponent's power plants or water sources.  This definitely needs to be balanced by maybe making them much more expensive and much less powerful.  I'm sure these will be balanced out over time.  *Edit:  As mentioned in the comments, you can disable the black market at the start of the game.  This is actually how I prefer to play since then the AI can't gang up on you and take away any advantages that you were smart enough to get at the beginning of the game.  I know this works both ways, but personally, I enjoy planning out everything without having to worry about the black market.  Maybe I'll come around to it with future updates.*Overall, currently, I don't think it's worth the price tag unless you want to be a part of the development process, but it may be in the future.  I'm looking forward to updates, as this game could be great!Update:  They've definitely been listening to the players with their updates, and they've updated the game twice since release which is great!  Nothing major that I can notice, but small tweaks that make a significant difference.  I'll keep updating as things progress.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Have you ever played an RTS or 4X game and thought "I wish non-military victories were more viable?"  Well let me tell you about Offworld Trading Company.In Offworld, you are a company looking to compete with other startups and get rich by mining Mars for as much of the thirteen available resources as possible and drive opponents out of business.  There are NO military units.  Economic victory is the only victory.There are four factions, but you don't select one until you've had the chance to survey the map.  Resource availability and diversity is randomly generated, giving you the chance to plant the faction you think is best for the environment. APM will not save you, Starcraft fans. Resource tile claims are very limited.  You will NEVER have all thirteen resources immediately.  Some can be extracted on the spot, and others can only be produced by combining resources.  What you can't collect yourself, you can purchase in an always available market where prices fluctuate on your behavior and the behavior of your opponents.Your "score" is your Share Price.  It is your net worth minus your debt.  You defet other players by buying up massive amounts of their increasingly expensive shares.  When you purchase all of their shares, you get everything they've been building.  Your goal is to buyout all the other players.The "essential" resources are Water, Oxygen, Food, Fuel and Power.  Will your colony starve if you lack them?  NO!  "Starvation" does not exist, unlike Civ.  You will automatically buy what you need from the market passively and accumulate Debt instead.  Scrambling to acquire them all initially to avoid debt is a beginner's (or Civ player's) mistake.  What good is staving off debt if you grab all those things without producing precious Aluminum or Steel to allow you to upgrade your headquarters and edge closer to victory?  At the same time, you can't ignore them forever, because too much debt reduces your Share Price, allowing players to buy you more easily.As you upgrade your headquarters, you are provided handfuls of more claims to tiles to help you collect and produce more resources, and build fancier buildings that will help you generate the wealth you need to buyout your opponents.And then Sabatoge comes into play.  Just because there's no militaries doesn't mean you can't take your opponents down a peg.  The Black Market opens at regular intervals, allowing players to buy EMPs to temporarily disable opposing buildings, fake Mutinies to steal buildings, Dynamite to destroy buildings, or devastating, nonlethal Underground Nukes to permanently reduce the yield of an opponent's production tile.  You can also buy precious claims when you want just one more building without having to upgrade, or Goon Squads that defend buildings from attacks (and then throw them back at opponents).  There are four factions.  Three of them are human and require Water, Oxygen and Food.  The Expansive humans are great if you're hungry for lots of tiles, because they get an extra Claim on a tile every time they upgrade.  They also require less Steel for upgrades.  The Robotic colony doesn't care about Water, Food or Oxygen, but instead require Electronics (the final, most expensive resource) as well as massive amounts of Power.  Scientific colonies have the unique ability to plant production facilities directly on top of a raw resource, therby "skipping" a step.  This is huge if you use it carefully.  My favorite faction, Scavengers, use Carbon instead of Steel and can use the Black Market more frequently.  They are my favorite because while other players are fighting over Iron and spending claims changing that same Iron into Steel, I can just use Carbon for everything (yet they are useless on a map where I can't find Carbon.)  Again, when you play the game, you scan the map for resources FIRST and then choose the faction you think will work best with what you can grab.As of March 2015 the game is aesthetically rough.  There are only two songs, simple, loud sound effects, and placeholder robotic voices to announce events in game.  Still, I cannot put this game down.  Its positively brilliant and addictive, and it will only get better as the game develops.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												It's like realtime Settlers of Catan.It's not much like city builder style economic games (such as Tropico, Dwarf Fortress, Factorio, the Settlers series) because you are heavily limited by the number of tiles (ie resources) you can claim. There's no optimising your road layout because there are no roads - your cargo flies where it needs to go.The limited number of tile claims you have slows the pace from totally frantic to manageable. The game is bursts of frenetic energy and aggression as you seize an available opportunity, then back to waiting. It feels a bit like a turn based boardgame with a chess timer.I bought this game thinking I was going to have a nice quiet time building up a peaceful economy, as in the games I listed before, and that I wasn't too keen on the competitive aspect. Two hours later, I'm a cutthroat wheeling-and-dealing space CEO.That said, it's very easy to make unfixable mistakes, and the game's not much good at teaching you how to play it. I think a lot of plays will be necessary to figure out good strategies. There are also some rough edges in the game balance - there are a few "I win" buttons in there, which I'm expecting will get nerfed in future.It's a lot of fun, though. Just expect to think on your feet, very quickly, and to go for the throat.

Early Access Review
								'This isn't going to be like other RTS, it's going to be economy based instead of blowing things up' ... Put's in a 'black market' where you buy things to blow stuff up.I like the game concept, but I feel as though the black market is detrimental to it. You are meant to outfox the other companies, by speculating on price and going after the resources that will be needed. It's like playing MULE or Settlers of Catan. The problem is it just reverts to any other RTS when the Black Market comes into play. If someone tries to plan ahead, see what is going to be needed, invest, ect. Other players just shut their stuff down. Sure, there are no armies, but is has the same effect. It's just lazy. Imagine Microsoft, instead of competing for market share with Apple based on innovation, could just nuke one of Apple's manufacturing plants. That's not how it works. Should we add a rule to Monopoly where you can obliterate Hotels? This is not in the spirit of this sort of arena.Please remove this and replace it with something else. There are auctions, price manipulations, etc. that are better suited for this game. More ideas like those, and less 'sabotage' type things would be MUCH better. If you don't want this to be like every other RTS out there, then don't make it like every other RTS out there. There is a lot of potential here, please don't drop the ball.I enjoy some aspects of the game, and see where it could be fun, but I cannot recommend it unless the direction is changed.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												I was intimidated upon hearing about the premise of this game... It sounds like one of those games that are only fun to people with very specialized knowledge and tastes. But actually the developers have succeeded in making a very approachable and fast game about economy, business and finance, with clear tutorials and interface, and with a focus on multiplayer but still having a fun singleplayer experience.Every building needs special materials and produces something else, but all materials can be bought or sold at the market, with dynamic prices based on supply and demand. Imagine if in warcraft 2, you could sell your extra lumber to other players. There's no military combat here, but economic attacks, defense and espionage are integral to the game.You may be interested in the premise or not, but don't skip the game fearing that it will be too complicated. The mechanics are simple at the core, and may teach you an abstract thing or two about how business works in the real world.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Given the oft and loudly proclaimed provenance of this game I expected a 4X-RTS experience, except with markets instead of militaries.  I imagined hours of playing vast, sprawling games across the surface of Mars, replete with complexity and grand strategic depth.That's not what this game is.  In fact OTC is a scion of the great RTS's of the late 90s, and it operates on that same tense, refined, match-oriented, competitive level- in which the genre name becomes an anachronism, because the actual gameplay is so tight and focused that it would be best described as tactical rather than strategic.  Matches are fast-paced and relatively short, demanding a combination of quick clicks and quick thinking to stay on top.  Resources, tech, and production are all tied up with each other in a single intertangled "tree" of progression.  You can buy or sell any resource or product at any time if you have the money, and one of the key facets of playing well is using this ever-market to drive up the value of your surplus goods and drive down the value of your opponents', while still making sure you are keeping your levels where they need to be to avoid halts in production or debt accumulation.  There's a moment sometimes in a match where suddenly you see a way that you can make the market perform for you like a puppet- a few minutes and some well-placed clicks later and your stock is way out on top  (assuming, of course, your plans aren't deflected by your opponents' own devious machinations).  Victory in OTC occurs when one player owns all the stock of all the corporations in the match.During the best matches I experience that same sort of premium-grade thrumming that I used to get from a good game of Starcraft in college, complete with peculiar blink of bewilderment at match's end as my brain powers down its High Alert protocols and returns to normal functioning.  I find it interesting that the devs keep emphasizing how not like Starcraft this game is, and yet my gut-level experience has been very similar for the two games.  It's interesting as well that the devs were so worried about multiplayer catching on without any combat outlet for players.  And yet this game shines most brightly in the cutthroat multiplayer arena.  I think they underestimated our creativity when it comes to eradicating our opponents.  The markets of OTC can be just as disruptive and violent (and satisfying) as any zerg-infested terran marine making a bee-line for your base.Overall 7.5/10Pros:+original concept with a classic feel+elegant, streamlined gameplay+relatively short matches+rewards creativity and decisiveness+compelling soundtrackYou decide:+/-quick clicking can be a major factor in your success+/-limited options in terms of tech and production+/-the differences among the corporate classes pose some interesting market problems for players but ultimately gameplay is pretty much the same for everyone+/- Early Access...sometimes you find a diamond at the end, sometimes it's a lemon.  I do tend to trust Stardock though.+/-high tension gameplayCons:-high, inflexible price point (a side effect of Kickstarter)-graphics and glitches need a lot of work before they are polished-occasional imbalances-game doesn't prepare you for its experience (watch some LPs, it helps a lot)

number of helpful: 96 of 144 people (67%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								A brief description of this game may read "resource management and competitive economics on Mars" - its free from combat (at least of a gun-play kind) and runs at "realtime" - Sounds good (if you like that sort of thing, which I do) and faily original...BUT there is one central and perhaps critical flaw...Offworld Trading Company has some truelly fantastic and compulsive elements - it has simple yet dynamic gameplay which takes seconds to learn and forever to master; the claiming and extraction of always limited resources before your competitors is simple enough (at least in theory) - the refinement of the resources into goods that demand higher prices, none too complex - manipulating the market for your benifit needs a little practice - However, learning how and when to combine black market tricks on your competitors with manufactured price hikes that trash their stock so you can buy them at a snap -- this takes time.  Sadly, time is the thing that you simply don't have.  Whilst the interface, the gameplay and the graphics are all on a scale between good and outstanding the games pacing feels all off.  It's like watching (the original) Total Recall at twenty times the normal speed; you know that there are some great moments in there that you would love to savour but it's gone before you've noticed you're enjoying yourself.  If you're victorious then it doesn't feel like you've worked for it, if you lose it dosn't feel you've had a chance to put up a fight.  A game lasts around a half an hour to an hour and moves at a pace that would give Usain Bolt jet lag...And this is worries me because I don't know how it can be changed without removing all that makes the game stand-out from the crowd.  The Unique Selling Point of this game is "realtime" competitive economics - but that's not strictly true; REALTIME economics is slow, careful, managed.  Sure, there is shouting and screaming on the trading floor, but the wider economic world around it moves at a more measured pace.  RTS is a format that suits combat orientated games - it's frantic "WHO IS SHOOTING ME/WHEN DID THAT BLOW-UP!!" quality is appropriate to its content - war is (I imagine) chaotic and frantic - it's central gameplay is built around event's that can be drawn over realtime - namely gunfights.  But if we had a TRUE RTS economics game you would need to pass it down several generations to win - Neither nation nor global corporation gained market dominance over thirty muinets, it takes hundereds of yeears.... something thats nicely communicated and simulated in the format of a turn-based game.  The question is "who want's this game", or perhaps rather "When do I want this game"?  If I'm in the mood for something fast-paced but stratigic it makes sense to look for gunplay, if its long lasting and stratigic economic is better.  This has the flaw of being neither and both.In the end, for all of Offworld Trading Company's good points (and it has many), its format seems irreconcilably at odds with its content; it ain't realtime economics at all, its economics so fast it feels like you can't breath - think Arnie in the red dust with eyes about to pop.

												Other reviews have covered the excellent sound, graphics, and market-driven gameplay. I will just add this: rarely have I played an RTS where the AI was so hard to beat. When playing on a proper difficulty, a combination of terrain, faction, and the behavior of your opponents will force hard choices that do not play out the same every time. Highly recommended.

												July 2016 Early Access Review UpdatedThe game is certainly more polished now that it was 1 year ago when I first reviewed it. It feels more like a game now and no longer causes my computer to melt down doing the tutorials. It is still a race to buy out the opponent and games typically last only 20 minutes. This means you are playing the same basic game over and over and over and that gets old fast.You are basically paying £30 for a game that gets boring after 2 hours, in those 2 hours you will typically have finished 6 games.The devs where told this a year ago and have done absolutely nothing to address the problem.Economy fans like their games to be longer than and deeper than this. Also it feels like a £9.99 Facebook game sold on the PC for £30 to me.Good game for £9.99.... bit of a rip off for £30 if you ask me.Below is my review for 1 year ago.... looks like I was right. April 2015 Early Access ReviewThe game needs more things to do, currently it is a pretty dull buy out your competitors before they buy you out affair. Every game is race to that end. Look at my hours in the game 1.8, I played several games and that is how long it took to win in each game. So there is no depth here, its a short sweet economic race game, with the finishing post being he who owns everything wins. It also runs rather hot too even on my well cooled system.I have not seen anything to suggest the game is getting more depth added prior to release. So I think this game will ultimately disappoint users who find them selves paying close to £30 for a game thats barely worth £4. There is going to be backlash over the price, just wait and see.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												What is this game about?:This is an economic RTS simulator that takes place on Mars. Matches will take around 15-30 minutes depending on how many people you are playing with. This is not a epic-scale game like Civilization!  So you, the player can choose between 4 different factions. The 4 different factions are: Expansive, Robotic, Scientific and Scavenger. Every factions has there ups and downs and you want to use the best faction that you think is good on set random map.Gameplay:-Ingame you will have a market window on the left for all the market prices and all the rescource units you might have. This is where all the buying and selling will be taken place.-In the middle of the screen is where most of the action takes plays. On the map you build buildings that produce rescources which cost claims where you have limited number of. Because of this you need to plan your way through-On the right top side is where you and other players companies stocks are. The goal to win a game is very simple. Buy every other company out by buying there stock. Each company has 10 stocks. You can buy someone out by having a majority of there stock (6 stocks=60%) or if they bought there own 5 stocks already, you can buy those 5 stocks, double the price, in 1 go.-To combat the company that is leading a match there is something called the blackmarket. The blackmarket is on the right bottom side of the screen and will have a set of different items. Some items are there for to shutdown the production of your opponents or to boost your own production.What has the game to Offer?:-9 Tutorials which are very well done and explain you the game. after every tutorial you pass it will be a bit harder for you which is nice.-Campaign which consist of 9 different leaders which have there own set of different buildings. You play 6 different matches where you buy into the colony and not a Company. After that there is a final match where you need to buyout the remaining 3 companies. Note: prices are going to be crazy in this mode. Campaign takes about 4-5 hours.-Skirmish mode up to 8 Players.-Daily Challenge. Everyone gets the same map and restrictions and you will be competing to get the best time. There is also a leaderboard for that and you can watch replays from other players to see what they did differently.-Ranking System(online). 1vs1 is available on Monday through Thursday and 4 FFA Friday through Sunday.-Custom Lobby games(online). Just skirmish matches with your own rules against real people or with/against AI.-Well balanced AI-Different types of game modes.

content:
Posted: January 8
												So this is a typical Stardock Game.  and for those that love stardock, you may enjoy picking this up.  I got it on boxing day for about $15.  I've played it for about 5 hours and am done with it and feel I got my monies worth at $15.  IMO it is not even remotely worth the $45 they are charging full price for it.   Pro's:  I like the factions.  they are well designed, have cool leaders with interesting personalities and the art is fun.The idea of a planetary city builder with strong economic motivations really appeal to me.  almost like Alpha centari playing the morgan faction for those Sid Mier geeks out there.Interface is easy to use,  turtorials are quick and snappy, you can be playing this game at full speed within an hour of running the tutorial missions.Con's:  ITs way too fast.  Games last about 30 mins start to finish.  (even the ones I win)  I am more into the long game simlations, which is why I opened with "typical star dock game"  your neighbours will be on your doorstep within minutes of starting the game, and if you don't take an eary lead, you are toast as you only have about 10 minutes to make up the lead or the game will end.The campaign mode was lacklustre, and turtorials for campaign mode were lacking,  it was hard to really understand what campaign was about until you play one campaign game through to completeion . fortunatly they games only last about 20 mins so its faster to just play it through and figure it out than to google it and read about it.Overall I am going to not recomend this game.  not because its not good,  it is, but Its way overpriced. if you are picking this up on sale, you can probably get 10 hours of fun out of it so pay accordingly.  if you have friends that play, you can probably get a little more time out of it, as multiplayer seems to be really the only place a game this fast would be fun time and time again.  Or if you like stardock games in general, go ahead and pick it up.   honestly though, its not as good as the videos make it look.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I first went into the game adoring the feel and wishing for it to be a longer classical tycoon style game.I'm so glad it isn't.This game is an incredibly intelligent and unique strategy game that requires players to manage a company and successfully out-play their competitors in short to intermediate matches, where the objective is to buy out the oppoisition. With limited claims, a♥♥♥♥♥♥of resource types and locations players will have to adapt their strategy to what they can get their hands on, and if a competitor is getting a bit too powerful, players can use a series of corporate espionage actions in order to temporarily cripple parts of their competitors, to get that slight edge.Everything about this gamem requires you to think ahead and plan out what you want to do, while being able to adapt said plan to the ever evolving playing field that competitors provide. Your stocks might suddenly be bought or maybe someone decided to shut down your production, and it's through this that you have to carefully adapt and react to these situations. The interactions between players is done incredibly, with fast-paced gameplay that'll keep you on the edge of your seat the whole time.Accompanying this is of course beautiful and stylized graphics combined with incredible sounds and music to create the perfect mood, depending on where you're at in the game. They successfully managed to make Mars up close beautiful, and after the release of recent DLC, they did the same with Ceres.While the lack of players is definitely a problem, the AI is honestly one of the best I've seen in any game. The devs have spent so much time and money on making an extremely intelligent AI that can adapt and plot just as well as the player, and will create many intense moments where you and the competing AI are racing to buy the other's last stock, with the most satisfying feeling when you finally manage to beat them.Ultimately this game is incredible and definitely deserves a try, though it may not be for most casual strategy players. You'll find hours of entertainment, whether it's through the AI or other players that by some magical chance you manage to find. GG Mohawk, GG.

number of helpful: 24 of 26 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Offworld Trading Company is easily one of my favourite real-time strategy games, and it picks up right where M.U.L.E. left off back in 1983, even making a few very sweet references along the way.I'm an economics dunce and a total sloth at real-time strategy but Offworld Trading Company grabbed me by the cahonies right from the moment Christopher 'Baba Yetu' Tin's Red Planet Nocturne pattered out of my speakers to the words 'Earth may be dying'. It's a wonderfully evocative set-up and one perfectly scored by Tin.Here's a war game that's fought on a different front: the Martian stock market. It's Corporate Combat. There's no diplomacy, and there are no weapons in the literal sense either; your weapon is cold hard capitalism and your trusty steed supply and demand. Ride it well.It seems some people go into OTC expecting some sort of longform, perhaps story-driven campaign, that plays like a laid back empire builder. It isn't like that. At all. This is a trading game and it's cutthroat. Quick and sharp. Dog eat dog. "Screw with us, and we'll screw with you."Single rounds can be over in as little as 15 minutes or drawn out towards an hour depending on how well (or badly) you play, but the game goes to great lengths to ease you in with a fine set of tutorials, a 'full fat' tutorial skirmish, toggle-able auto-pausing when you're doing certain tasks, speed settings, and it also comes bundled with a comprehensive and in-depth almanac. Oh, and the tooltips are superb.There is a campaign mode but it's not a linear single playthrough affair. It's dynamic, replayable, meaty and as such something you can really sink your teeth into. Think Invisible Inc. or Infested Planet's new Planetary Campaign DLC where each skirmish is linked together by a strategic layer, rich with tough but exciting decisions that may have far reaching ramifications as you progress.The Daily Challenges too are worth a pop just to hone your real-time skills with no pausing and see how you fare against other players. The competitive multiplayer is demanding but there's also co-op against the AI which knows how to play and can be a formidable challenge in itself. My friend and I have yet to beat it on the recommended Manager difficulty!All in all, if you like your strategy to be focused and deep then Offworld Trading Company might just be for you. It's such a smart game and one I foresee myself coming back to again and again. I'm yet to pick up the DLC but it sounds fantastic.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								My roommate walked in and asked what I was playing. I told him it was Offworld Trading Company, an RTS about building a corporation on Mars, expanding your base, and specializing in the production of a whole host of materials to earn enough money to buy out your opponents. He told me it looked pretty interesting, but mentioned that I was losing... And I was, BADLY. The match was down to myself and one other company, but that enemy had bought out two other players. They were an unstoppable behemoth with 10x the iron mines, steel mills, glass factories, electronic depots, and every other profitable thing you can imagine. It was this sort of scenerio I might have just given up and quit in any other strategy game. But, I couldn't embaress myself, here. I had an offworld market, capable of launching rockets filled with my most precious materials to the skies and bringing back buckets of cash and my opponent didn't. I coud see the flashing, red percentage next to my enemy's name, noting how close they were to buying me out. I managed to buy a bit of my enemy's stock. But, it was still going to cost 2 million to win. I sold EVERYTHING, making a little bit here, a little bit there. I looked to the right: 70%, 80%, 90%... 99%. That's it! 2 million!!! Buy, buy, buy. I won. What.I've read some reviews where people don't seem to understand why prices go up or down and don't understand some of the core mechanics of the game, so I just wanted to clear a few things up. There are 2-8 companies in each match, with a colony at the center. All goods start at a certain price. If players buy more of one resource, it goes up in price. If they sell a lot, it goes down. The colony also expands as the game goes on and each building they create has specific demands that also affect the market prices.Each player chooses one of four types of headquarters, each with their own abilities. The game is based on isometric tiles and when you start the game, you'll only have a few claims to own the tiles you choose. By leveling up your base from level 1 to level 5, you get more claims to diversify and increase production. At max level, you can build an offworld market that launches rockets into space. This secondary market isn't affected by supply and demand, it just has permanatly high prices. This makes it a very lucridive end game to reach and pile up enough money to buy out your opponents.The game is a tense, corporate competition that has so many ways to play, allowing you to build a vast mining corporation, an electronic manufacturing titan, or a chemical lab empire. You can upgrade everything, specialize or diversify, build quick and unstable, or slow and steady; the game offers a ton of ways to replay. This is a fantastic strategy game that isn't much like any major game out there and is tons of fun with friends. The AI is pretty tough, though.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I want to like this game a lot but it is really hard to, like really really hard.tl;dr = if you like the concept wait (most likely a long time) for a good sale (price of $5 or less)The video of this game above says that no two games are ever the same.  And I will admit, I took that with a grain of salt but holy cow is every game the definition of linear.  Get to HQ5, build 2 rocket pads and sell stuff till you can buy someone out.  After you buy someone out it is literally an easy win if not outright impossible (if the player is good) to lose the game.  Very little room for play/counter-play is basically a big issue.The game is so under developed that there isnt many Pros to the Cons for this game.  I find it annoying that a developer wants to crowdsource their development.One big thing this game is lacking is an actual supply and demand.  I can debt materials out of thin air.  At least they could make all resources actually match the surpluss (or shortage) of stuff in the game.  For example.  If no one built power, stuff should just go unpowered, instead of debting power from some magical source that produces it.  This thought can be carried over into every other resource.  If I want to buy iron, the market better have a surplus of it, such as another play sold 200 iron "to the market" so that now any other player can now buy that 200 iron at some market price and if it is gone, welp its gone (till someone else sells some).  THIS IS THE KEY PART OF THE GAME PLAY THAT I EXPECTED WHEN I STARTED PLAYING.  Sadly this game is more about "get the most money" from selling♥♥♥♥♥♥to the aether instead of economic warfare.Debt is really meh in the game, especially if you dont have TIGHTER DEBT rule on.  My friend -- when he played with me -- had to get over 300k debt from an auction (that apparently can go onto infinity) before it started to seriously effect his stockprice.Stocks dont do anything other than protect (delay) you from losing or to take control of another player.  There is no reason to really do anything with Stocks till later in the game.  Realistically it should yield dividends (if you owned other people's stock) for example.  It should be a risk/reward factor -- do I keep my stock in this player to yield dividends and I black market this other player to keep them down while I build up or do I sell now from this guy so I can outright buy this other guy.  This thought process never happens the way stocks are used in this game.  It is always "I will just wait to get more money (from selling stuff) and buy this guy outright".While the developers have some odd understanding that a minimap and/or player distinction (EVERYONE LOOKS THE SAME) is not imporant, I am left clueless at to this Warcraft 3, Starcraft 2 and Age of Empires "RTS" they have played without a minimap or such distinguishing features between players.  Very irritating.Races are pretty much unimportant and do little to change the way one plays the game.  "Exanpsive" has the most advantage by default because Claims are so imporant for every aspect of the game but that doesnt mean they automatically win either.I could go on in detail about a lot of other small aspects of the game that are bad but that would be a waste of time for both you and me.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												I didn't think I'd like this game since I do not usually like Real Time Strategy games, but after only a couple of months Offworld Trading Company is already one of my most played games on Steam.What makes OTC so special is how different each match is. While other games in the genre require constant study of builds as the meta shifts, here the randomized maps and varied strategies from opponents force players to play each round differently. Whereas one match might see the price of food skyrocket you to victory, the next match might find food barely worth the cost of the building. The player most able to see and take advantage of gaps in the market wins.The result is a game that still makes me sweat after 200 matches played, yet even when I lose I still enjoy myself. What better compliment can you offer a competitive multiplayer game? I highly, highly recommended.edit: This game has only improved over the course of Early Access, and it's still a game I play regularly!

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												Important:  Each game is a match that takes 20-40min to complete.  There are options that allow for longer games but the design is based on short cutthroat matches over long empire building.That being said the game is fantastic!The single player enviroment is rich is choices.  You can play a campaign at a difficulty of your choosing that goes through 7 matches each with carry over conditions and abilities.  This forces you to mix up your playing style and adjust to different situations.  You will be restricted in building choices as well, so learning to make do with what you have is important.  The game ends after a final showdown where you are allowed to buy out your rivals.  This mode is very fun and less stressfull then the other match types.Skirmish and multiplayer allow you to buy out your rivals from the start (this is how you win the game).  With a dynamic market then the game is all about spotting oppertunities and taking advantage or knee capping your opponents with targeted special abilites on their structures.The game has a setting that allows you to hide the real identity of each player to prevent grudge matches from getting out of hand for a reason!!The game is fast, but very deep, you tend to get time to think about your decisions despite the time pressure.  Production chains are rather simple, but the overall interaction of the market and the 13 resources allows for immense possibilities.  No two matches are ever alike.The game is pretty unique and I really do not have anything else that scratches the same kind of itch (Anno series comes the closest, but the markets are pretty stale in comparision).If you like schemes like shutting down your rivals water production shortly after causing a spike in water prices with the ultimate goal of making their food production too expensive to compete with yours, then well, you have found your dream game.To me this game is a 10/10 for this type of game, but it is not for everyone, expecially people who do not like competitive games.

number of helpful: 43 of 60 people (72%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Terrific game built on a purely economic and capitalist set of goals as opposed to a military one. The initial game is relatively simplistic. Build a base on mars with the resource nodes available on the map while trying to make money by selling those same resources for money. You can only hold so many plots of land at a time so you have to build your economy in a narrow frame of what you want to do with the space you have. Resources gain more and more value over time but every time a player, or the ai sells something it lowers the value of the resource. The game is a modicum of a real world stock market and economy but simpler and faster.The game has a lot of interesting depth and complexity to these simple mechanics. There is the push/pull of using your resources more quickly to advance your base vs selling them to have cash on hand. You can prioritize basic resources for your base in the early game that have less value later or prioritize the pricier resources for cash. Playing on maps with restricted resources forces you to change how you approach making money. Off world shipping is worth bank late game when selling basics like foods but requires advance components and resources to make. It requires a good timing on when to have what resources in production in order to maximize profit. One corporation only uses robots which requires no food to operate and less water but it means a higher requirement for advance resources. This means dedicating less land plots to cheaper basic resources but a higher cash cost early game.If aggresively manipulating economies to your benefit, moving resources for money, or aggressively selling your own stock in order to gain quick cash to make deals and then buying it back and throwing cash at your opponents in hostile takeover does not sound interesting then this game is not for you. Otherwise go nuts. Also the game has beautifully simple graphics.

Posted: April 28, 2016
												You know it’s a good game when you go to sleep and dream about playing more. How does someone make an economic RTS fun? Play this and you will see exactly how. Also the tutorial is really good and gets you up to speed, haven't touched the campaign yet but it’s on my to-do list. Oh and the soundtrack is just amazing. This game was finished 6 months ago or at least it felt that way (it’s been an amazing experience being part of the early access for it), and it has just been polished and polished to the amazing creation we are presented with. Soren and Mohawk Studios created something that will last a long time in the minds and hearts of gamers, just like Civ4. Highly Recommended, and easily going in my top 10 game list for 2016.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review (2/12/15)BLUF: #1 - I feel that RTS is a poor term to describe this game and #2 - from the Devs “Feedback! We want to know how players are going to break the game, suss out any degenerate strategies, and make sure we polish every rough edge off of the gameplay. Offworld Trading Company is fully funded; we are not relying on Early Access sales to finish the game.” This statement is key.***For those of you who have been burned by early access games before please take the note from the Devs seriously. This is a very playable and stable game right now and they already have the resources to put the finishing touches on it. So you are not really paying to make the game, you are getting an early shot at the game and a chance to drive further balance into the system. The final quality of this game will depend heavily on balancing the PVP aspects of the game so the more feedback they have now the better.As far as this being a RTS; while it might be the closest term we have to define it, that will give many people the wrong idea. There are no units to move, no combat, and no chokepoints. You establish a base and build buildings to harvest resources (much like the Warhammer:Dawn of War series) and use those resources to develope higher teir commdities to eventually sell for cash and buy out your opponents. It is fast paced and at times will feel like a RTS, but traditional RTS tactics will fail for the most part.The key is that the prices that determine which resource is the 'win' resource will depend on the strat adapted by the players in the game and will change from game to game. There are no Ultimate Resources that win the game each time. The higher teir products will usually have a higher price, but if everyone in that game chases them then the price will plummet and the player sitting on a pile of low teir resources can dominate. Basically the L33T strat that everyone wants to use will neuter itself before it can win.My current concerns:The pace of the game is very aggressive for a strategy game. The pace can be adjusted and I have only played against the AI with their GHz brains, but knowing PVP types this could quickly devolve into a 'who can spam out the first 3 correct buildings' contest.The interface needs to do a better job of letting the player know whats going on. There are some pretty nasty things lurking on the Black Market and all you get is a chat box type readout to announce them and maybe an onscreen animation if you happen to be looking at that part of the map at the time. The trick is to find the balance where we get the info we need without getting our screen spammed out by alerts. Good luck Mohawk!

number of helpful: 46 of 67 people (69%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review
Ignore the entry ticket price, this is one of the most polished Early Access titles you'll ever see.Offworld Trading Company, possibly the most curious of creatures. A game that dares to break the rules, it's not quite a 4x and it's not quite an RTS, and yet it's got elements of both, as well as a very brutal and brilliant introduction into capitalism in it's most true sense.The creator of this was the lead designer of Civ IV, still widely regarded as the pinnacle of the series and still very much fondly remembered by many to this day (and often still played by many, it's got a dedicated following, mods and glorious goodies, it's still fantastic, if you don't have Civ IV, please get it). He's brought a very unique approach to this game and has effectively talen the spirit of M.U.L.E. and brought it back, shaken it up and presented us with a entirely new set of concepts to learn and re-learn.The game plays out over a martian map, randomly generated from various landscapes made up of craters, dried riverbeds and valleys that do a fairly solid impression of conveying the martian scene, as well as various terrain that can be covered in ice, certain areas will be marked with resource node icons indicating they are of potential exploitative value for various minerals.  Arranged on a hex grid, you'll immediately be put in mind of old strategy games, but the comparison ends there. There are no units to control, at all. You only build things.A non combat 4X, is this even possible? Say whaaaaaaaaaat?Yes. I'll repeat that. You only build things. In this game, your structures are your units in effect. Your mines, your colony buildings, and your economy represents your "arsenal" and "weaponry". This makes for a frenetic early game as everyone jumps into the map blind, all arriving at the starport with nary but a blank map and the ability to scan in a limited range and for a limited number of times (these recharge over time, but you're effectively capped to a number of 'hops'), you'll see tantalising highlights on the horizon suggesting possible mineral nodes, but you won't KNOW what they are unless you scan right over them. This presents the first risk/reward mechanic, because the very early stages are a gold rush, do you take your time and map out the area, performing a thorough survey and pick the best spot (and risk losing it by accident to a lucky colonist) or do you jump at the first spot that "looks good" and risk sacrificing a better opportunity later on?During the early game, you'll be moving fairly quickly to make the optimal use of your initial claims, working out the best places to put down mines, whether you're best off setting up colony infrastructure or buying in the resources you need whilst you export minerals, again, these are all choices you have to balance, and the economics are very fluid. The game operates an exceptionally liquid supply and demand based market that fluctuates very quickly based on what is sold and what is required by the people off planet, so taking advantage of peaks in the market, and stocking up when there's a glut can make for excellent trading strategies on top of the usual manufacturing gigs.As the game progresses you'll be offered auctions on patents, black market goods, pirates will offer their services, and the game settles into a reasonable pace, it's not too brisk that you'll be panicking over keypresses, and you'll usually have more than enough time to plan your moves, but it's juuuust fast enough that you'll not start feeling bored or that there's a lull in the action. The pace even now feels just right, and the game even at this Early Access stage feels amazingly well refined. The AI is also brutal, which makes for some excellent and tense singleplayer matches (and if you're not careful, amazingly short ones, the AI knows when to strike and buy you out, with scary precision).The economy has a solid enough set of gears that you can work through as you expand, moving up through basic goods at first, and then you can decide to diversify, thus preventing your company from becoming exposed to the fluctuations or even possible manipulations of the market, or you can specialise in luxury goods, with the aim of striking it rich when demand is at it's highest. If, and it's a big if, you do this well, the rewards are huge, and in an RTS, would be the equivalent of nuking the base, here you win with money. Earn more than your opponent, buy them out and crush them.This is where the true nature of the game comes to the fore, as a lesson in future capitalism, it's bold, and even at times cruel, but perhaps a very good mirror to hold up and show what can happen if the only guiding force is the market, as a game, this makes it a brilliant and unique concept, and as an Early Access product, well, it's far from "Early" in my eyes. This game feels very much close to completion, they're more talking about fleshing out the multiplayer, getting the pacing and balancing just right and layering on the polish (this game needs polish?!?! WHERE?). Truth be told, it feels very polished as it is, there's a few graphical glitches but these are -minor-.Yes, the cost of entry is high, but for once, this is a game that actually justifies the entry fee.Closing thoughtsThis is a rare case where Early Access actually is a literal application of the term, you're paying to get Early Access to the almost complete product, and to provide feedback that helps shape it before it goes to the final version. Balancing, tweaking, and providing strategic insight to the developers, who have been listening and responding, and watching in kind. It's a very good example of how Early Access in a "shortform" approach should work (there's plenty of longer form SEA games that have done well such as Prison Architect, but that's a seperate discussion). As a result I really have little hesitation putting the paws up for this one, it's a genuinely brilliant game and it brings something different to the table, which it should be commended for.Current verdict : Highly recommended, and ignore the Early Access sticker, there's nothing Early about this game, it's very much in an end-to-end playable state

												Really fun game, I was surprised because when I read other reviews I wasn't so sure I would like it. They somehow made a game about stocks, fun! Well, it gets more in-depth than that.. but that was my biggest worry! This is surprisingly fun, challenging and you will enjoy it more than you think you will! Make sure you are in the mindset to learn stuff, and have fun! I know I have been. :)

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game needs a lot of work to make it enjoyable. The Black Market items just make the game stressful as, if you're the highest ranked player for the mission, you will inevitably be targeted repeatedly by the other three AI players, making it nearly impossible to manage your resources. Even if you are doing really well and own all the stock in your own company in a skirmish, another player can still somehow buy stock in your company that shouldn't even be for sale and win the game. The claim system is completely hampering the ability to play the game as it is portrayed in the videos. There's just too small of a map and too limited of resources to enjoy the act of building up a company or colony. The missions are over so quickly I feel no satisfaction even if I win.Yes, most RTS's are military games, but there is an econmic angle to them as well. The strongest economies are usually the winners. This game substitutes the lack of tanks and turrets for Black Market items that blow up buildings, temporarily disable them or capture them for other players. THIS IS NO DIFFERENT. There is no difference between this game and a military RTS except that this game is not fun, not realistic in the aspects of building up a company or the ability to focus on a single resource chain / manufacturing process, and it is over so quickly it leaves you wondering why you just spent 30-45 minutes playing a "week" mission in a compaign that makes you start all over again the next week with some "upgraded" capabilities.I spent one skirmish (because I wanted to play with all available buildings) only to find that by the time that I could start launching items into space for selling offworld (the best way to make money in the game by far) that the other computer player had already bought out the other two companies (which I had bought stock in, but could no longer as they were now 'subsidiaries' of the main company) and proceeded to blow up my only launchpad (because, again, limited building claims) with the black market dynomite option even though it was protected with the Goon Squad (the only defensive measure in the game that you have to continually and immediately purchase after each attack [which is an extremely ridiculous option considering the computer can repeatedly attack you faster than you can click to purchase and place your defense against this).Maybe I haven't given this game enough time to understand it completely, but, as an experienced gamer of RTS's. I found this game difficult to understand, unintuitive in controls and concepts, not fun (for previously mentioned reasons), and regretted buying it immediately.Hopefully this game has a major overhaul by the time it goes into full version, but I will not be playing it again and hope that I get my refund.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I recommend this game, with a grain of salt!  This is not a game for everyone and the price point isn't for everyone, either.The description reads that the game is complete and only looking to do polish and balancing.  In my eyes, the game is not complete, and shouldn't be deemed complete.  For $40 CAD, Offworld Trading Company will make your chequebook scream.  The sheer lack of content in this game at present doesn't make this feel like a $40 game; however, this may be the "spoiled adult" in me talking - It cost more to buy M.U.L.E. for the C64 back in the day, and it has far less.For starters, everyone fights for the same resources, to produce the same few marketable goods.  This is, of course, the entire premise of the game, but I don't feel it's done correctly.  The game really boils down to "Who clicks faster."  You have the same relative strategy among all the other players, no matter the race you play: Build necessary starting materials to upgrade your HQ, buy materials that are dirt cheap and sell materials that are pricey.  The lack of materials and race specializations may be the downfall here, because once you fall behind the competition, winning becomes unattainable.  Since everyone is fighting for the same resources, whoever dominated the market first, wins; you may as well just resign.You are given dirty underhanded tricks to try and slow down the competition, with ever increasing cost as they are used.  That, in itself, is another problem.  The profiteer gets to use these features to their hearts content - they're making the money, after all.  As they use these features against you to continue pushing themselves ahead, the underhanded tricks end up costing more - something you obviously cannot afford - putting the balance in the hands of the first place position.You may be wondering, "Wow, he's whining a lot about losing a game!" and no, I've won my fair share, both against the A.I. and humans; I write this from both perspectives.  If you get ahead of someone, you literally can continue to open the gap between yourself and second place, just because I landed on that Iron first.  I truly did not find the game enjoyable when I was trouncing my competition; it was far more fun when we were on equal footing, needing to make quick decisions to outwit each other.I still give this game a positive recommendation.  After all is said and done, I very much enjoyed myself playing Offworld Trading Company in its current state.  I cannot say I will ever play it again though, which is why the $40 price tag seems extremely steep.  This is one of those games that you will love to play a lot and never play again.  As much as I would love to launch it in future, after having figured out "how to win," the game has lost all flavour due to its extreme lack of content.Should the developers revisit the economy and add an abundance more resources, giving all players a chance to compete, then I feel this would be an exceptional real-time strategy game.  Until then however, this is a game of it's own genre: Real-time clicking competition.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												There is a really strong caveat in recommending this, which is that the tags on the store page are extremely deceptive.  This is not an economic game, this is not a simulation game, this is not a trading game, and this is not a base building game.  This is a very fast paced, micro-intensive RTS.Its an interesting take on the RTS genre, because you don't have any units to control.  But make no mistake, this game plays very similarly to one of the micro practice maps for SC2, and uses essentially the same skillset.  Its just that instead of microing units around a map, you're constantly scanning the map, spamming abilities, and hitting the buy/sell button.  I know it may sound like this is fundamentally different from microing units around, but in practice its not.   If you're someone who likes the micro game in SC2, you'll like this game.  If you're a more casual RTS player then this probably isn't the game for you.  There's nothing wrong with that, and the game itself is quite well done, but the game is definitely targetted towards a relatively small niche and the store page/reviews in no way reflect that.

Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								As many other reviewers of this game have stated, the price point of this game is simply way too high for what you get, especially considering the game is in early access and I expect them to only raise the price from here. I don't shy away from early access games and I've had more than a few that never really progressed as I hoped/expected, but most I feel I at least get my money's worth out of them, but at $35, this is one of the few I definitely regret picking up.It's not really a bad game and it is an interesting concept, but the sacrifices the developers have made to make matches fit into 20-30 minutes have made the gameplay chaotic and often times inconsistent... not things that are typically appreciated in an economic game, competitive real-time or not. It also lacks any decent mechanisms to defend yourself from sabatoge or simply being bought out once the bulk cash transactions start coming in in the late game, so winning or losing a match can be both frustrating and unsatisfying. You can carefully manuever yourself into an advantageous position to corner a market on a resource or disrupt an opponent's supply chain but then you get 75k from one offworld shipment of a base resource like oxygen, dump all your resources on the market, and hit a + button a couple times and win without any of it mattering.The game definitely lacks depth and each match usually hinges completely on the base materials like glass or power. Regardless of which resources are the focus on any given match, the gameplay is mostly the same every time. It can be fun and it does have potential if the developers are open to some design changes, but it is simply not worth $35 or more right now and I seriously doubt it ever will be.I would love to be wrong and see great things happen for this game as development continues, but right now, I can not recomment it.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												I have been playing Offworld Trading Company since release in March and have found it to be an excellent game.  The game is easy to learn and play but has a depth that belies it simplicity.  There are 4 HQ types with different traits and advantages, they provide a wide variety of strategies to win the game.  Offworld Trading is best described as an Economic RTS, as you upgrade your HQ you receive more claims to mine resources or refine them via factories/plants, sell your products into the market to gain cold hard cash.  Use your cash buy shares in completing companies eventually taking them over and reigning supreme as the only corporation left standing.  There is no combat system as such, no need to furiously click your way to victory, however there is a Black Market function where you can buy various items to either slow you opponents down, like an EMP to freeze his/her factories for a short time or mutiny their power plant glassworks, taking those tasty profits for yourself.  Other items will give you a boost, increasing your production or a goon squad to catch those stinking saboteurs.  The game is very well balanced and there are many ways to squeeze the most profit out of your tiles.   I play multiplayer exclusively because it's so much fun, the AI is excellent and well programmed, but playing against 6 other people is miles better, this game really shines when you have a good group of human players.  Typical game lasts 20 -40mins which is the perfect length for me.ProsSimple to play and very rewarding for the casual player, but plenty of depth for more serious gamers   Very well polished, stable and balanced for an Early Access game, imo it could be released tomorrow at full price.Gameplay is intense and very fun but not frantic like other RTS games.Devs are very active in the community and actually listen to feedback.ConsDifficult to find higher level players to play with if you live in Europe (unless you want to stay up till 2am)If you like RTS games then this is a must buy, I am very happy with my purchase, great re playability, really shines in multiplayer.  10/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												I bought this on the recent sale, and it is easily worth the full price for any strategy game lover. Where to start? I feel like I have to explain first, and foremost, what this game actually brings to the table. I am a lover of RTS and the turn-based strategy staples. I am also a lover of MOBA type multiplayer. I think it is important to note that the single player and multiplayer are almost two different games. They follow the same mechanics, but the single player feels almost like a career-mode where matches are linked together and unlocking perks for your chosen CEO along the way, while the multiplayer brings the most intense purely competitive gameplay that I have seen in years. Even in the games where I get trounced I am left feeling like I have more grasp on the game than before, and know this is a benefit for future games.The reason this game is amazing to me is that there isn't a "meta" strategy to just win. This game requires a fluid strategy with the goal being to acquire competing companies by buying a majority stake. The goal is to develop supply chains that produce goods from basic to higher tier products made out of those base resources. One players actions in the first minute may require a fundamental shift in the strategy of another. This is way more than the generic paper-rock-scissors we see in a lot of strategy games, or simply any competitive game.This brings us to the learning curve. If you have played a strategy game before 2000 then the tutorial is amazingly informative. For those new to the RTS genre (I see this game mostly as such), it will feel unfair to lose repeatedly at first. These losses are the growing process of grasping the mechanics. As you start you will realize you have been handed a toolbox with a dozen tools, and winning only comes when you know the time and place to use each tool. You will lose suddenly and realize that you simply forgot about one aspect, but the oversight is just one more learning opportunity. Players that go into a situation saying I want to always use this specific company faction or believe they have an infallible one-size-fits-all strategy will lose, and quickly at that.I have seen reviews where the reviewers say that the game is about speed and not strategy. The speed simply comes with playing and understanding the resources needed for expansion. Again for RTS players think of the first time you grasped how to expand bases quickly to reach end game in the likes of Warcraft, C&C, AoE. Once you know how to upgrade quickly then it is time for strategy to kick in. The tutorial games are difficult at first, but only because the learning curve of these levels want you to graduate with the knowledge of the mechanics before letting you loose.  The multiplayer wait times can be on the long side for FFA(4-player) matches, but the game allows you to do the 'Daily Challenge' scenario or a skirmish against the AI while you wait. That game will be autosaved before entering the multiplayer match. 1v1 matches have much shorter wait times. I think 1v1 is easier (may be different for each person), but FFA is where the real fun lies.If you like single player more than Patron DLC is a must (adds aspects to campaign mode), and I think the Ceres DLC is definitely worth it as well (adds new resources, new power supply, new map type).TL;DR:Anyone that wants to be in control of their own game strategy on the fly in quick, highly competitive matches with RTS elements must own this game. A lot of gamers lately want their hand held by a cut-and-paste guide that will ensure they win a high amount of the time. Thankfully this is not that game, this game requires one to like facing challenges.Edit: I'm now over 115 hours in, and this review was from about 15 hours in. I had only seen the tip of the iceburg. This game continues to amaze and I am still learning more with every game 100 hours later.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a decent game, but the price is a bit high for what you get. They definitely have a lot of work to do before the game releases. I wouldn't term this is an economy game. This is an attack your opponent RTS, but the attacks are different than your standard RTS. I was expecting a laid back economic builder in the sim city fashion that was a real-time game. This is more of a fast paced eliminate your opponent game like your regular combat RTS.Playing on the easiest difficulty and the game on slow speed I feel rushed. If I do not start buying out my opponents quickly they will buy me out. My games typically last 30 minutes to an hour because the AI pushes the game so fast. If I go any slower I will lose.I find it difficult to beat the computer. I feel like I have to use exploits to even have a chance. The way I am able to beat the computer is to find the least populated resource and build my base on it to reduce the amount even more. Then I claim all that I can of the remaining. This slows the computer down a little bit and will allow me to prolong the game. I have never played on anything except the lowest difficulty because of how challenging it is.If you are looking for a casual economic game then this is probably not what you are looking for. If you are looking for a fast paced RTS that the first 5 minutes of game play can make or break you then this might be it for you. There are a lot of much better RTS' out there. As an economic builder I don't think this games is going to appeal to the type of casual player that would be interested in economic builders.Game stability? The game has crashed on me about 5 times while I was playing tonight over the course of about 5 hours.This game is supposedly in Alpha. If it is truly in alpha then they are still planning to add more content to the game. If they are just fine tuning, bug testing, and performance optimizing then this is not in alpha. If it's alpha then I look forward to the complete game. If this is beta then I'm disappointed.If you have $40 to spare and would like something to do for a day or two then I would pick this up. If you have high expectations for this purchase then I would suggest waiting to buy.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Early Access Review
Short version:Interesting premise but lacking in execution. As of yet the game is very short in content. One can spend roughly 3 hours in it before one has seen everything and a feeling of "this needs more time in development" settles in. The only reason I personally spent more time on this was from coming back for matches between patches to see what they added (and it wasn't much, mostly balance adjustments and bug fixes). The developers consider the game "feature complete" and in doing so crush any hope of new game mechanics to broaden gameplay.Would rate the experience 4 out of 10, in particularly in hindsight of the the high price for the small game one gets in return.Long version:Offworld Trading Company has the complexity of a typical smartphone or board game with a tedious buy/sell minigame in the form of juggling various goods around. Player influence on total econonmy or pricing is negligible - you can not corner a market or establish a strategic monopoly as it's always possible to buy resources from the market, even if nobody supplies them. A single match is roughly 30 minutes in duration but can take up to 40 in rare cases. Gameplay is heavily streamlined to remain within tight confines.To illustrate a few mechanics:Upon starting a match one has to scan the map to uncover its limited resource fields, quickly slam down a base building and then build extractors on resource deposits. Automated NPC ships haul the harvested resource back to the HQ once the extractor building is full. Those units can not be interacted with directly (except for a very rare piracy action card one can win in a random auction to steal enemy supplies for a short duration) and merely exist as a visual way to see when the next resource-"tick" happens. They are the only units on the map, everything else is just buildings.There is a limit over how many tiles of the map you can build on as building on a tile consumes "claims" - you start with a handfull of those and only get a handful more for upgrading your HQ, which in return only has 4 steps and stops at level 5. A few screenshots on the Store page show how small the fully upgraded "base" will get. As buildings give an output adjaciency bonus one just builds a cluster of similar buildings and spreads out the other clusters of different types to avoid getting targeted by expensive sabotage actions players can buy (with a cooldown), such as EMP strikes.The match itself is won by buying out the competition. This starts by acquiring "shares" of the enemy company - the total amount of shares each company has can be adjusted with difficulty settings but is typically 10. The more shares one owns the cheaper will be the final takeover - that option simply becomes unlocked once all shares have been bought by someone (no matter if a company bought its own shares or someone else did) - there is no way to prevent takeover, even if the company is doing well financially, as long as the enemy has enough cash on hand to buy one out. This means one could lose if an enemy simply stops spending cash very early to rush a buyout while one would rather upgrade and then have the stronger income/economy to win in the long run. This sounds more complex than it is but at its core feels unrefined and gets boring rather quickly.In technical regards the game is very simple and seems to be made in the Unity Engine 4 - as such it only supports single threading, has greatly limited scale of maps and environments, medicore visual fidelity and tacked-on UI. At this stage the UI seems extremely clunky - I'd have hoped it's a placeholder but as they are adjusting and updating it while adding new buttons I somehow get the feeling they'll keep it this way.The current voice files are text-to-speech placeholders with awkward pronounciation but are the most memorable feature of the game - sentences like "Just look at all the money." from a creepy robot voice are simply hilarious.All in all it feels like the designers behind this project had a nifity idea but no great vision with merely a few simple game systems in spirit of a board game in their heads - the blanks have been filled with convoluted mechanics. I do not believe the developers will give it a complete overhaul between now and release and as such can not recommend a purchase.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
Early Access Review
GenreIts not often I come across a game which is a totally new genre but I think Offworld fits the bill.Offworld is a strange hybrid of 4X and RTS but without the combat, however that description alone does not come close.MatchesMatches are generally short (30 min) and start off with a similar feel to 4X games, you explore expand and start to exploit the landscape, but you need keep moving, resting on your laurels will get you left behind by the AI, time is the unlisted resource in this game.Each game is a struggle for economic dominance with the winner buying out the shares of the opposing companies, now this may sound a little dry, but the fun comes with how you achieve this.  There are many ways of getting the upper hand in Offworld, with strategies ranging from predicting trends, to dominating resources, outpacing others with research and new techs, managing your debt, or using a miriad of black market options.Early access The technical quality of this game is very good, it works better than some "finished" games, no crashes, everything works smoothly and looks great.Content wise I may like a few more victory conditions or changes to the current ones, other than that just needs some more tooltips and tutorials.CampaignThe campaign mode offers a small meta game involving highering engineers and expanding colonies, it also has some new victory conditions, and can been played with a variety of different colony "managers".ConsMatches end too abruptly for my likeing, and I usually find it disapionting when they do... but this hasn't stopped diving right back in to new matches to try out new strategies.A few tweaks to the victory mechanics should help a lot here, maybe adding multiple victory conditions, and or making current ones more obvious and exciting.My ReviewI've not completed the campiagn or tried multiplayer yet, so I'll update things when I do.This is a different type of RTS, centred around economy rather than battles, but still very satisfying, forethought and timing are a must, a very enjoyable game.

Posted: August 18, 2016
												I waited for the summer sale to buy this since it looked interesting, but not $40 interesting.  Oh how wrong I was.  The campaign mode has significant replayability, since you can change up who you play as and the difficulty levels and what not.Yoshimi and New Meridians seem to be the easiest factions to play as for a new player, since it is easy to exploit their strengths.  But the other factions also have their advantages, and understanding that strategy keeps me coming back to this game when I can.The graphics are really nice, the music and sound effects are gentle and pair nicely with the game, and the interface is pretty intuitive once you know your way around.  The tutorial missions are great and get you up and running with the game quickly; they are some of the best tutorials I have seen in a RTS/4x game.  It also helps that the developers added a lot of amusing commentary in the tutorials to keep the player engaged.Overall I say that the replay value and lack of bugs make $40 completely worth it.Make Mars great again!
