content:
Posted: February 12
												TL;DR - I like the game for attempting a different and solid approach to the stategy genre and I recommend it for the slower-paced buy highly chaotic nature of matches themselves, but it certainly isn't everybody's cup of tea so if you're not into those things, or expect the traditional RTS experience, give this game a pass.There's certainly a divide among the people who've tried this game, I think it stems from a clashing between a misunderstanding of the game's main concept, the expectations from watching a couple of gameplay videos and playing the game itself, which is understandable because this isn't a game that's easily put in a few words.It seems that people are now associating RTS with APM and fast reflexes exclusively, which is another reason why this game is such a departure for most of the users who try it. Out of the gate, this game is nothing like the traditional RTS: you aren't microing units, you aren't building an army, you aren't going for the high APM, you aren't scouting bases or out-blobbing the opponent's blob army. Instead you are making decisions for the most part, decisions that impact the course of the game over time instead of immediately, leading to a slower paced game based around matches of wits and constantly monitoring a wide variety of indicators that are further influenced by the chaos theory that stems from the many other choices that other players are making during a match.This is a game that demands close observation of numbers and the things that affect those numbers so that you make informed decisions that lead to you out-witting the competition over matches that are certainly longer when compared to other multiplayer games, especially those that belong to more recent launches. It's also a game that assumes that you can properly learn its rules, which is why the training wheels come off sooner and there's huge rifts in the handholding in between difficulty settings. The computer doesn't cheat the higher you go (at least, if you don't go higher than manager which is the standard difficulty), it just reacts sooner and expects you to keep up the pace through, again, decisions based on proper vigilance of information and indicators.I admit to having a bias for this kind of game, since I really like strategy games, especially those driven by economic aspects and this one is certainly all about the incredibly unpredictable nature of economics and a caricaturization of the cutthroat corporate environment which all serves to keep me engaged and entertained, making for a good game in my book considering both the beautiful audiovisual design and the solid mechanics. At the same time, I find it easy to empathize with the people who get put off by this game, its rules are certainly different, it demands different things from the player, and matches themselves never tend to play out the same way twice, even on the exact same conditions because there's always something else that you, and the remaining players, can choose to do.I thoroughly recommend the game but only if you like slower paced games with lots of stuff happening at the same time, along with learning new things and experiencing a different kind of strategy games. If you aren't one for patience, expecting the standard fast-paced, high APM, insane reflexes gameplay, I suggest you go for something else.

number of helpful: 19 of 24 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								So what should I write about this game. I know it is still in Early Access but it doesn't look like it will change much more until the final release. After all it appears pretty much finished so far.First of all, this game is fun. Actually I like the game style. It is reminds pretty much on playing Civ.The problem is, where Civ offers a very wide variety of gameplay elements (from war, over diplomacy, economy, religion etc.) this game only took the economic part of if.This unfortunately offers very little replay value. You basically start every game somewhere on the map, building all type of "farms" for resources and hope for the best.My biggest problem however is that the interaction with the other companies (e.g. players) is very limited and comes only to light when they are buying a spot of good resources you were looking after.So then, you end up in a skirmish of selling recources when you can in order to make money and buy the other company shares in order to win.This looks every game more or less the same because all the elements that made Civ so great are missing.The only interaction are a few "illegal" actions like sabotage you might do. But even this has limited effect (e.g. the opponent's mines are blocked for a minute). The game offers no diplomacy (not even on an economic way like making a syndicate, negotiation or trading agreements like I offer you electricity in order to get better offers for your steel producion) or corporate espionage (like stealing other players inventions). After all the game goes very quick (a game might take 30 - 90 minutes. So there is no grand strategy like investing in late-game infrastructure / units etc. Just a bit of research can be done which basically leads to improved production (e.g. instead of 10 electricity, the power plant offers 15).This leads after all to the strategy of building your own variety of buildings in order to be best prepared for changing prices (if you sell stuff, the price drops) so you might sell what ever looks best at the moment.To come to a conclusion, this game looks promising. I really like the style, it is easy to start with - no real need for many tutorials but even if you need some, it is done quickly. Still it lacks of gameplay.So for the time being, I can only reccomend the game for fans of economic realtime strategy gamers (even though there are no units to control).For people who are looking for another Civ-like game with grand strategy, long term multiplayer sessions with different victory conditions, this game is unfortunately not what you are looking for.

number of helpful: 15 of 17 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
Rank: 9/10Recommendation(s): Play Galactic Civilization or Civilizations IV/VMajor Theme: Dirty Violent Capitalism.Bought at Price: $25 - Game + Current DLCsNo shooting? No turns to take? No physical combat between players? A fine demonstration of how violent capitalism can get? YES.If you aren't biting your nails when stock prices between you and your rival get close...Something is wrong with you.


It's quite close 
A Screenshot of Offworld Trading Company
By: DarK_St3alth




If you aren't excited when you finish research on a patent that helps you keep a monopoly...Something is wrong with you.If you aren't glad to buy your rival out when it's down from 4 companies to 2...Something is wrong with you.If you aren't mad at someone doing so well compared to you, and decide to buy a nuke to screw them over..Something is wrong with you.Or... you could be a filthy socialist and need to see a doctor. It's one of the two.It should not come as a surprise this game is the #1 top seller on Steam under "economy" right now. Granted it's 66% off, and probably not worth the normal $45, this game does however bring scarcity to boredom.It's interesting to see Stardock reach out to more than just Galactic Civilization, yet another economy game they made.One of the biggest issues for me coming from GalCiv was, "how are players going to take turns". I knew it wasn't 4X like GalCiv or Civilizations IV or V, but placement of your base or settlement is very important. How do you prevent players from going into a scramble to be the first one to put something down?


Offworld Trading Company 
A Screenshot of Offworld Trading Company
By: DarK_St3alth




There's a very good solution put in place. A ticker for Debt, sock price, and Bond rating. The quicker you are to place, the more debt and thus lower stock price and higher bond rating you will have.What if I keep waiting and waiting? While I haven't seen starting debt go any higher than +$1,100, you can be paid for base placement (note the plus sign). That assumes there is more than 1 player waiting.You can also get additional claim points if you are the last player to place. The whole game is built around tile claims, so these additional claims can outweigh a better starting position.Tricky thing is, as you play the game, you will find that you will just have to play all of the 4 different corporations. Some have different building materials from others, some have certain bonuses, some don't need certain resources to survive.If you find yourself in a bad position, with a gloomy future, you can even the playing field with auctions and the black market.


Offworld Trading Company 
A Screenshot of Offworld Trading Company
By: DarK_St3alth




While it can be silly to pay $56,000 for a land claim not even 5 minutes into the game, other things do come up such as underground nukes, computer viruses, or even diet pills that somehow make your workers faster. It's capitalism, self interest is the center focus of the game.While this game doesn't look graphically intensive, it does however require a graphics card and operating system that can run DirectX 11. Windows 7 with some recent GT/GTX 700 or higher series graphics card would make a good choice if you need to upgrade.One of the issues people seem to be running into is that they play games in english, but they set their operating system in some other language. They discover that the game uses their native language instead of english. This is fixed by simply going into the settings menu, and selecting your desired language. The game uses the OS language by default.I don't normally make a point of this – but I should probably make a note of it somewhere – there are several options for those colour blind. That's correct, the game has options built in to adjust colours to make them more "readable" for those who suffer from it. I can't really remember the last time I saw this in a game.While I've only played the daily challenges, learn to play series, and 4-player free for all, I haven't really seen the "COOP" aspect of the game yet.Another point I should bring up is that I don't think I will be getting 100's of hours out of this game. The content is lacking, even with DLC.The game UI/HUD might be large, I feel that way, but you do get used to it.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I've always thought that one of the problems with modern games is that they are a bit too obvious in thier attempt to make you feel good by - in essence - letting you win which is why the demanding difficulty of Offworld Trading Company is so very enjoyable.As I pass the twenty five hour mark on Offworld I'm also playing The Witcher 3 which allows me to perform some very heroic slashes that seem far beyond the mashing of left mouse I am doing.  It is very pretty but it seems to remove me from the mix.  The Witcher 3 is great but sometimes I feel like I'm a distraction to it, rather than the other way around.Offworld Trading Company is the opposite.  Go disengaged in a minute of playing Offworld and you lose.  Make bad decision in Offworld and you lose.  Play well but not as well as someone else (including the impressive AI) and you lose.  Every defeat one can imagine a cause for an consider how to fix it.  The moment I realised that not mining a resource because it could be bought dirty cheap was a viable strategy was a revelation made better because it was not hinted at, or revealed in a tutorial, or given to me in any way other than through experience.The result is a game where one feels an authorship over victory (or defeat) that creates a more compelling narrative than many a game that sell themselves on their narratives.  An irony of sorts there.

content:
Posted: January 6
AbstractOffworld Trading Company (OTC) is a very capitalist and economically oriented game. The game itself is not a one big giant campaign, but a competitive match between various companies vieing for the business of blossoming offworld colonies on Mars. Your goal, buy out your competitors.GameplayOTC has very interesting gameplay, not just in the respect that hey, you're makin' money, but that you are actively participating in the offworld markets. These offworld markets being Earth's satellites like asteroid colonies and Mars colonies. You must set down your company's HQ in a spot close to useful resources, and even those will change based on what company you are playing as. Robots don't require life support, but humans obviously do.In the world of competitive marketing, you must produce and maintain enough resources to play the economy. Various resources will become highly demanded for, you in turn must produce more of these in order to satisfy that market. But be careful. Don't produce resources that no one needs.On top of selling these resources, you must produce some for your own good. Upgrades and new buildings require resources as well. Expanding can't be done without it. Mine silicone, carbon, pump water, electrolize hydrogen and air, and the list goes on.Gameplay of OTC can change based on who you are playing as. Previously I noted life support, robotic companies don't require and humans do, well, if you're a robot, save operating costs and don't build electrolizers. Other companies can build things differently than others. New Meridians are very science based people and have developed technology that can manufacture resources directly on top of a resource deposit versus having a mine yank it out and send it to the HQ.Overall, the game whether on a public stage or offline with the AI can be very competitive.MechanicsThere are multiple systems in OTC. The most important one being the resource market. Selling resources like O2 and Food usually turn a large profit for manufacturing companies. But also, there is debt. Should you worry about it? In my experience, not exactly, as when you start makin' the offworld shipments you can make so much profit that the debt will literally eviscerate.The black market is also very important. Corporations may seem very up tight and concerned about making a profit and caring for their customers, but when it comes down to corporation versus corporation, dirty deeds will be done. EMPs and electrical storms can take out production rates, goon squads will protect your stuff from thieving corporations, and worker strikes can turn manufacturing plants to your favor. But be careful, you aren't the only one that can use the black market.Shares. The game winner. Without shares, you don't win...well, you don't lose either but more importantly you don't win. Shares in your own company will protect you, along with how much one of your shares is worth. invest in your company and increase production and your worth will rise. Buy competitor shares and keep them on their toes. Then, once you buy enough shares, buy out the company, buy out the company and you have one less competitor.ScoreGraphics: 8/10 - Not the greatest in the world and some things will clip if you look at them real hard, but this is easily looked over.Gameplay: 9/10 - Makes me want to play more all the time. It's the reason I played for 2 extra hours when I first bought it.Mechanics: 9/10 - Makes this game what it is. Very well thought through and makes for very interesting gameplay at times.Online Play: 7/10 - Takes a hot minute to find a match but when you do, all the more fun!Overall: 8.9/10Very well designed game, and leave it to a previous Sid Meier's developer to do it! I do recommend this game, but make sure you have the time to finish a match if you go online.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Offworld Trading Company is a new genre of game, which is a blend of several styles into its own new style. A fine balance bringing to the table an awesome game.On some sides, it reminds me of the old RTS Monopoly Tycoon, with the multiplayer capitalism management on one hand and the real time business sim on the other hand. (The auction system is by the way fantastic !) While at the same time, the game is grand by its simplicity of the resources manegement and strategy planning, maybe similar to Settlers with the logistics supply chain of raw materials up to the final produces.This game can enter into the History of Gaming, that it is at the same time a smart game, with in depth game anaylyzis without having dozens of parameters, just a few interesting resources with different rules and needs which intricately are depending on each other in a beautiful supply and demand concept. And at the same time, it is a game fun to play, where you don't have to learn dozens of recipes, where you quickly have fun (a few tutorials teach you the basic ropes of the game, same as chess, the game can be learnt in a very short time, but it can require a long time to master :)!). Lots of events occur in game, which can change the whole course of a development, pirates intercepting your cargos, mutiny of your geothermal powerplant at the very wrong time... well you get the picture hehe !You might be thinking that this game sounds like a very long game to play, spending hours of planification, development and implementation ... such as a Heart of Iron, Total War or a Civ game for instance ... well not at all, the games lasts hardly more than 30 minutes ! And this is in the case you are not losing after a few minutes!All in all, this game, is, I believe, refreshing with its new genre, smart with its simple but challenging puzzles mechanics for the colonization of Mars, all this while having a good fun when utilizing the resources of the planet.The question is ... will you challenge yourself ... go play this legendary Offworld Trading company ?

number of helpful: 19 of 25 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Offworld Trading Company , although still in early access, does a great job of defining stages to the flow of a match. Why do I mention this first? Because the best RTSs I've played have loosely defined stages that allow for depth of strategy at each step. Available funds  are precious early in a match and there are several outlets to utilize these funds. You can upgrade early to try and get a lead in resource gathering, you can use the black market to shut down your opponent's income, or you can manipulate the market to make it more costly for other players to catch up to you. As the game progresses, the options available to you also expand, and strategies abound.The mid-game in Offworld Trading Company is where the most important blows start being traded. In order to ensure your company is not bought, you must purchase and hold onto at least 5 of your own stock (which then have to be bought out all at the same time in order for another player to remove you from the game); however, the money available to you to buy your own stock could also be used to take out another player by beating them to 6 of their stock. This makes decisions on who to buy stock in, whether to purchase your own stock, or whether to continue to upgrade to get a lead in the late game potentially deadly. If the wrong choice is made, other players will take advantage of your mistakes.Late game, if the game hasn't already been decided by the mid-game brawl, comes down to endurance. Each remaining player's goal is to get enough money to buy out the others before being bought themselves. There are several advanced buildings in Offworld Trading Company that allow for varying strategies to accomplish this task and, depending on the state of the market, each strategy has a place and can allow for you to outspend your opponents.An economic RTS is a fairly unexplored idea, so be prepared to endure a fairly high learning curve before becoming competent in the gameplay. I'm sure most of what I've mentioned in the paragraphs above means very little to someone who hasn't played Offworld Trading Company , but the point is to show the depth of gameplay Offworld Trading Company allows for.So, let's break this game into its parts:Content: 5/10Multiplayer is where this game shines. There is a campaign mode, but it is currently very limited.Animations: 9/10There is little animation in the game, but what has been done is done well.Graphics/Artwork/Illustrations: 9/10Once again, there are few graphical elements required for this style of game, but the graphics are this gen. and well done.Gameplay: 10/10Loads of depth to multiplayer games, and a good pacing built in to the gameplay.Controls:10/10I would only give less than a 10 in this category if there was no ability to change hotkeys or the controls were unresponsive/glitchy. Although I do not like the layout of the default hotkeys, I don't consider that a reason to downgrade this category.Reliability: 8/10The game is still early access and some bugs are being worked out. There are some issues with making lobbies and changing hosts mid-game that are being worked out, as well as a few smaller glitches.User Interface (UI): 9/10Very well put together to give an overview of how the game is progressing as well as easy access to your options. I took away a point because I think that the notification system could use some work when you are targeted by the black market or a shortage/surplus occurs.Music and Sounds: 10/10Some sounds are still being created, but the recently added new music and the completed sounds are very well done.Originality: 10/10I can only imagine how difficult it must be to enter a new sub-genre into the books. Soren Johnson and his team have done a great job in developing this original idea.Community Vibe: 10/10The developers listen closely to player feedback and are very active on the forums. The game is updated on a regular basis and has improved with each iteration.Total Score: 90/100If you're a fan of RTSs or enjoy market manipulation, I can highly recommend this game to you. If you enjoy a challenge, Offworld Trading Company will provide it to you. This is a Game You Absolutely Must Have :) .Although there is plenty of room for casual players in this game, with its current player base of dedicated fans, I'd recommend people who put themselves in this category to watch some videos of the game before deciding to purchase.Here is a video of some higher level gameplay with good commentary: 


YouTube™ Video: Offworld Trading Company: No Buyout Tournament Day 2. Soren, Veivi, Ultrapope, Blackmagic Game 1 

			Views: 516		

			Tournament game featuring new stock mechanics.

number of helpful: 31 of 47 people (66%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 17
												If you were hoping for M.U.L.E. or any other game about forming a business in the crucible of the wonder that is offworld colonization, then this is not that game.  However, if you like to win at games about number accumulation in real time, then you are in luck.  Offworld Trading Company is the epitome of real time number accumulation games!The gameplay is basically day trading as a manic depressive.  Place buildings to make some commodity related numbers go up and others go down over time.  Some tiles are worth more numbers than others, but you have a very limited number of claim numbers to place.  Perform acts of sabotage to lower your opponents' numbers, but be careful: it costs cash numbers!  Whenever you buy something, the cost number of that commodity goes up.  Whenever you sell something, the cost number goes down.  Can you consistantly sell the most commodity numbers when they have the highest value numbers?  Usually you have no idea who is shifting what numbers.  When you play this game, this is your life now.To win the game, you need to earn the biggest amount of numbers to buy your opponents' stocks so your numbers eat them in a "hostile takeover."  Lets say both you and your opponent have enough money to buy the other out: first click wins, because numbers!  Mercifully, games of Offworld Trading Company are usually over within a half-hour, but win or lose you will have literally nothing to show for it.  In a story-based game you may have heard a story.  In a building game, you might have built something cool.  In a 4X game, enough might have happened that you ended up building a story.  But there's nothing at all memorable about a match of Offworld Trading Company, just a sense of relief that the frantic shifting of numbers is over.I tried to salvage this by getting good at Offworld Trading Company, but now I don't think it's possible.  I tried playing Skirmish on "manager" difficulty (a level playing field) and the AI wins every time.  I tried prioritizing upgrading my base.   I tried prioritizing having the most of the highest value commodity.  I tried cornering the market via tackling a scarce resource.  None of this works, the AI first out-upgrades my base and then buys me out before I catch up.  Maybe the AI is programmed to know something about the game I don't, maybe a computer is just naturally better at shifting numbers than a human player, or maybe it just flat out cheats.  At this point, I honestly don't care anymore, I'm just sad.In summary, Offworld Trading Company is a saddening game that makes me hate numbers.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Offworld trading company is a real time strategy game focussing on simulating economy and free market trade. This is not really a tycoon game because it's not about gradually building your business over time. Instead each game is a short (30 to 60 minute) race against your competitors to see who can buy out each other's companies first, by setting up an effective and efficient organisation.You do this by producing, buying and selling resources in such a way that ensures profits in the short and long term. Everything you do has a benefit and a cost, using resources but producing them at the same time. You need to ensure that you read and predict market trends so that you are producing the right goods at the right time. It's all about supply and demand. If electricity is scarce and you're not producing your own, you'll end up spending a fortune buying it. If the market is flooded with food you might as well buy it rather than waste land and resources to make it yourself. Likewise, if there is a fuel shortage and you are producing a lot of fuel, you can make a lot of money selling it at high prices.Don't let the simple (thought nice) graphics and animations fool you, there is a lot to this game. The depth and complexity makes it both fun and intelectually stimulating. The best part is that no two games are the same, and there are several strategies that you can successfully use to win. Also, what worked for you last time might not work for you in the next game. This is emergent gameplay at it's best.There isn't much to dislike about this game, as an economic simulation it is unique and well balanced. It will take you about an hour or two to really get into the game and to appreciate why it is so good. That said, for the average player the full price (40 USD) is definitely a bit steep. It is still early access though so it might be a different story once the full release is out.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Think of it as a sort of competitive SimCity.  You build your "city" over terrain that offers various resources with the goal of growing your access to valuable ones while also being able to afford the industry.  A nice big patch of Iron, just ripe for mining?  Do you have the water, power, and electricity that you'll need to run that mine?  Can you buy those needs with the profits from that mine?  Up to you to figure it out.  Throw in competitors who will attempt to get there first, or sabotage you if you get there first, and you have a challenging economic game.The interface and general gameplay information is simple enough to use (it is NOT a spreadsheet simulator at all!), very similar to the Civilization series, and you can get into the game very quickly.A couple of things on the downside, however.  There is very, very little explanation for what you'll need to do or why you need to do it.  The first few games had me box myself into a corner because there was no explanation covering what you'll need to start a basic successful colony/company.  I still don't know how to hire specialists (required in order to build certain buildings) because the game tells me I need them, but not how to get them.   It's also very difficult to visually see what your opponents are doing; there's a scrolling bar of text that gives you updates, but it's not particularly useful while you're trying to manage 100 other things just to stay afloat.I haven't tried multiplayer yet, so I cannot speak to that.Overall, definitely recommended if this is your cup of tea.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												This is an interesting economy tycoon game.  The first few games are tough but after a while you get the hang of it.   But, then after a while you see how basic the public stock ownership is, and the game starts to lose its sparkle.  Especially when you can lose the game so easily by it.  And, then you realize how unrealistic it is.  So, then you try to focus on building, and you start to realize the game is really kind of confining,  The maps are small even when you pick huge.  Then you find yourself competing for the same area with 4 or more competitors that in a very short time build up to the limits and try to take over you and each other.  That gets old quick because you want to build and develop Mars, not just fight in a little plot of land on it.  Finally, you say to yourself, well how is multiplayer.  If your lucky enough to find someone in the lobby and play, i imaging it could be fun.  I've been there 3 times and its been empty.  So, up front it looks fun and interesting, and it is for a while, but the replyabillity is limited.  I think it's overpriced for what you get.  Wait until it drops under $15.  Just my opinion.

content:
Posted: April 16
												Seems like a lot people hated the game because they expected it to be like Civ. It is a shame for the game is actually an RTS, closer to Starcraft but with so much more diversity and depth. Unlike starcraft, the strategy is centered around grabbing ressources and messing up with your opponents using black market powers.The game is just always evolving, with 4 different factions who define your playstyle entirely. There are vastly different maps, pushing you to adapt to the new conditions and resources available every time. Finally, the black market adds another layer of complexity entirely as different powers are available every game. A game where you can uncover new ressources will be drastically different from one where you can claim more lands or one where you can steal ressources from each others.Finally, the developers are constantly updating the game with new add-ons that offer new sets of rules and challenges to adapt to.If you want a fun deep RTS with a max duration of 30 minutes, that will challenge you constantly to adapt and judge where the market will go, this is the game for you!

Early Access Review
								- PROS -Elements of Stock MarketingElements of Production Mechanics (Supply/Demand) A realistic approach towards coperate financing.Interesting methods of victory. Basic elements of auctioning. Basic elements of share holding. - CONS - Lacking in content. These basic elements should be expanded upon. In game UI could use a rework. Allow for Company to company investment (with return), or unknown shady investment with 5% - 10% or even 30% interest. Those are just some general, throw around ideas. Hope this helps.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												I should mention first that RTS games are the games I dislike the most. I really don't like the whole idea behind going down a memorized checklist for the best builds as quickly as possible. I just don't have the time or patience for that. That said, this game isn't bad so far. I've only played offline because of the above reasons and I don't think this game will change my mind on RTS as a genre. But, there is something about this game that is keeping me hooked where other major titles haven't (Starcraft, Warcraft, CoH, etc). Maybe it's the complete lack of combat or the unique focus on economics. Or that the skirmishes themselves are very short.  It probably helps to have some background knowledge of economics going in, but it's not required. The tutorials do a good job of explaining the basics. And, while I do find myself pausing a lot (and kinda wish there was a turn-based mode as a result), I haven't felt overwhelmed yet. And I appreciate the developers giving options for turning off the black market. If it does end up turning into the typical RTS “build order checklist”, that will be disappointing and I'll update my review accordingly. But, for now, I'd say it's worth the $13.59 price tag. The AI has been competent and the individual games, and approaches as a player, have been fairly unique.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								In Short (from my curator review): "Excellent game whose novel Economic-Strategy ideas will hopefully spawn a long lasting genre of this quality. Dispels the notion that strategy=violence."Longer Form: I am an economics student in graduate school and a sci-fi fan, so as far as I'm concerned OTC was designed specifically for me. The economics & finance in the game is not only fun, but educational and facsinating if you have an interest in those subjects. I love the strategy genre, and have for years, but having a genre so closely tied to violence: Total War, Company of Heroes, Starcraft, Age of Empires, etc. has always bugged me a little bit. Not because I'm a pacifist, but because it takes away from strategic depth to have such a simple zero-sum mechanic at the core of gameplay. With OTC there are not such clear and basic decisions. In a war game: produce units, more is almost always better. In contrast, OTC can't be won, even on the easiest difficulties, by spamming one type of production. You'll inevitably over-supply that commodity and shrink your profits on each sale down to next to nothing while paying through the nose on whatever inputs are associated with that commodity. Simply put, there's more strategic depth. The art style is nice, it is simple as of right now and realistically rendered, I wonder whether there is room to convey information more through the art than is currently done. For instance if the ships transporting resources could convey more about their cargo to lessen the emphasis on the ever-present charts. Note on Early Access: As always, monitor reviews and update logs to note that devs are making progress, but as of the time of writing this review, they are very active and seem to be constantly tweaking and making improvements.A few minor gripes: 1.) My computer is not a world-beater, but can handle most any games on medium or high, however OTC gives me a little trouble with frame-rate so I've had to go down to low settings, which is a shame for such a pretty game.2.) In-game UI could use some poish, main menus and what not are gorgeous so I have faith that these will get better.Recommendation: If you like strategy games you should do one of two things: 1.) Buy it 2.) Wait until it comes out of Early Access, then buy it.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												As a long time RTS and stragegy fan, as well as an extreme Civilazation fan, I have to say I was a bit disappointed with Offworld TC.  As a whole, this game feels more like a fantastic foundatation for a spectacularly complex trading sim versus what it actually offers.  Do not be fooled, you will devour this game in its entirety in a matter of hours.  It does not hold a candle to the complexity and depth that the Civ titles (and other leading titles) have to offer.  I purchased the deluxe edition of this game (on sale) for 39.59.  Within a matter of 2 days had not only beaten the campaign, but had exhausted (unless I missed something) every aspect of playability and replay value that the game has to offer.  A more reasonable price for what this game actually has to offer, at least in single player mode, is more like $10-15.  I found that I had lost the desire to keep playing after a very small amount of time.  I even stuck with it for a bit longer just to see if there was more that I perhaps had missed...turns out I found no reason to keep playing beyond the couple days I devoted to mastering it.  As a fan of the genre, I had high hopes of progress, strategy, and replay value that the best RTS/stragegy/sim/farming/economic games have to offer.  This review is not meant to ONLY bash the game.  With more content, resources, campaign options, and other things of this nature, this game could be epic.  In reality it's nothing more than a foundation for what could be an absolutely fantastic game of depth and strategy.  I would recommend this game only when the price is reduced to something more befitting of a game that lacks everything that was mentioned above.In summary, this game is great and certainly worth playing, but only if the price is right for what the consumer can get out of it.  As of right now however, it feels incomplete and very limited as far as play choices, resources, strategy, economy, variability, and overall complexity,  Kind of sad that its almost over before it begins... I am recommending this game because of its uniqueness and potential but on a scale of 1-10 this game is a 4, at least for the price.

number of helpful: 25 of 38 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really, really, really wanted to like this game. It is right up my alley and I thought it would be a blast. Unfortunately not.  There is no joy in building an economic engine or a profitable company. There is no satisfaction in making good strategies. There is no logic in the buy-out end-game.There will be games in which you are hit three four times a minute by sabotage. Every company will attack you and you can't execute a strategy for the spam. There will be games in which you are the strongest company and suddenly find yourself bought out by a company worth half of your value. And I mean sudden. One moment you are thinking "wow, I am actually generating a profitable company here and then WHAM! Game over!. It's a total WTF moment because there is no clue it's coming.In Railroad Tycoon you could buy up your shares to keep from getting taken over. Not in this game. It's simply not fun.It could be, and should be. But I think the developers have gone down the path of playing so many games with each other that they see the fun in it, but forgot that the fun they are having is only because they know each other and designed the game themselves. I'm sure if I played several hundred hours I would start to get into the nuances of play. But why spend that much time on something that isn't enjoyable just to get to where it might be enjoyable?This is a real shame and the first time in a long time I really feel my money was wasted on a steam purchase.Maybe they will stop and reassess their design. But at this point, this is a game best avoided. This game will need major rethinking and the designers to ask themselves,  what exactly is supposed to be fun?

number of helpful: 36 of 59 people (61%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												I put this game on my wishlist based on the Pedigree of the developers. It seemed an interesting and different take on an RTS and it looked like a harsh business trading simulator. I bought it on sale at 35% off and that came with a free key for a buddy. Called my go to buddy to give it to him and he said "Oh man, I already have it and you are not going to like it. It's fun for a couple of hours but that's it. It's too simplistic to enjoy much longer".Sadly, he was dead on. The game is extremely simplistic. So if you are looking for the varied and intersting types of games you could get from Civ, you won't find it here.I literally enjoyed it for about 4 hours and that was pretty much it. You have four factions who are largely identical. They all make a variation of mines and factories which make exactly the same core components. You take those core components and build one or more of 5 different buildings that can give you an edge like help you produce resource X a bit faster, or get a monopoly on a tech like teleportation, which eleminates the need to transport your goods to your home base.You can then begin to sell your goods to try and make money to buy out your competitor faster than they can buy you out.In the meantime there are a handful of repetitive, boring, dirty tricks you can use to slow them down or speed you up in your pursuit of the one goal, which is buy your competitors out.That's it. That's the whole game. Their variety pitch is that there is an infinite number of ways to play each match because you won't always use the same dirty tricks, but there are only a handful of dirty tricks.If you are interested in a repetitive experience of skirmish matches which last 15 - 60 minutes, and you like fine tuning your ability to deliver the same strategy over and over, then this game is for you.If you are looking for a deep, strategic, intereting RTS with a variety of playstyle and paths to victory, then absolutely not.As polished as the game is, one can see that there is very little depth or substance. My go to gaming friend nailed it when he called it "simplistic". Wish I had called him before I bought the game. I'm going to have to bust it out once a month or so to get in some skirmishes and still have it feel fresh and get my money's worth out of it.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												After playing for 70+ hours, I still don't understand why anyone is making a negative review on this game, unless it was not what they expected. It's Starcraft meets Civilization with a stock market. Except, that it is neither Starcraft nor Civilization. It's something totally unique. If you don't like how short the skirmishes are, then play some campaigns (personally, I wish the campaigns were longer than 7 matches. Marathon, anyone?). If the AI is predictable and unchallenging, then turn up the difficulty and watch them pound you in the ground - it will improve your strategic capability, if nothing else. If you don't like keeping tabs on your competitors while you're busy advancing your own goals, then you're in the wrong genre entirely.The beauty of this game is there isn't just ONE strategy to win, but dozens or perhaps hundreds. There are many choices that can be made (by you and your competition) that can affect the later part of the match. And then you throw in the variability of the game's stock market based resource pricing. Sure, if everyone is producing and selling iron, then the price of iron will tank, but unforeseen and ultimately random events can change anything. You may need to adapt: if you decide to make your fortune on glass and then the price of glass plummits because of market saturation, you have the option to scrap your facilities and focus on something new. It's not a set-it-and-forget-it type of RTS. You have to adjust and adapt to each unique scenario and you may have to do so several times to achieve victory. It's the kind of strategy game that leaves you wanting more.

Each has there strong and weak points. This premise alone seems pretty minimal, right?Wrong.You're gathering your metals, making steel, etc. You start gathering water, or food. You feel safe. You're doing alright, and your money is going up.Suddenly one of your opponents EMPs your grouping of three water generating facilities.Now you're going into debt.Water is $212 a unit. And you need three units a tick. That's $636 you're going into debt, each tick.Your debt risses, you have no spare cash. The "duration" of the EMP is another THIRTY seconds.You sell your stockpile of resources to lower your debt. It seems to be working.But then, a competitor starts buying stock in your company. He already owned 50% and now he's at 80%$22,000 is what it will cost for you to lose the game. Does your competitor have that much?You're still hemoraging money from buying water, like a total noob.The EMP wears off. You pay off your debt. You're back in the black.You buy the last 20% of your own company with all your cash.Then he throws pirates at you, crippling both your food and water shipments.Your water was already low, and you start losing money.But you have food! You'll be fine!And then the last 20% of your stock is bought for the X2 price of $44,000 and your competitor owns you.10/10 Would get bought out again.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Offworld Trading Company is a very refreshing take on the RTS genre. Once ruled by the likes of Starcraft, Warcraft, Age of Empires and Command and Conquer, the genre's popularity has currently taken a turn for the worst. Many attribute its downfall to the success of League of Legends: by distilling the genre to it's very core and simplifying the gameplay, it has become the most played multiplayer game. Offworld Trading Company does this to an even greater level: while League eased the burden on the player by allowing control of just your hero, OTC did away with controlling units entirely.This game innovates in so many aspects that it's difficult for me to list them all. There is no combat, but the multiplayer still feels vicious and fierce. Instead of fighting with guns and swords, your tools of conquer are liquid assets, market manipulation and sometimes Filthy Pirates. No two maps are ever alike: sometimes silicon is lacking, and whoever can secure a monopoly on it will certainly profit later on. Other times, there is little aluminium and by keeping the price high you can prevent your opponents from upgrading. Every game starts with you settling down on Mars as one of four corporations, each as different from each other as Starcraft's factions. The purpose of this is twofold: you are assisting the local colony by producing whatever goods they need, while also looking to become filthy, filthy rich. The early game consists of rushing to upgrade as fast as possible by securing control of your primary resources. Once your HQ reaches level 3, the focus becomes sabotaging your opponents as well as (ab)using the market and other players to make money as fast as possible. Is one of your opponents shipping resources from far away, without producing any fuel? Put down some reactors and make bank on the high fuel price. Does he start producing his own? Sabotage his factories and turn his debt into your money! These kinds of decisions pop up constantly, and you need to be vigilant to seize the opportunity. But when you do, it pays off fast and hard! The game usually ends (after around 20 minutes) in a frantic race to make enough money to buy out your opponents, while preventing them from doing the same. While there may be a clear leader at times, he can be toppled if two or more players gang up on him.This game is fantastic. I wholeheartedly recommend it to fans of the RTS genre, as well as anyone looking for an unique, intelligently designed game. While there is a learning curve, the in-game tutorials do a great job of explaining the interface and the basics of gameplay. I also recommend Zultar's tutorial series to anyone looking for a more in-depth guide. The unofficial official Discord server[discord.gg] is one of the best resources for this game, you can get specific advice and guidance, or just chit-chat, with players that have hundreds, if not thousands of hours played.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
Early Access Review
Offworld Trading Company™ – Competitive Market StrategyRating: RecommendedFor young aspiring entrepreneurs, Earth has grown much too crowded to do business. The vast openness of the barren planet Mars calls to explorers and investors alike. Once the colonies have been established, the entrepreneurs see the potential for profit. Businesses start popping up on the Red Planet – this is where you come in.Offworld Trading Company is a fast-paced strategy game all about manipulating the Martian market, producing goods and buying out other businesses. Natural resources are limited and competition is brutal for control of the richest veins. Placement of mines, extractors, and other resource-producing buildings is critical to amassing enough materials to purchase new structures, upgrade your headquarters and get more claims. Each claim allows you to place one structure – use them wisely.Price values of the thirteen types of resources fluctuates with market activity. Is someone selling off their entire aluminum stash? Expect to see prices nosedive. You can also buy stock in your opponents’ companies. If all stock gets purchased and you have enough money, you can buy them out, causing all their buildings to come under your control. The goal of the game is to be the last man standing by buying out all your opponents.The only bad points this game has so far are its high retail price ($40) and the black market feature. The black market in this game makes investing in buildings risky. Found a high (level 3) water deposit? Someone can purchase an Underground Nuke for a paltry $1000 - $3000 to knock that deposit down to low (level 1) permanently. It seems an unnecessary element in an already risky business environment.I haven’t explored deep into this game, still in Early Access at this point, but it’s been both challenging and rewarding. You may ask “Is it really worth $40 in Early Access?” No. Wait for at least 25% off, preferably 50% or more. If you’re a dedicated economy gamer (Railroad Tycoon, Capitalism series), this might trip your trigger. Pick it up if it goes on sale.Not RecommendedRecommended with Caution- RecommendedHighly RecommendedRecommended as Essential

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Offworld is a unique RTS game that captures the best and worst parts of capitalism, in space! I've been following this game for some time, and I am not disappointed by the results of the hard work of the development team.The overall objective of the game is to become the most profitable off-world trading company by becoming the most profitable and efficient corporation around. You'll achieve this by building supply chains of goods, selling them to a local colony, shipping them off the planet, and using your gains to buyout your competitors while avoiding being bought out yourself.Positives:+Amazing soundtrack by Christopher Tin (composer of Baba Yetu, of Civ 4 fame)+Quick cutthroat gameplay; the decisions on where to land, and what to start producing are the beginnign of a race to quickly provide goods that meet the demands of a local colony.+The gameplay is unique: there isn't any 'militay' component to this game; instead you will be competing with other corporations in the marketplace to become the most efficient and profitable offworld-trading company.+Interesting hostile actions - while you can play it straight and just compete on the 'free market', there are a variety of options to sabatoge your competitors through illicit means.+Unique factions  - each faction has their own set of strengths, and weaknesses; playing one versus another feels very interesting and different.+Great writing (in the tutorial and opening missions, at any rate).Negatives:-It seems like there's not really a comeback mechanic once you start to fall behind; if you make a few mistakes early, you're probably going to have a bad time. I could be wrong, but once I start to lose, I continue to lose.-The factions aren't visually all that different.-This game is probably overpriced for the content that you're getting; I recommend purchasing this game on at least a 25% sale, probably closer to 50%.-I'm unsure about the replayability of the game; so far, the experience has been novel; outside of multiplayer, I don't think the game will provide more than 20 horus of gameplay.Overall, I highly recommend this game for RTS players who want a different experience - namely one that focuses on competitive supply chains and economic efficiency. The game has a lot of character, and has been very enjoyable to explore.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												This is mostly a personal preferences review and it is written after less then 2 hours gametime, then I requested a refund. So this is more of a "what this game isnt"-Review, so others who look for a complex and "big" economic simulation (like I did) save themselves the hassle.For a real economic-simulation the game is way to "small". It will take 15-30 mins at max to reach the maximum possible expansion for your buisness on a map."fighting" the opponents is either done through just throwing acts of sabotage (bought at a black market) at them or by buying them out.If that now sounds intricate and complex, it really isnt you just click a black market mission, then click the target and it happens, buying the other buisnesses out just means making money faster then they do and buy their stocks before they can buy yours.I didnt play it long and had it refunded pretty quickly, especially after seeing that really trying to muscle the opponent out of a market isnt really working, because there is basically no need to close down factories as soon as you produce enough energy, fuel and necessities of life so you dont need to buy them to keep your company running (and that is EASY).So basically if you like a rather uncomplicated build-up-stuff game that is about just building and clicking faster then your opponents, well it might be a game for you. If you are (like me) looking for a real economic simulation, well not so much.Sidenote: Something that had me kinda baffled was that the game greeted me with a box that told me it was an early access version, despite the fact that the steam-shop site doesnt mention anything about it (no usual big green box, saying "early access")

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Overall, somewhat suprised and pleased with the game. I'm still not terribly happy with the price point (I think for EA something around $20 would be more fair with a possible $30-$35 point when the game is finished) but I don't think I wasted my money.Some of my negative comments first:- The UI can be a bit clunky and laggy at points.- If you leave a campaign game in the middle you seem to automatically lose that round (no way to save it and return later unless I'm being oblivious).- If you start losing rounds in the campaign it becomes extremely difficult to make up the lost ground.- No clear indication of when a campaign is over/ability to have multiple campaigns going at once.My biggest takeaway - no problems with the gameplay. The rounds definetly go by quicker then I thought they would as do the campaigns. I do wish there was an option in the campaign to vary the number of starting opponents (simply because once they are all eliminated you win and they can get eliminated fairly quickly) but thats fairly minor. The AI is extremely robust and even the start of the game takes some thought (eg do you drop your base quickly and move to what nodes you can see, do you spend longer scanning hoping to hit the motherload, etc). It does feel like it's really all just a race to the offworld markets (they are so lucrative that whoever gets their first is more or less going to win the game) but the gameplay itself is great. The game takes some forethought as you are limited in what you can do via a limited number of claims (it would be nice if you yourself could give up or auction off a claim). Graphics overall are simple (but clean) and make it extremely easy to see what is going on in-game.All in all I still do have a bit of an issue recommending it at this price point but if you think you'd happen to like the genre and aren't tight with cash I would pick the game up. Hopefully this turns into a good example of Early Access but even if we never heard another word from the Devs the game is completely playable now.Edit: After playing some more I do have to say there are some annoying balance issues (some of the "races" are clearlier to play/win with then others and some of the abilities/techs are way to strong while others are almost useless) but hopefully those will be addressed going forward.

number of helpful: 14 of 21 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been following this game since before it was on Steam. Such a great concept! And it does not disappoint.The Good* Simple game mechanic that grows to a complex interconnected system* Easy to learn, requiring almost no tutorial, but difficult to master* Fun and addictive gameplay* A lot of the usual grind has been automated, leaving the player almost entirely grind-free to focus on base management (yay). The sole exception is the Saboteur system, which you can find in "The Bad" section below.* Challenging AI* Very satisfying victories without long drawn-out endgames* Decent graphics (if a bit blocky)* I am playing this in early-access, and yet the game seems full-featured and stable.* Interesting and current topic (mars colonization)* Well thought-out in terms of resources, resource usage, and gameplay mechanics* Offword mining and its actually about (mostly) peaceful commerce? What an original idea!The bad* The core game mechanic involves getting resources first, and then combining/upgrading to extract them faster. Other than avoiding pirate raids, no thought is given to logistics. I would have liked some road or train building, or having to run power lines or pipelines, rather than everything being delivered via hover selds* The sabotage system is annoying and feels "taped on". Its mostly ineffective, and yet pulls the player away from base management. Especially towards the end of the campaign, this can get kind of grindy... with players always having to repair or re-up their goon-squad, and keep track of attacks all over the place* The first colony almost always wins - I suppose that's incentive to drop early, but with a pausable interface, all the level3 resources near the colony are gone by the time the second corporation touches down* The game seems weighted towards Expansionist and Saboteur factions, with little real benefit for the robots or scientists* Synth voices for the characters are annoyingNot sure if these are good or bad...* I feel like there should be more of a sandbox mode, perhaps with some far-future constructions like terraformers?* Game is also quite short. It seems like a perfect length for what this game is. However, its a lot of fun, and I kinda hope it gets more features, which (I think) would need a longer campaign* Its cliche, but I expected at some point to find alien ruins / fossils / alien tech, but didn't. This could go either way. It adds a bit of mystery and alien-ness, and deepens a story.. but it is very typical and overdone too.ConclusionLoved it. I love strategy and simulation games, so this might get a touch of extra appreciation from me that might not be shared by all. Even so, I'd give Offword Trading Company a 9.5 / 10.Thanks for reading!

number of helpful: 14 of 21 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a promising unique type of Real-Time Strategy (RTS) game.  Even on its normal speed, that you could adjust even in multiplayer, things are fast paced enough to finish a match in 30mins but plenty of time to think about your actions.  You begin by scanning the map for a good starting location.  Each player does the same, but here's the catch, if you are one of the last to found you get bonus tiles (called claims) to build buildings on because you are pretty much forced away from the prime locations that the first founders took, unless your lucky and they didnt spot something.  After you found, this is the fastest part of the game, because you want to claim certain tiles first.  Now each game is going to have a different strategy.  Perhaps you want to claim that lone carbon resource so no one else can get it and force them to buy off the market.  Maybe you think that the other players are going to sell water down so the price to purchase it would be $1, so forgo water and go for more prime minerals or power sources.As the game progresses, you can buy items off the black market or on auctions.  Some help yourself but most of the time you are buying them to stop production of your enemies or to steal one of their resources for a short time.  Each time a player buys, say a dynamite stick, the price goes up for all players the next time you want one.  There is a lot of choices in a fast matched game to choose.End game is always the same, trying to constantly protect your Offworld Markets with shields (Goon Squads), trying your best to disrupt the enemies Offworld Markets.  It usually ends with the first one to amass a huge amount of cash to buyout the remaining shares of your competitor.  It really is no different than a military RTS how to end a game, always ends the same way with hordes of marines going time and time again.  However looking at stock prices for the end game and scanning over to your enemy base to disrupt stuff is about all there is in the end game, nothing fancy like seeing buildings get destroyed by your units.All and all, it is a great game to try out.  They havn't really stated what will be coming in the future except for leagues and ladders like any good RTS game would do.  If they do that, they need to limit the observer mode to a delay or something, and I can see free for all getting out of whack with teams trying to join in and gang up on a player.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Should you Buy Offworld Trading Company?  A 4X Economy Review 

			Views: 1,048		

			From Soren Johnson comes Offworld Trading Company, a unique mix of an economy simulator with the 4X style. The game is in early access however the promise was made that it was in fact a complete...		

Upon loading up the game I was surprised to find that despite the early access tag, it's actually a full game with polish.The game is sort of similar to Civ in that it is a 4x, but that's where the comparisons will end. It's closer to an economic simulator. You build infrastructure that produces resources. Resources can be used to produce new infrastructure. Infrastructure can take resources and created finished products out of them. And with all that you can sell them out to a dynamic market in which the price will fluxuate based on how much each player is selling of that commodity.The main part of the game is surviving as a company and buying out other ones. If your company value falls low you become vulnerable to losing shares of your company to competitors. Your company value is your debt and your infrastructure value combined. So paying off debt will make it harder for people to buying you, while having a large sum will allow you to buy an opponent.Once you have bought an opponent you gain their stuff in full and gain a significant advantage.The game comes with a tutorial for playing the game and playing each of the four factions. Each faction comes with its own unique set of opening boosts and needs. With a few dozen maps to choose from there is tonnes of gameplay value for your dollar.Fans of games like Port Royale, Rise of Venice, Anno 2070, and C.E.O. should definitely give this game a try. For people who are newer to economic simulators and want to give it a try, this might be the game for you.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Offworld Trading Company is a frustratingly fun game! I have only played vs. the AI and it feels rewarding and fair when you outplay it or when it outright buys you out. Furthermore, I found it interesting that setting up the difficulty level (whether for the AI or you) means that you are setting up a handycap. The AI with the same handycap as the player still beats the player if s/he does not play "correctly." This means that you should pay attention to what your HQ needs and what other HQ use as resources. You should use your AI games to figure out which strategy you like (or as in my case keep you alive) best. The random resource allocation and the map designs increase the complexities of this game. Say you want to grab the water, fuel, and food markets. If the map only has 3 water tiles and they are located in a very narrow ridge between craters, you may have a problem. Why? Well, if you are rushing stocking early fuel expecting the prices to go up (because everyone will have to grab resources in weird locations and far from their HQs), you may not want to spend fuel to get fuel transported to your HQ. Furthermore, if you place the HQ near the water tile, you may not have the space to properly place the fuel refineries. You see, how you place buildings affect what bonuses you get from the production of the resource!As you can see, the game is complex enough that I don't dare venture into the multiplayer ladder without having a clue of what I should do under different conditions to maximize my early game profits (also, I have an unreliable connection sometimes). The mechanics feel solid and balanced. You usually lose because you of some badly managed resource or market or because you failed to ship resources offworld before the competition.Overall, I love the game! The animation quality is great! I like the voice over and sounds, although the early access text-to-speech (placeholder?) voice over assets had their own personality. Heck, even the menu surprised me. This is the first game I have seen that differentiates and supports three types of color-blindness.Please, do not ignore this game and grab it as soon as it becomes affordable to you. Then, play it and join the ranked ladder so we can buy each other's companies some day!To the pirates I say, "Pirates, I hate those filthy bandits!" :P

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												What a great game! It's definitely unconventional as RTSes go, but what's wrong with that? We're all looking for something new and exciting to try, right? If you are reading this you probably know basically how this game works, so I'll spare you that.The game is challenging. And to do well even against the non-cheating AI you have to think and react fast. After a while you get to understand the "personality" of the AI and you can get to a point of being able to beat the Manger AI (standard) regularly. At 45 hours I'm not there yet. Once you can do that you can bump up the AI so that it cheats (or maybe you're just handicaped...or both...I actually don't know yet). Better yet, hop into multiplayer and play against people who really know what they're doing. There is ranked 1v1, ranked 4-player free-for-all, and custom games up to 8 players, in free-for-all, teams, and comp stomp.I've watched some live multiplayer on the MohawkGames twitch channel where they are essentially game casting as they play. Soren (the creator) is pretty good at this, but Zultar is amazing! I have learned from watching them, but the biggest lesson is that there is a huge skill curve to this game. I cannot say whether that skill curve is steep, shallow, or moderate, but there is so much depth to this game that even though I understand all the mechanics I'm not even close to understanding more than 10% of why the top players do what they do. The game has observer and replays, and is pretty well balanced it seems. I've watched some youtube videos of the OTC Tournaments during beta and release, and I personally think this game could make it into the competitive scene, if other top players pick up on this gem.Now if your major draw to games is graphics, you'll want to pass for now. The graphics don't suck but this game isn't about eye candy. All the factions use the same buildings and "ships", except their starting base. They have some good animations and there is some life to the maps, which is pretty nifty given this is taking place on Mars (cloud shadows, flares, dust storms). I don't spend much time looking at the art...I enjoy the gameplay.If your major draw to games is character and story, you'll want to pass for now. The tutorial brings a little bit of life and humor to characters that you'll encounter in the campaign. Incidentally the campaign is designed to be played after you've played through the tutorials and have some experience with skirmishes, not before. The campaign is largely a string of skirmishes where you take the role of one of the characters and try to be the best corporation over the course of seven rounds. "Only seven" you ask? The campaign is designed to be more of a single-player mini tournament that is replayable. You play one of the four factions through the rounds, starting with diminished capability but building up toward the final round. Each round you have the chance to gain some new abilities and after each round you "tech up". The maps available to play during each round are selected randomly, so each play-through is different. There is also some progression between runs of the campaign where you get to unlock other campaign characters to play. A neat system, but again not for one who relies upon story.If your major draw to games is replayability, both singleplayer and multiplayer, this is your game. Skirmish, the campaign, and I think multiplayer have a really neat system to enhance replayability. While there are some preset maps that have standard terrain, I think most games are played on procedurally generated maps, made fair by allowing players to plop down wherever they want. Not only is the map terrain procedurally generated, the resource locations are too. In the game there are some random events, like dust storms and solar flares, plus a colony that affects the economy through granting random bonuses and creating random (though predictable and exploitable) demand. In short, no two games will ever be the same. UNLESS...you input a random seed, which will produce the exact same map if you happen to want to. That's a great idea, which I can see it being used in tournaments.Lastly there is the "Daily Challenge". This appears to be a skirmish seed that everyone can play to compete for top spot on the day's leaderboard. So far it seems the top spot is whoever can win the game the fastest. And right there next to their time is an icon which you can click to watch the replay! A great way to see how the top players play.Does this game have what it takes to catch the RTS world's eye? I think so. I hope so. It's the most fun RTS I've played in years. I can envision a future of DLC with more factions, resources, buildings, and gameplay mechanics that will make this game's replayability and multiplayer even richer. But first, you have to buy and play this game. What are you waiting for?Pro tip: Don't be afraid to bulldoze buildings and put down more profitable ones. The good players are refocusing constantly based upon the market.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												Ahh, yes. Capitalism. An economic system that produces lots of waste, harms the environment, and promotes terrifying business tactics. Transplant it onto a newly colonized Mars and give it very few laws and restrictions, and watch as the companies destroy each other and buy each other out!In all seriousness though, this game is great. Like, really great. I would go as far to say that it's the best game I've played this year! This game has so many great features, it's gonna be hard covering them all. First, the amount of diversity each company has. They all have their own special abilities, which can make the gameplay very different, depending on who you pick. Second, picking & choosing which product you want to produce and make a profit off of. For me, I always have to switch to another product halfway through the game, because I end up making the price of it too low! Third, the market. Watching the market prices go up and down, all while manipulating them is very fun to do. Fourth, the special buildings can really change the tide of the game. I have won many times due to using them, they really do save you now and then!Finally, the difficulty. I mean, this game is brutal. The AI can get very, very aggressive. I can barely win a skirmish on the fourth lowest setting! (Honorable mentions: the soundtrack, art style, and sound effects.)My only complaint that it does get a little repetitive, but honestly, it doesn't matter if you just put it away for a bit, and come back to it later.If you're looking for a great strategy game that is brutal and shows no mercy, this is a game for you!

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'll put this out there to start: I picked this game up on sale for $20, which after having played it feels about right. This is a recommendation based on the $20 pricetag, I do not feel it's worth $40 quite yet.Pros:+Interesting concept that is (mostly) executed well.+Four different faction types that are relatively balanced.+Good level of mechanical depth that makes the game more enjoyable as you learn.+Multiplayer is fun, particularly co-op+Winning is satisfying - there's no other way to put it. When you buyout your last competitor, you feel like you've earned your monopoly.Cons:-Tutorials are bare bones at best, useless at worst. On top of not covering very basic but vital mechanics (using claims without building, the usefulness of upgrade buildings such as the offworld market/patent office, etc) the last three tutorials simply throw you into a standard game and tell you to win with a given faction, with barely a blurb about that faction's unique traits as a guide. You will need to suffer through a lot of trial and error before you feel skilled at the game.-The market essentially functions the same way every game. Certain goods (electronics, chemicals, food) are basically always the most expensive on the market, so a strategy of "spam electronics late game" is always viable, and ruins the charm somewhat.-The Black Market, as it is currently implemented, is a big drain on the game. It refreshes too fast, and you are constantly being bombarded in all directions by pirates, EMP's, and dynamite. Honestly, for a game that claims to remove the military elements of the RTS to focus on economics, it detracts from your economic game and forces you to focus on what is essentially guerilla military ops.-The difficulty settings are such that you can only functionally choose to apply bonuses/handicaps to yourself. The AI always plays at the same (fairly high) level, which makes it difficult to keep up as a newbie.Overall the game is still very rough around the edges, but what's there can be fun, particularly with some friends to co-op with. However in it's current state it absolutely feels $20 too expensive at it's standard price of $40. If you can get it on sale, it's worth a look.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Love the game and has potential. I do have a few comments and suggestions tho.I'm a fan of the campaign mode and wish it could extend Much longer. There should be an option for more maps than around the 6-8 currently. That aside there is a steeper learning curve than people realise and certain information isn't readily available for those who just jump into playing.The tutorial doen't explain certain mechanics, like the fledgling colony you're there to support. When it fails (loses all population) some people fail to realize this and think they've been bought out with no notification. This is not the case as they are your local consumers. The larger the independent colony is the more resources they suck off of the market.Having a resource monopoly can be your best friend. Just know when to hold, and when to flood the market. The ability to precisely time buy/sell actions is paramount.The least powerful faction so far in my opinion is the scientific. Especially in the campaign mode, as they have no indipendent water production to start with. Geothermal in campaign is near useless so are the ice and dry ice condensors. Half of the time you don't have 2 of the 3 mentioned if not none at all. My suggestion to improve scientific is give their buildings slant drilling (except mines and quarries and water pumps) by default instead of the reduced sabatoge innate perk.Another thing that should change would be if your debt is higher than some % of  your asset value, any cash made should automatically go to pay off debt, including the automatic selling of stocks that you may have. I know there is an option to have all cash towards debt; however, at a certain point I think lenders would hire collections on your goods. This would allow some negative operational budgets but prevent abuse. As is your stock could be worthless, however maintaing stock in other companies gives a high value well beyond what should be viable.I was attempting to see how high of a population i could get the independent colony to grow and I managed to get an AI opponent into -10,000,000 in debt with an asset value around 1.5 million.  What was interesting is that he still held high cash reserves , and decent stock value because of an earlier purchase of some of my stock. I got it to almost 70 population when my game crashed due to me spamming up around 30+ offworld trades.For the love of God give us a save/load option in Campaign! Also please fix the game lag from opening up any specialized building menus (engineering upgrade, hack net, etc).One final thing I'd love added is a "Sell at 'X' value" option similar to the auto sale of electricity but have an option to start/stop selling at a certain value. This would further increase the potential of market manipulations, beyond just start/stop of the power only. An example of this feature would be  locking it to automatically sell water once the price has increased to $30 a unit, and have it auto selling to keep it at that value and no higher.Offworld trading is very OP, it's pretty much game over when someone builds one. I have managed to survive once by spamming mutiny on an opponents and using the funds to buy them out.  This may lead to a game bug, where a person can have more than 2 markets if one of their two is under mutiny and placing another. I can not remember if the opponent had more than one base, as this is a viable option as to how they ended up with 3.All in all a pretty good foundation with just some fleshing out to do with tutorial/help hints, balancing and optimizations. I think an open mod community could really make this a longstanding foundational game. Turn the campaing into a galaxy of planets to work your way through coquering a planetary network would be amazing. Just using similar bonus system for conqured planets. IE: Upon starting a new planet the first map only carries over your Planet wide bonuses from previous planets. This would allow alternate upgrade/tech advancement strategies for different planets.Well that's enough for now, I'm going back to play some more.
