								If you want to play an RTS that makes you think and keeps you on the edge of your seat as three other players all have one buyout left before you've been bought out, you're waiting for your offworld trading rocket to finally launch and get you that 61k that you're dying for. *Boooom Zzzzttttt* all of a sudden you've been smashed by an EMP blast at the heavy cost of 250k, the black market has been abused and bled. seeing your money hanging around half of what you need to buyout your main competitor, seeing an open opportunity, you cast mutiny (pre-purchased and dying to be used) on their geothermal plant, EMP blast on their headquarters, just a little off the side on an empty tile (to ensure a goon squad hasn't been used)... But you will see for 16 years they have produced some amazing games and if you haven't checked out Galactic Civilizations III you need to! They have a good reputation, sure, sure... content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												If you love M.U.L.E. buy this game. If you don't know what M.U.L.E. is play it free on planetmule or alternatively buy this game. If you hate M.U.L.E. I respect your bizarre life choices, but do examine this game to see if your complaints were addressed.   Offworld trading company is in my opinion the best non-combat RTS on the market. It's not M.U.L.E. but it takes that core concept and give it's a fresh modern spin. It is a well balanced blend of risk vs reward which is simple to learn but challenging to master. A lot of attention and love has been poured into the game and it shows.  Considerations:  * Game is fast paced.  It's a not a case who ever issues orders the fastest wins like most RTS but the game is about balancing you income and the market environment which influences that income is in constant flux and you must be constantly on your game to adjust your strategy and make choices as the climate shifts if you wish to stay on top of your competitors. It eases you into it buy things get more frantic as things go on as you are juggling more and more avenues open up for players to sabotage each other. Point being there isn't time to relax in a match like their would be in a turn based strategy. Most people think a quick game is a good but this is a preference you have to weigh up for yourself.  * The extra campaign features are just for single player. It is a constant gripe of mine that competitive games that offer mechanics for campaign map don't accommodate multiplayer. Sometimes you want spend to an afternoon with a couple of friends competing for a long game of back and forth struggle. As usual that's not an option. The campaign mode offer a fun and in depth expansion to gameplay experience by incentivising you to continue playing successive matches and thus is makes a good introductory experience to the game and augments your single player experience so it's more then just death match skirmishes with AI bots. Just a shame death match skirmishes is the only experience you can share with your friends.  * Competitive play will take practice. The downside of simple to learn difficult to master means that without putting the time in you simply will not be able to compete with experienced players. The AI is very well developed at this point as a training tool but you are still going to take a beating before you can compete with regular players.  * Replayability. The game has a solid core mechanic with a good deal of depth but that's the extent of it. The different factions all follow the same core rules they just each get to break specific rules, meaning learning to play one means you can play them all, you just have different ways to apply their advantages to different strategies. There isn't a lengthy/branching tech tree and if you've played one 30 minute match you've seen all the game has to offer. It's not that it lacks content (it's packed with it) it's just that the content is focused on a specific experience. It's fair to equate it to a game of speed chess. How many matches can you play before you get bored? For some people it depends on the opponents, others just love and can't get enough of the game while other just enjoy a single match every now and then. When you buy the game you a buying a quality board to play with. It's up to you to assess how much playtime you'll get out of the board.  If these considerations do not concern you then I can heartily recommend this title. It is solidly built, well polished and has benefited from rigorous balance testing. Also it's fun, which is what matters most. If you are unsure if it's a fit for you or not remember you can always buy the game, play a few matches to see what it's like and then refund it. 2 hours playtime is plenty of time to get a feel for the core mechanics. For many of us it's exactly the revival of this niche genre we have been waiting for.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Offword Trading Company is a fun, challenging, economic trading sim. It's the only early access game I've played that I would actually recommend buying in its current state. It already feels like a complete game, and a fun one at that. To start a match, you and your competitors search mars for a place to start your business ventures. The map is randomly comprised of different resources, used to either support your colony, or turn a profit. There are a couple of different colonies, all of which use the available resources differently, providing a slight variety on play-styles.The matches last around 30 minutes or so, which I think is a nice change from the time-investment of the Civ games.There is also a blackmarket, where you can purchase goods to sabotage your competitors, or even manipulate the market in your favor. Be aware: the AI are very well programmed -- don't expect any mercy!"Is it worth the price?" Yes! Stop asking and start playing.

												I simply cannot recommend this game. I was in the mood for some trading and had been eyeing this game since prior to launch.But now that I bought it, I deeply regret it. This game is incredibly simple. It's dumbed down and gets repetitive easily. There is no real market, you buy and sell to the game with some simulated market prices, and that's what your competition does too. If a colony says it requires food, you won't be selling food to them, the game will simulate it and make the price go up a bit. But you just won't trade with anyone specifically. There is only a "sell" button for each good and that's it.You can hack Mars information systems (somehow) to simulate a shortage and make the price of your goods go up, but in late game each time, all the goods prices will be going up and becoming hella expensive. Right, real market right there. You can also make prices go down but that doesn't have much impact late game against AIs.The game is just too simple. I am greatly disappointed and sad and missing my money.I haven't tried multiplayer and won't review it.

								If Starcraft and Settlers of Catan had a baby (visited by the mailman Capitalism 2), you'd have Offworld Trading Company.Early Access, schmearly shmaccess, this game is good enough now. Art assets are a bit wonky (placeholder computer voices in lieu of actual actors, some weird asset error messages while playing), but whatever.It plays like a... Real Time Board Game. You get the clicky clicky fast decisions of an RTS, but the complex game mechanics / card shuffling of something like Settlers of Catan (or a similar German-style board game where there are multiple ways to win).My only complaint after a few hours is some interface tweaks (such as highlighting existing buildings of the same type you're building so you can more quickly snag the adjacency bonus) and maybe more visible notifications for the "cards" played (stocks being bought, EMPs being detonated, etc.)Basically though, if you like RTS games, and you also like economic games, totally get this. I suck at Starcraft - I can't click fast enough to matter, and I freakin' grew up on a computer. But I'm also not a dummy. This game was designed for me.See you on Mars, suckas. content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
Product received for free
Offworld Trading Company is a space strategy game with many great attributes and with constant support from the developers.If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.What is happening in the game:You are in control of a colony, based on Mars, and you have to get as rich as possible. You can build mines, factories and farms and then sell them when the price is right. Defend yourself from other companies and try to take them over.Pros: Trading Aspect | There are a lot of similar strategy games, but this game has something other games rarely have: trading. It adds something new to the game and it makes it different from other games of the similar genre, which is definitely a huge advantage. Trading has a lot of different options since you can have different strategies for higher profits and you can even influence the prices, just as you can in real life (if you're wealthy enough). Appearance | This game looks great and it doesn't use a lot of system resources, which is great. Even if there are a lot of things happening on your screen, it is still very easy to track everything. This is sometimes a problem, especially when you get so wealthy that you can afford anything, but your screen gets littered as well. Anyway, this game doesn't have this problem. Tutorials | This game offers an amazing tutorial which covers all the basics well and prepares you for your journey. There are five tutorial levels and each one covers a few connected topics. When you complete the tutorials, you're mostly good to go as the game itself is not extremely complicated, but I will also mention this later on.  Learning Curve | You don't need any prior experience with similar games as this game teaches you game mechanics very gently with some funny dialogs, easy-to-understand instructions and helpful explanations. I've never seen something like that and it's really something every game should have. I sometimes feel frustrated when I don't understand what the game wants from me, but no such thing happened with Offworld Trading Company. Game Modes | Game modes are definitely another great thing about this game as there are many of them, which means more hours of interesting gameplay. After completing the tutorial, you can play some prepared practice games. Then, you can play the Campaign, Skirmish, Daily Challenge levels and even multiplayer ones! Atmosphere | The music in this game is really great and game events also have some influence on what kind of music is played. The sound effects are also pretty great (such as explosions and other things). This is one of rare such games where you don't need to turn on your own music if you don't want to get bored! Achievements and Rewarding | When you do something good in this game, it really lets you know that you did something good and that you learned something. There are quite a few achievements, some harder than others, and they are one of the rewards for making progress. This really makes the player to play the game more since it's like getting a cookie each time you do something of value. This developer really knows how to keep its players! Almanac DLC | These kind of things are usually available as paid DLCs, but this DLC comes with the game for free when you purchase it. You get access to many things, such as a 91-page (!!) strategy guide by professional players and designer notes from the developer.Cons: Pricing | 40€ for a game is really too much, even though it's a very good game. Games of the same genre are usually priced at least 10€ lower. If you manage to find someone who wants the game as well, you can buy the Deluxe Edition which gives you an extra copy of this game. Otherwise, I just don't find this game to be worth so much. Hopefully, the developer will drop the price at some point or at least put a nice discount on it on every major sale. No SteamOS Support | Linux lovers are sadly excluded from this game's player base as well.  I wonder when developers are going to realize that there are some hardcore Linux fans that only buy games when they support their operating system ...The final verdict:Offworld Trading Company is most certainly an amazing game. Apart from its trading mechanics, there are also great graphics, many game mode, a very helpful tutorial and many other great things. Overall, there is nothing particularly bad about this game apart from its pricing. I still think that 40€ is way too much for such a game. When you do buy it, you should have no problems liking it, but I do recommend waiting for a sale before deciding to buy this game. Hopefully, there will also be a price drop in near future.With love,BirdCuteNote that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a great game, lots of fun. The first round will be very overwhelming, however the learning curve is easy. It is still in beta, I hope they add a minimap and some hot key functions. navigating is a little odd. An issue I find with all steam games is the hot corners on mac, if you have it enabled, mess up the game. The task bar pops up over the game interface as well as the header bar. It can be irritating when scrolling to the edges is the only way to navigate.It's super fun, but fast paced. You'll be done with each round in 30-45 mins each.  It does leave you wanting something more enduring sometimes. I want to play longer, do more, expand. I don't want to own Mars in an hour or less every time.Again I know it's a beta but the game seems unbalanced, for example my second time through I had bought out all my competitors but one and owned all the resources. I had lots of money and resources, but I was just sitting and messing around. Unfortunately the AI generated enough over a long period of time and bought me out. I lost even tho I owned 90% of the map. Seemed odd.Overall, lots of fun, not time consuming. Leaves you wanting more strategy space RTS tho. Great beta! I hope to see some more features in the full release. 100% worth it.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												This game would’ve been great if gameplay and economy had a greater impact on one another. In the beginning it feels as if you’ve got some control of the market but after a while you realize that the market is basically just random for each skirmish and after that AI and players can temporarily manipulate prices with abilities rather than planning ahead and being smart about investments. I am not saying that the abilities such as sabotage should not be in the game but when you realize that that’s basically what the game revolves around it gets boring very fast. It doesn’t really matter what you invest in as long as you are fast enough to screw up your opponents with abilities first, buy their stocks and GG. Anybody looking for an interesting story/campaign should give up on this game right away. There basically is no campaign. It’s just a bunch of skirmish matches against AI with some limitations on each mission. It’s a great looking game with a nice concept but it failed to deliver.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												This game is exactly what it is sold to you as, which is to say an awesome quick economic rts. You get to play Martian capitalism with all the usual questionable and sometimes dirty tricks of the trade, and it's HUGELY satisfying. Here is what stands out to me about this game in particular that I think makes it worth buying:- fast games (around 20 minutes)- beautiful visuals and a spot on UI- wonderful soundtrack- well put together live market system- four distinctly flavored factions- slightly lengthy but really useful tutorialsThis is the first time I have seen an economic 'game' actually achieve the 'game' part. There are many economic sims out there; Offworld is not one of them, it is instead an actual game, a fun experience, which uses a simulated live market and other things to make you feel like a true capitalist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in space.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am reviewing this game far earlier than I usually do.  Generally I try to get 10 or 12 hours in on a game so that, even if I haven't finished it yet, I have a solid feel for all the merits and flaws of a game.  However, I am having so much fun with this one that I decided to review it already.Now, the game has flaws.  It does have a tendency to lag out a bit, especially when engaged in the daily challenges.  The graphics are pleasant, but nothing particularly special... of which I approve, since my graphics setup is more for work than gaming, so I have trouble with graphically intensive games.  And you can further turn the graphics down to save on your computer's resources, which is nice, also.There is a minimum of combat (although you can do several different kinds of sabotage, including detonate an opponent's property), since the game is primarily market based warfare, and you win by buying out the competition.  Managing to balance your debt, so that your stock price stays up, while still generating the liquid assets to buy out an opponent makes for some interesting and fun strategizing.There are points where this game lacks, but it's still in Early Access, so that's no big surprise.  Because of this, further reviews will be coming as the game develops.Initial Scoring: 8 out of 10

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												So, I have been wanting to give OTC a thumbs-up since I got it; I think it is really one of the great games of the last few years. Such a unique concept, well-executed, simple to learn, hard to master. If you want thoughtful strategy with competitive multiplayer, and don't care for a long-form story campaign, try this! The AI is also pretty good; quite challenging. There is a short randomized single-player campaign mode to provide variety over plain skirmishes.Anyway, I held off on reviewing this for a long while because after 85 hours clocked I still don't know if I *really* get it. To elaborate...The game takes place around a fictional colony on Mars (placed in the center of each map). Multiple companies set up shop around it and compete for the market driven by the demands of this colony. You are granted a very limited number of land plots to choose and build factories on. Then you have to be ready to strategically replace buildings lest they become unprofitable. Everything you do consumes resources, influencing market prices. You and your competitors may also play the market by buying up and selling down large quantities of goods. Entire matches can be won/lost on market gambles. Lastly, there is a black market of sabotage actions to give an extra edge over the competition. These must be utilized ruthlessly against a skilled opponent (who will be using them ruthlessly).Conflict in this game is highly indirect, through the market. This means that when you are losing (or winning) it can be hard to tell why! Do not be fooled by the immediacy of black market actions; they are powerful, but the main force behind a win is always economic. There is an interactive replay function that allows every match to be reviewed from any player's point of view. Make good use of it!It seems that for the above reason, some reviewers are put off by a game that appears simplistic to some (too easy) and impossibly unfair to others (too hard). It is important to know how the difficulty setting works in this game: Difficulty levels are given fanciful names from "Applicant" and "Intern" to "CEO" and "Guru". These do not change how the AI plays (it always works to its best ability), but give some starting bonuses or handicaps to the player. There is a setting in the middle called "Manager (AI)" which gives the standard amounts (that the AI always gets) and is actually quite hard for a beginner. There is a set of practice scenarios that ramp up in difficulty and you can see in the achievement stats how many have beaten the last one which plays on "Manager" - scroll down to "Managing Expectations":http://steamcommunity.com/stats/271240/achievements/So, have fun, and don't jack up the food price too much!

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Okay, so I'm going to put the important bit first. If you're a fan of the RTS genre, but you dislike the intensity of the micro required to perform in the genre at a high level competitively, this is the game for you. Don't even read the rest of the reviews; just buy it and prepare for a fantastic experience. Offworld Trading Company is a deep game. A very deep game. What you need to succeed is an ability to accurately assess a given situation, and make good decisions based on other players' actions. That's pretty much it. The difficulty comes with how many variables there are: buildings, resources, money, debt, the black market, and other players. These variables interact in many ways, but never through direct conflict. It's pretty clear that the inspiration behind OTC was board gaming, and there are ways in which it feels like a board game at times. But computers are capable of more calculations than humans which, coupled with the fact that so much thought has gone into the intricacies of the economic system, makes building an economic empire both very rewarding and enormously fun.Multiplayer is balanced extremely well. All of the game-breaking exploits have been quashed by this point, and watching streams of the very best players makes it apparent that it's careful consideration of options, and not raw APM, that's rewarded in this game. This fact alone makes it almost unique within the genre, and as a result I can't recommend this game highly enough. There are enough active players in the ranked queues at the time of writing that you'll pretty much always get a game, and that will be improved further when you (yes, you!) buy it and start playing. So off you go.Oh, and the guy who made it is the guy who made Civilization IV, which is the best Civ game to date by a long way. He knows how to make games.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Highest recommendation.  The last games I played more than 50 hours were (not coincidentally) Civ IV and Starcraft 2.  This game is completely different and yet reminds me of Civ IV in some way I can't identify.  Basically, the implication in the game's blurb is dead on:  if you loved Civ IV, you'll probably love this.I believe you will also love this game if you are a more macro-oriented RTS player.There are 3 changes which would further improve it.  These are serious, but their specificity should signal to anyone on the fence about buying it how damn good and deep the game is to begin with :(1) Precise "colony" demand function.  If for instance you pause the game, buy a block of 100 of a resource, then sell them back one at a time, you'll wind up with less money than you started with (was previously more but seems to have been changed).  There's some kind of error with the demand function, likely due to rounding/approximation of price, quantities or both.  It's a bit frustrating to know that you've lost some money if you buy something and change your mind or are on autosell for a good and decide to buy back.(2) AI behavior.  Generally, the AI is too aggressive against the player (or perhaps only to the player most "ahead"), cutting off its nose to spite its face.     (a) Hacks.  An AI player will create a surplus in something you are producing/mining very profitably even when            the AI is also heavily producing/mining this as well.  This may even be their most profitable or most commonly produced good.     (b) Blackmarket.  In the campaign, near the end of the last day, the AI will still spend an exorbitant amount of money to slow down your production, well exceeding their direct benefit from lowering your stock price a small amount.     (c) The AI seems to always know you've attacked them when you do despite anonymity.  Further, if you retaliate to an initial attack of theirs they will re-retailiate, leading to a kind of "arm's race."      In short, each AI should be maximizing their own individual benefit instead of minimizing yours.  These are identical if it is 1v1, but I'm often "ganged up on" to an excessive extent when ahead in a game playing with several AI players.  It is an excessive extent not because I dislike it or feel it is "unfair," but because it is to our mutual detriment.(3) The UI.  I generally play against the AI primarily and very slowly, with pausing, an efficient UI is a lower priority for me.  However, in the few multiplayer games I've played, I've been overwhelmed by the amount of mouse movement/clicking necessary (unlike, say, the macro components of Starcraft or better yet Supreme Commander).     Ideally, I should be able to create one set of hotkeys to select construction, patents, optimizations, hacks, launches, and blackmarket (e.g., numbers 1-6), and then, conditional on one having been selected, hotkeys for each option (e.g., research teleportation = "T", so researching teleportation could be done by pressing "2" then "T").  The fact that such a complicated system of hotkeys is necessary is actually a good thing, as it's due to the vast number of decisions the player can and must make at any time.     Lastly, a mini-map roughly indicating resources and opponent claim ownership (not simply completed structures you can see by tabbing) would make acquiring the information necessary for your decisions far, far more efficient.Let me reiterate that this is one of the best games I've ever played.  If you even suspect you may be the type of person who would enjoy it, invest the $40 or less for what may be hundreds of hours of rewarding gameplay.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												Its a weird game to love. An RTS with units. A heavy economics board game played in real time. That said, this has to be one of the most enjoyably complex/simple games I've ever played. That is to say, the fundamentals of the game -harvest good- and then -sell good- or -convert good into a refined good for which to sell- are super easy, just that the ground moves under you so often you have to question if turning your water into food is worth it, as the price of water increases, whereas the price of food decreases as you sell it.Its a weird game to get someone into. I had the distinct pleasure of climbing up skill levels with fairly evenly matched friends, but its hard to learn when what works right now is almost assuredly going to be a terrible idea next time. All in all, most games end up with me spending the next day or so occasionally going "OH. I totally should have just scrapped my iron production, bought a bunch of it off the market while it was cheap, and instead put down steel plants to convert that material, rather than fight for the flailing iron economy"A++ Would try to make all the space bucks again.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This may be early access, but it's pretty much shippable now. That's saying a lot. It's fun. It doesn't sound like it would be. But this is one of the most addictive games I've played in a long time.It's RTS-like, but there's no direct combat. This is a purely economic game. Take a look at what resources are on the map, collect the rarer ones, sell them. Buy the ones that are more common.You win via hostile takeover (buying your opponent's stock up). When you lose, you get a $3 mil severance paycheck.The economy is awesome. Twelve resources is a lot to keep track of, and all of the prices fluctuate based on availability and how much people are buying/selling. Every game plays differently because of this. Steel tends to be fairly valuable, but the last game I played, it was the cheapest resource the whole game. Another game, the map had only 3 waters on it, and I camped on all of them. Monopoly!Player stock price fluctuates based on your assets, your income, and your debt. When you buy out another player, you get all of their assets. Which means that once someone buys out multiple competitors, the game is basically over, because there's no way to compete. While steamrolling someone usually is an annoying quality in games, it works well here, since once you reach that point, the game ends swiftly.I don't know what they're going to do before they ship the game. It's worth buying now. If it gets even better, this might be the first game I am hooked on since the early 2000s.

number of helpful: 21 of 36 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								While limited in content (only a 406 MB download on windows atm), this is a promising little trading game with a hopefully bright future. You get to choose from 4 different classes of corporation to play from. Standard capitalists, Robots, Scavengers and Scientists. They each have a very different play style that works for them, for example Robots don't require food or water to survive, meaning they can focus right away on resource gathering. You can't just throw down a load of buildings to gather what you need right away, you have to 'claim' ground and resources to gather them, and you can bid against other corporations or upgrade your head-quarters to get more 'claims'. To win a game you have to buyout your opponents corporation, this gets harder as the game goes on, and the surviving corporations get bigger and more effective, but a single campaign could last maybe a couple of hours.  rapid expansion, careful selling and buying of goods, and sometimes abit of espionage can soon become formulaic. For example I've only spent about 4 hours, and I've manage to figure out how to win every time with the Robot faction (haven't won much with the other 3 yet)IF the dev's add more to the game then I could see a lot of re-playability in this game, but at the moment its limited, and you may wish to wait while the price tag drops a bit, I kinda regret getting this at £26 (that was with a 10% discount). Wait a few months, see what the price is like, see how much its changed, and I'll come back and do a second review of the updated version.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												[Intro] Had a bit of difficulty deciding between yay or nay, gave it a bit of consideration. The idea is interesting and not explored enough, so I felt very tempted to recommend solely on the premise of having a more diverse RTS scene. The decision rested on how they delivered on what they tried to achieve and promised. [Justification] It's not an interesting RTS (though i might be proven wrong if in a couple of years we see this game played competively, which I doubt). The way it is now, you'll have a difficult time playing on the higher levels until you find exploits that break the game. You won't become good at gaming an interesting rulset against an interesting opponent, you'll try to become good at beating the way the game was designed. Is not well balanced out and doesn't have an interesting AI, though people who might like '90s "challenging" (punishing) AI might want to give this a go for all times sake. The difficulty levels are simple starting penalties, which shows how little good gameplay is "rewarded" the player who makes the least mistakes wins, it should be more than that and I can't see it. There are 4 factions you can play as, they're not symetrical, but not well balanced out for asymetrical gameplay either (and they're not all that different). The robotic faction seems to be the obvious choice at the moment, the rest that are introduced later to the player will make your own playthrough more and more difficult, not different. Why would one not choose the faction that offers the easiest win when playing a skirmish match? Disclaimer: I caped at medium difficulty. I don't feel motivated to continue learning the game to beat the game. The economics. Aah, this should have been what made the game. Does the game make some interesting commentary about economics in RL, in video games or gives us an interesting mechanic through which the player might learn something useful about how economy works? No, none of these. The game uses very basic supply/demand system to set dynamic prices, which is cool as an idea. But there's no background simulation of why these resources are really needed, the demand is neither believable and allows for fluctuations which are actually based on supply alone and RNG demand. Boooooring. This is one of the objective reasons why one may argue that the game has no depth. [Others] Many talked about the price. I agree, it's too expensive for what it has to offer. I played the game and don't plan on purchasing content for the game. However, I wanted to avoid this and focus on how well the game delivers what it set out to accomplish. I'm also annoyed with the low res textures, gimmickey animation, almost like in a facebook game (though many liked the style for some reason). The campaign doesn't offer any compelling backstory, it just allows you to experience what the game has to offer a little bit more gradually. [TL;DR] The game has an interesting idea, but it's not very well delivered. It's worth trying out, but then you have to consider if it has enough value to offer to you.

Early Access Review
								It's an early access game and by that it means it's no where finished. Hopefully they will make the game good as the price tag feels "little" to high. It should have been between $15 and $20 (max) for what you get (not much). Let me bring up some things I feel about the game:1. It's to few resources in many games which do so it's highly frustrating when you can not build new stations as most are already taken, you can not build more because you need to upgrade your main base and the only thing you do is more or less waiting, waiting and waiting some more. Huh!2. It feels really frustrating very often because in the beginning it's very stressful game as you need to take good spots asap before the quick AI who can instantly do it. In the end game it feels the reverse... boring as the only thing you do is more or less are waiting until you have enough cash even when you have sold most of your resources to be able to buy something new. It's a waiting game in the end.3. It feels also the AI has full control (100% of the time) over your economy. As soon as you get enough money to buy AI out he increases his buyout price. So it feels really frustating and you start to ask yourself if AI is sheating which is not so enjoyable.4. It looked fun when the devs played it but sadly it wasn't. However I think the game can have potential if they make it more fun in all areas. Was bored of it already after some hours, but forced me to play it just to see if I have missed something which can be fun. The campaign could have been much more fun than it was. But it's hard to see what they can improve to make it more fun. It felt like I bought a shell with no fun content. It felt like a work to play the game.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
Early Access Review
Fun as defined by repetitive actionSo why recommend with a title like that? Cause the game can still be fun, if not a constant repeative action at end game.  The methods on how you overly strategize towards the end can vary, mostly in how the map generates, how quickly your enemy deploys/expands and the various methods they use against you and vs versa.  But the end becomes nearly the same; sell resources at high prices before the other player/AI - so you have enough dosh to buyout the other player, because they certainly are about to do it to you! (You see an ever increasing % sign next to their name, telling you of your impending doom).A hair raisingly good timeWhile the game does raise the stakes and cause you to panic, the game is short lived. You may think "Fast paced gameplay that has relatively quick matches Amora? That's good!" but granted, that isn't a good thing... unless you like that sort of thing.  I'm more of a stock that enjoys the time it takes to get somewhere, and admiring my crushing blow towards my opponents or their epic schoolin' they lay down teaching.  I could  list a plethora of games that follow this suit, but you may already get the idea.So, purchase this game if:Enjoy StrategyLove live action cat and mouse; chess stylized market manipulationsFast paced, hair raising gameplayDo so ever love repetitive end game experiencesRemember, Bunny loves you <3

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												Overall, this RTS game is a refreshing take on a familiar concept: Corporate Warfare as Alien Colonization RTS.  I've been playing it now for three days, and overall - I really like this game.  My only issue is that it seems the devs really took a few shortcuts that seem to show, the sort that you might not see in a release from one of the more established publishers. First, typos - you'll see them in the game and referred to in discussions.  Seriously, guys - if you can develop a game you can spell check.  Just lazy IMO.Second, balance - the game does not seem balanced between the difffering factions nor with the AI.  So far it seems to be either very easy to win, or impossible to win.  There are a lot of "moving parts" in this game - i.e. a lot of resources, upgrades, and attack options via the "black market" and hacker array to contend with, and no matter what you do the AI will make all the necessary calculations much faster than a human to determine the best strategy to win.  Devs have said this isn't true in discussion, but with respect they understand the game differently than a new user and they should listen to the criticisms.Third, font/resource icon size - there are many instances when the fonts are honestly nearly too small to read.  Anyone who might need reading glasses (not just middle-aged gamers like me) will find it hard to read numbers, which is pretty important given this is a game of corporate warfare and espionage.  Seriously, make the fonts/resource icons like 10-15% bigger and it's much more playable.Fourth - there seem to be issues with multi-player, but I cannot speak to that specific complaint because I've not yet attempted to get into a MP game, but read the discussions if you want to learn more on MP bugs.That said, I'm confident that future relases and patches will address these issues, and one of the best features in my opinion is the lean and effective use of code.  I was THRILLED to see that it only took up a little over 2G on my MacBook AIR.  I'd strongly consider this title if you're a fan of any of the Civ games, as well as C&C or other RTS titles.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												One of the most complex resource management games I've ever played.What I found charming about the game is how it simulated not just the basics of economics but it had elements of consumers, terrain (including weather effects), sourcing and patents. Players are also able to manipulate some of these factors through the 'black market' basically debuffs or buffs you can buy on a periodic basis.Not counting for daily challenge or multiplayer, there are essentially 2 game modes. Skirmishes are 1 off rounds where all buildings are available and your goal is to buy off the shares of your competitors to win.If you like progression then campaign mode is pretty nice. Instead of buying your oponents, you buy buildings for the settlers on the colony to win which would also help you tamper with supply and demand (Personally I built more houses so I could drive the price of food and oxygen up lulz). it adds a little more depth to the game as you do not own every building and would have to choose which buildings you'd like to acquire or upgrade though the downside is that this mode lasts for only 7 rounds.TL:DRFairly complex with a variety of strategies to win and ♥♥♥♥ over your oponent that doesn't make you rage quit. Realistic resource manager cause it adheres to a lot of basic business and economics principles.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is a lot of fun, there's a learning curve for this type of game until you get the basic hang of it (31 hours of play until my first win). The UI is fine to me, could be refined or polished up later on. The graphics are decent in that they're not childish looking, but colorful and well done without being too detailed and distracting from the real content. Another great added feature is the customization of gameplay options.  Map size, location, resource amounts, black markets and many more options available to pick from.The factions are great and seem well balanced on the surface, until technology and research are conducted with some factions  gaining a very strong edge. Some technology can compliment a faction weakness very well or enhance upon current factional strengths.Gameplay can be quick and brutal, once you've mastered the learning curve you can be just as brutal. After 31 hours of gameplay trying different factions, and tactical approaches I won. OTC will eventually unleash your inner mastermind when you learn which Black Market sabotage to use on the leader of the pack to keep them in check and in debt. Low on power? Go steal some. Combination tech and sabotage can render great net returns with the correct amount of timing.---My only negatives are not knowing what the sound effects mean and the exact location of my affected colony. I feel like Factional structures should have an easily identified signature look rather than a colored border. It seems there's only one way to win and that's... Offworld Trading. Every game feels like a race to Offworld shipment rockets where other rts have multiple methods for obtaining victory.If you're looking for something fun and different with 30 minutes to kill, this game will please. I bought the game even after reading the negative reviews and was able to overlook the smaller details.

content:
Posted: March 19
												A unique game which invovles resource gathering and quick decisions about numbers. I enjoy economic simulators, so this was pretty high on my list of games to get. I don't like how formulaic it can be though. It's similar to RTS games like Starcraft in that there is a certain build at the beginning of the game, as well as midgame and endgame strategies. (which is kind of a turnoff for me). But a round is relatively short, which is a plus in my eyes, because nothing is worse than playing an hour into a game just to lose. I was hoping more along the lines of a space-themed Capitalism II, but it's much more like Starcraft minus the fighting. (Sorry, I haven't played multi-player; this review is strictly for the single-player experience).+ Not many number crunching games, so this was a welcome entry.+ Plays very quickly, if you're spending more than a few seconds looking at the screen without clicking, you're probably going to lose.+ Good replay value.+ Good production value.- AI can be pretty difficult.- Even if you're well positioned, you can lose instantly if you don't pay attention to your stocks.- At the time of writing, the game is still going for about $40 which is a pretty steep price.8/10 Won't appeal to everybody, but a much needed entry in economic gaming~

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												I played through the tutorials, which took me over 2 hours to finish, so I was past the refund time. Game modes unlock as you finish the tutorials. Since I knew I had to keep the game, I made sure to play it for what it was worth. Turns out that was about a week of fun before the charm ran out.I expected the game to have some of the dynamism of Civ 4, with more economics, since Soren Johnson was the lead on the game. It turns out to be a fast, pausable real-time game where you mine, buy, sell and turn into about 3 products. Matches run about 15-30 minutes depending on game type (campaign, skirmish, multiplayer), or end more quickly if you make an oversight in your production. Your AI opponents are trying to get the upper hand on the market and drive you out of business. Both the player and AI can corner the market on resources and production, and play dirity tricks to steal from or knock the competition's production offline. You can also upgrade production techniques and patent methods to give you an edge in making your products. The winner buys out all of the competition, forcing them to become subsidiaries.Graphics wise the game uses sharp, simple graphics with a bright, almost neon palette. It is easy enough to see what is going on once you get used to watching ships shoot across the map carrying cargo. Outliners for sales, resources, and production are visible and easy to use. There are a number of voiceovers to events in the game, such as a company losing stock, a disaster, or industrial accident. Most of them use a pretentious tone, and they sound off regularly to inform you of the happenings of the map. The voices do not seem consistent to the AI personalities, and I got tired of hearing "Screw with us, and we'll screw with you" and its ilk after about the 20th time I heard it in a match.Since I didn't like the game enough, I never tried multiplayer. If you were hoping for a deep simulation and a wide sprawling market where you plan and plot over time, this isn't your game. Its a short, well-designed game that plays at the pace of a casual title. Campaign mode can be fun, because it lets you acquire and keep upgrades between matches. Skirmish mode is a place to practice and find out how not to lose. It took me about 8 hours to understand the flow of the game and how to win. Just remember the tutorials take a lot of time, so if you don't like it in the first hour, you may want to seek a refund. I may get bored enough to return to the game one day, but the frenetic pace and short playtime just does satisfy as much as winning or losing in another game of thoughtful planning.Pros:The AI is smart and know how to play the game well on standard difficultySharp, if cartoonish graphicsRobber-barons on MarsCons:Short playtimeAnnoying, inconsistent voiceoversLots of critical thinking, QUICKLY!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												Ahead: I personally do not find this game to my taste. It's just not the genre i like.On the surface it looks like a base building sim. However, as the legendary Diablo review by ActionButton showed eloquently, sometimes what looks like a game of chess can actually be a round of Street Fighter.OTC is like that. It may look like a base building sim, but it only looks like that insomuch Street Fighter looks like a Jump'n Run.Important things that differentiate it from classical base building sims: The amount of buildings you can build is highly limited. I think somewhere around 20 total. You're not expected to build a huge base and never remove any of it, in fact, you're supposed to keep changing and modifying your base to meet the market's needs for the 13 resources. Just like in combat, standing still means death. There's also very little to do on the base level other than building/bulldozing producers and upgrading your HQ. All the interaction between the bits of your base are automated.In short: The base is only your gamepad with which you engage on the actual battleground, which is one that is extremely high speed.The actual battleground consists of selling resources when prices are high, producing or buying when they are low, managing whatever debt you have, in order to make enough money to use super abilities to disrupt enemy activities to drive them into ruin, or straight-up buy them out on the stock market.The speed of all of the above is increased by prices (resources/stock) reacting immediately to any action taken by any player in a match. If you react a split second too late, your huge pile of electronic chips may be worthless because your opponent dumped theirs first.This is not a game of base building.This is a game of high frequency trading simplified to human scales.

That is not the offworld capitalist way.I will update this review as I play more but so far I have to say how good it looks with loads of replayability.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
												I purchased this game back when it was in early Alpha, and did a majority of my playing then.  I played some more late into the Alpha and was happy to see that while changes had been made, it was still a fairly fun non-violent game.  I recently noticed that it had reached "completed" status and decided it was time to give it another try.Graphics wise - the game is in a much better place then it was during Alpha.  It eats noticably more system resources than before but with good reason, the buildings and terrain is much more detailed and pleasing, and turning down the graphic settings is always an option.Gameplay wise - After only a few minutes of playing again I already felt fatigued.  It felt like gameplay hadn't changed at all since the Alpha, so I was just doing what I remembered doing then: play your factions strengths/advantages and try to buyout companies.  I did notice in the one Skirmish that I played that some rules had been changed around.  I now had to complete a Skirmish to access the Campaign despite almost all of my Alpha play being in the campaign's different iterations.  But hey, a skirmish to learn is better than a hand-holding tutorial so why not.  During the skirmish I bought out one of the competing companies, but that companies assets didn't become mine (as they previously did in the Alpha), so I spent over 1/4 of a million to buy a company that was floundering thinking I'd get to add it to my conglomerate and improve it.  WRONG.  Five minutes later I notice red numbers next to my biggest competator - he's getting closer and closer to buying me out, though I cannot help but notice he and the other still-standing competator both have over 200k in debt - I figure they must have to pay this off before doing anything major.  WRONG.  Considering that I was actually two companies worth over 4 million at that point, the opposing company that bought me seems to have gotten a great deal having only paid 3/4 of a million (on top of a few hundred thousand for some of my shares over the 30 minutes of play) to buy me out.Personally, I liked the Alpha better.  I probably won't bother trying to beat a skirmish to access the campaign (even though it's what I really want to play) largely because I'm not sure I agree with a lot of the game's rules.  Watching AI companies stockpile massive debt like it's a good thing and having no access to boughtout company assets is a real turn off for me.  Or maybe, like a lot of people say, I've just already played enough in Alpha to use up all the replayability of the game.A fun game, but not worth it unless it's on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												Okay, so I'm far from the best to write a review on this game and that is because:1: I only have about 8.6 hours in game at the time of writting the review2: I'm not a big RTS playerSo with that in mind, I can give out my opininion about the gameThe concept of the game is great, the fact that you have to focus on trading more than fighting to claim victory is interesting. It brings a new kind of experience to the genre wich is a good thing. The whole mechanic of the game is based arround collecting and selling ressources to turn a profit and stack up capital, wich is then used to build more or buy stocks in opposing companies in order to buy them out. Great concept in general.So the concept is great, but what about the gameplay? Well that too is pretty good, now if I could I would make some interactions less troublesome but since I haven't taken the time to go bind my keys I can't blame the game for not having something it might have. Other than a few annoying things the gameplay is all you could ask for, it is slow paced but that is normal from the very nature of the game.So concept and gameplay are good, but is it worth the price? I personnaly bought it when it was in early access so I got ~16 CDN$ worth of DLC for free, now that includes the Soundtrack DLC and the Real Mars Map Pack DLC, but with that aside i'm only reviewing the game itself, not the DLC. I can say I'll have enough fun to make it worth the 39.99 USD$ I payed for it when steam didn't have the CDN$ shop. Current retail price in CDN$ is 43.99 and I can say I would gladly have payed this price aswell. Now, the campaign has it's own share of goodies but it isn't a story based campaign like Star Craft and War Craft had, it's more like a few skirmish rounds on different maps with different objectives. I am in the middle of my first one so i can't tell you all about it but it gives you different ways to play the game wich in the end adds to the value. The standard skirmish is great and is the most fun for me. I can already assure you that it was worth my money in those almost nine hours.[EDIT] I just finished the campaing and it was incredibly satisfying. Definitely doing a few others soon!So my final verdict, if you already play RTS games and love them then go give it a try! The whole economic twist will make you play something you never played before. If you are new to RTS games in general this isn't a bad palce to start. You'll find the more military based ones just as good when you get to them, plus if you are having trouble starting there is a 91 pages almanac to help you get the hang of the game.My rating? 9/10, 90/100, 18/20, 4.5/5Hope this review was useful to you! If so, please let me and steam know right below in the: Was this review helpful corner.If you are looking for a good match jsut add me up and I'll buy you out anytime!With all of this said I'll end it here and let you all go: save humanity, turn a profit, preferably both.CmD0_ out

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												I have given this game a recommendation, but I wouldn't call it a complete or total recommendation as there are some parts of the experience that didn't really meet my expectations.The good:  The game tutorials are humorous and the gameplay is interesting enough. I would call it a resource management game or 'an RTS without troops' if that makes any sense.  I like it overall.The bad:  I bought this game to play as a co-op experience and that's why I thought it came with a free 2nd copy - to play with a friend!  Turns out that there is no co-op campaign and it's basically just multiplayer skirmishing against AIs or other humans that can be considered cooperative.  I wish games would stop being labeled as co-op if they only have it in the multiplayer mode - that should be called multiplayer co-op or something to differentiate the two.The ugly:  The single player mode is well designed and has some very interesting mechanics but it's damn short.  It hardly feels like the mechanics of planning your company and investing your personnel while managing your cash flows have a chance to amount to anything over the few chances you get to make choices.  It feels like they cut the single player down to the shortest allowable length, which is too bad as it has potential.I recommend this game but be aware of the above.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												A deep RTS that requires more skill and strategy than a high ATM.Offworld Trading Company had been on my wishlist for a while before I decided to buy it but I am so pleased I bought the game.Some reviews stated the game was to simple or shallow and this were the ones that made me think twice before pulling the trigger but this is one of the deepest games I have ever played and whilst it is very simple to pick up (thanks to a very good tutorial) its a very hard game to master.You have a few options when it cames to playing pick from the single player skrimish mode or campaign both of which provide a very hard to beat and smart A.I. and the campaign is endlessy replayable, a test your score against others daily challange and of course multiplayer.As the title states this is not a game where a high action per minute rate is the be all and end all but a game that requires a plan (a plan that you also might need to abandon ) and some forward thinking.All in all a great game that appeals to someone like myself who does not enjoy the more classic RTS games.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												Ahead: I personally do not find this game to my taste. It's just not the genre i like.On the surface it looks like a base building sim. However, as the legendary Diablo review by ActionButton showed eloquently, sometimes what looks like a game of chess can actually be a round of Street Fighter.OTC is like that. It may look like a base building sim, but it only looks like that insomuch Street Fighter looks like a Jump'n Run.Important things that differentiate it from classical base building sims: The amount of buildings you can build is highly limited. I think somewhere around 20 total. You're not expected to build a huge base and never remove any of it, in fact, you're supposed to keep changing and modifying your base to meet the market's needs for the 13 resources. Just like in combat, standing still means death. There's also very little to do on the base level other than building/bulldozing producers and upgrading your HQ. All the interaction between the bits of your base are automated.In short: The base is only your gamepad with which you engage on the actual battleground, which is one that is extremely high speed.The actual battleground consists of selling resources when prices are high, producing or buying when they are low, managing whatever debt you have, in order to make enough money to use super abilities to disrupt enemy activities to drive them into ruin, or straight-up buy them out on the stock market.The speed of all of the above is increased by prices (resources/stock) reacting immediately to any action taken by any player in a match. If you react a split second too late, your huge pile of electronic chips may be worthless because your opponent dumped theirs first.This is not a game of base building.This is a game of high frequency trading simplified to human scales.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												I can really recommend this game.  First, I would like to say something about the negative criticism about the "simple rules"  of this game. Indeed, the rules of the game are clear and not that difficult to learn. However, "simple rules"  do not imply a simple game. I think this is not a simple game at all. You really have to think strategically about each choice you make, because you only have a certain amount of money to spent, a certain amount of building locations, a certain amount of resources... etc. You all have to balance that out and watch your opponent carefully. Besides playing a skirmish game against AI or playing a game in multiplayer, there is also a single player campaign. This campaign is not really story driven, but gives a twist on the standard skirmish game. After 11 hours of play, I barely touched it, because I am still trying to beat the AI  in skirmish on a higher difficulty level.This brings me to the next positive side and that is that there is a wide range of AI difficulty levels. On the lowest level, I find the game pretty easy. On "standard" AI (in which you and the AI do not get any bonuses, and so is the most fair game) I am still not able to win. The variety between the different skirmish matches comes from different resource availability, different resource locations, and also different factions. There are four different factions in the game, each play a bit differently.Even if you only want to play singleplayer I think this game has a lot variety and replayability to offer. I did not play in multiplayer at all yet. People that like strategy games will probably like this great game. So buy it!

												This is a really good game. It is an RTS but with really no units to speak of. It is an economic sim like Anno but with greatly streamlined gameplay. It is a multiplayer game with an incredibly strong single-player campaign with progressive unlocks.It is by the lead designer of Civ4, and it shows. It is all about fun with incredible depth beneath it on every facet. Also the music is incredible. It's by Christopher Tin. You know that awesome song in Civilization 4 (Babu Yetu, which is Swahili for Out Father)? He did that. He does it again here. It feels somber as you enter in. It is tense as the game roles with his music. It ties together nicely.I played it under early access, but it is so, so much better now.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												This is quite a special game that does not fit into any conventional category. It's an RTS-like game but there are no combat units to manage. You win by out thinking your opponents (AI, in my case) by outplaying them in the commodity market. The game's premise is that you and a few other AIs are setting up shop in Mars. You race against each other to see who make the most money out of mining minerals in the planet. The more of certain minerals you sell, the price of the minerals will go down in the stock market. This manipulation of the stock market will enable you to influence the net worth of your company as well as your opponent's. You win buy buying the company shares, having a corporate take over. The action is pretty intense and yet, you can always auto pause to take a breather and think of your next strategy. Having high reflex and able to execute many actions per minutes does not matter here, this is not your usual RTS. And yet, the amount of excitement from creating espionage to influece the stock markets, causing the shares of your competitors to drop is very real. Each game is short, maybe an hour for each sitting, very useful for a quick fix before bed. Highly recommended!

There is a lot of information that needs to be conveyed in the game and it's done in a very clumsy and uninformative matter combined with a poor user interface.At least the art and music are great.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Soren Johnson does it again.This is an excellent game. Keeping with the spectacularly high standards previously set by Johnson's earlier games (i.e. Civilization IV), he takes a genre- RTS- and completely reinvents it in a new, engaging and fun way- the economic RTS! Gameplay is addictive and systems are compelling to interact with. I love the art style and the game is both fun to play in single player and multiplayer in their own unique ways. If you like Civilization, RTS games, really anything with fun gameplay, trust Soren Johnson once again and get Offworld.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I first saw this it looked promising, nice new RTS to play.I've been playing it for awhile now and all I can think is how I got fooled into dropping 35 bucks for this. The balance is practically non-existent, the AI seems to make horrifyingly bad choices and at times it seems like the game is straight up cheating as ridiculous as that may sound. A particular example of this happened in one game when the bot, finding itself roughly $80,000 in debt, suddenly and inexplicably, had it's stock-price nearly quadruple while it's debt only increased.It then proceeded to use it's newfound debt to buy me out in all of twenty seconds.Deciding that perhaps operating so far in the red that you're in the black must be how you do things on Mars, I tried a similar strategy only to be met with the bot making the same miraculous turn-around only a few days in.Setting aside the questionable balance for a moment, I'd also like to point out that the audio is almost impossible to understand at times. But I guess that's kind of a moot point considering the probables you're going to have to go through to play this miserable game.All in all? Save your money for a better game. Wishing I'd stuck to the "avoid early access at all costs" lesson I keep learning and ignoring...

Early Access Review
								Read the game description and take them at their word. This game is not like Anno xxxx or Planetbase. This game plays like Starcraft or Command and Conquer. This is fast paced strategy, and when it comes right down to it, there's not much difference between matching your attack type to an enemy's defence type and sabotaging your enemy's chemical production right when you notice a lot of players building labs all at once. But the latter for me feels more grounded in plausibility and ends up more fun. The only criticism I could have for an economic version of this type of rts gameplay is that when you are defeated, it is with an instant cash buyout. There are many interesting routes to that situation being possible, but when it happens there isn't much warning and then bam- you're out of the game. I don't even really mind that so much, though. When you're about to lose Starcraft you have to preside of the death of all your soldiers. This game rips the bandage off quickly, and your company becomes a subsidiary. I presume most of your workers even get to keep their jobs. I play the crap out of the daily maps. I haven't won one yet. 9.6/10

number of helpful: 18 of 33 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Cannot recommend the game at this time.  This game is brutally difficult, even on the lowest difficulty settings.  CPU players are far too aggressive (Think Civ 5 Ghandi meets the Red Skull) and do not seem to compete with one another.  There is a bug currently in the game that allows CPU players to purchase stock in your company even when they do not have the funds to do so.  The game also, apparently, gives stipends of cash to the AI player, resulting in an early game juggernaut.  Every game is a zerg rush - there is no long term strategic play in this game whatsoever.  Sabottage corporations in particular are incredibly frustrating to play against and their playstyle is one dimensional: to deny others the ability to play.  This is not a very good design for an RTS game, as there is no effective counter to this playstyle that is accessible at all during the early game.The CPU text-to-speech announcements get annoying very fast, especially the one voice that is barely understandable - I thought I had selected the wrong localization.  Overall, this is a great concept and the game could be fun, but for now the game is balanced such that it is just a mad rush with no real strategic depth or fun factor.  It needs more Sid Meier.Could this game be worth the money?  Eventually, maybe.  It isn't right now.  Hold off on this one.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is very enjoyable to play. The graphics and animations of the buildings are really great, it has a good playability experience in general. The game is exensive, as I don´t really feel there is that much to do just yet in Early Access, but having spoken to one of the developers it is obvious that they really care about the game, so I am looking forwards to see what they add to it in the future.I found the game either very easy, or very slow on the extreme ends of the difficulty spectrum, so I would suggest you start off on a mid range setting. Also don´t expect the AI´s to all gang up on you, they work on an every man for himself basis,which is more realistic.I would perhaps wait for the game to be on discount if you are tight on money, but if you are working and have cash go for it at full price.The game is very accomplished graphically, and with some more voice over work in the future I feel the sound would be equally good.I don´t like the tutorial system in the game, I find the teacher characters annoying, but then who really likes tutorials in any game anyway.All in all I would give the game a 7 out of 10 in its current form, needing more content to make the game longer and bigger to score higher, but overall worth a look even if just for the cool animated buildings and atmosphere of the game.For the developers, here is what I would hope to see with this game in the future:- More buildings. It would be cool if you could have 12 or so more buildings. My recommendations would be: A Biodome (food), Shield Generator (black market defence, e.g. emp), Casino (pleasuredome clone), Landing Station (for importing materials or tourists), Gold/Diamond/Valuables mine (profit generation), variants of the existing buildings.- Larger maps, I feel the current map, even the large one is too small.- A sandbox mode without claims, where you can spread accross the map.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												I've had this game since it was in beta, and was the first game I ever streamed on Twitch. Even when its graphics, characters, and music were sketchy as hell, the core gameplay was enticing enough for me to spend HOURS learning how to read the stock market, fake out other players, and understand how I lost. This isn't Civ. This isn't a turn-based strategy or another RPG (both of which are my more usual fare). It's a game that's like... like chess with the stock market on Mars. There are a limited number of moves/buildings/resources and only one way to win--but infinite strategies to get there. If you like chess-on-steroids while you're competing against the clock, you'll love this. If you're looking for a narrative or something closer to Civ, go elsewhere--but keep this in your library when you're ready to stretch your brain a bit.

content:
Posted: April 20
												This game is fun, challenging, and rewarding, even when you lose. Its kinda fun to see how much you're worth to someone else after you lose a close match. Most matches run about half an hour, sometimes more, sometimes less. The whole game is about market manipulation until you can buy out your competitors, hostile-take-over style. Which makes agressive actions almost a necessity. I once bought a guy out because he was relentlesly attacking me. I had to liquidate EVERYTHING to do it. I was saving to go after the bigger fish because he was already moving on my expensive stock. But once I secured my safety, and no longer losing my money makers, I was able to restock while the market recovered from my stockpile dump, Which allowed me completely dominate the market the rest of the match. But that moment of indecisiveness almost cost me, and Ive lost to that same move before. The action is there, and this game rewards you for clever thinking, but sometimes you gotta earn that win, they wont always hand it to you.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								A deceptively fast-paced economic, base-building strategy game with no military units.Offworld plays very well in a FFA environment, and I enjoy 6- and 8-player games regularly. It keeps you on your toes as players react to changing prices, trying to make profits. You need to be constantly asking yourself, "what resources are the other players neglecting?" It can become quite frenzied in the end game as you buy up a couple other players and suddenly you need to manage ~60 structures, trying to gain cash faster than your rivals, who are trying to buy out your company. Trash those Glass Furnaces, drop down Reactors, research Oxygen production because it's selling for 60k offworld. Your rival has more Offworld Markets; better sabotage his shipments or oxygen production...Every game is different with randomized maps and resource distributions. Black Market (aggressive abilities and other utilities) is also switched up. There isn't really a build order; need to look at the map and the other colonies to figure out the best overall plan, which will definitely change several times during the 20 min game.It's fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Offworld Trading Company is an excellent game.  Simply put, it strikes the perfect balance between heavily detailed strategy and intuitive gameplay.  This allows you to begin enjoying the game from the off, but also to continue honing your skills for hours afterward.  Some negative reviews indicate that OTC gets repetitive quickly.  I disagree.  Although the main idea of the game remains the same, there are numerous factors that make every match entertaining in its own way.  Personally, I find it no more monotonous than turn-based strategy games like Age of Wonders or Civilization.In summation, Offworld Trading Company is a wonderful multiplayer or singleplayer game that I reccomend to anyone who enjoys RTS games.Overall: 9.2/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								4x strategy without combat and Stephen Hawking doing the voice-over!Graphics serve their purpose, the interface is sharp and controls in general feel very polished. This looks and feels like Civilization 5. Just do yourself one favour: turn off both the music and the sound effects.It's a business game that offers a lot of macro economic goodness. Supply and demand at its core, resource shortage, bottlenecks, dirty tactics.This game offers the best a.i. I've ever seen and it's still far from finished. The a.i. doesn't cheat on low to medium difficulty settings and it still gives me a tough fight for my money.I'll give you an example what the a.i. did to me:I was totally reliant on my next two steel shipments. The a.i. evaluated my situation, hired pirates and intercepted those vital steel shipments. I went bankrupt because I was used to games offering poor a.i.. I was aware of the bottleneck in my supply chain. Hell, I'm even writing a paper on supply chain management RIGHT NOW! And the a.i. was set on the 3rd of 8 difficulty levels! This should have been a walk in the park.Well, I learned from it. After 3 hours of playing I'm pistol-whipping this little ******. I own the a.i. (on level 3 of 8). Now it's time to be a man and face it at 50% of its might. :DThe price:I got it on 50% summer sale. For 19 quid it offers fantastic value. I would go as high as 30. Wouldn't pay 40 though just yet. It's too steep for an early access game. Wait for a decent sale and get it if you enjoy economic games.The con:There's only one problem with the game and unfortunately it's a major one: the performance is sub par. The game is rather cpu-heavy. I got a decent system (i5-4660, gtx 960, 8 gb ram) which is way above min reqs. The cpu seems to be the bottleneck and it shouldn't be really. It's just a matter of poor programming (no multi-core support maybe?).-----------------------------------------Update: As of beta 4 the performance has improved significantly and is actually pretty good now.Update: The game is in beta 5 by now. Many improvements again. Farther zoom level, balance, more campaign features etc.Having played it for 45 hours now in total, I can easily recommend it. Still not burned out on it in any way.rating: 9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												If Command and Conquer impregnated Port Royal and they gave the genius child to Richard Branson to raise, this would be the result.NOTE: If your looking for another CIv or Anno, this aint'nt it. it is not casual, it is not friendly. this game means buisness. and.youll.need.to.think.(thank god)Ever Managed a company?If the answer is yes, then this will seem familiar.Dont get me wrong, its cartoonified and simplified, but its every bit as involved, with the management systems impeccably balanced between your own needs, your competitors needs and your balance sheet (as in real life).This is not particularly easy, and the game means what it says for its difficulty levels. Most games I see recently have it set so that easy means brain-dead, medium means easy peesy, hard means youll need to think etc, not so OTC. Of the 5 levels to choose from the 3rd (Apprentice, i think)  is recommended for anyone who wants to graduate to online, and the game will truly try to win and challenge you. I lost my first 2-3 games on apprentice, but after you have picked up all the tricks (underground nuking their minable resources is my personal favourite) youll always have a fighting chance if you stay focused and flexible. Ive seen several reviews claiming the game is too hard; it is challenging, and it definitely is not pick-up-and-play, but its not impossible (also go for an easier setting....) With that said it is a strategy game...think strategically and youll have a shot, go forward without a plan and the AI will punish you every time.My only worry is longevity, once you can reliably beat the computer time and again (even though its fun every time) the game does start to pall a little, and with the online systems untried for major usage, it worries me a tad.I wholeheartedly enjoyed this game, and if you enjoy strategy and games that force you to TRY then Im confident you will too. Its that beautiful balance...not quite like anything ive played before, but familiar enough to still feel like home.
