content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Early Access ReviewIn his current state it´s hard to write an effective review but the game has true potential.The concept is easy and at the same time complex, you have two different modes of game, Quick Play and Campgain, and until now I managed to fully understand the standart game. You start with an unrevealed mapand you have X scans(you will receive more over the time) to use and scan for resources, after you´re first scans you will definetly find some resources and the call is yoursShould I place my HQ here or do I keep scannig for(maybe) a better place? Of course that these depends on the type of HQ you will play with. The 4 HQ´s are Expansionists, Robotics, Scavengers and Scientifics and each one of these have a distinct way of operating. Once you place your HQ it´s time to put down your buildings, but chose carefully because you have a limit and you have to place them in a way where you won´t be in a HUGE debt right at the begining of the game. After you spend all the claims you willprobably want more and you need to upgrade you HQ. It takes some resources so be careful! After all these steps it´s time to make the "big ones" and try to "buy" your opponents, and make sure that you are not bought otherwise its Game Over for you.You can always use some dirty tricks to slow down your opponents or really just wreck them,it´s called Black Market and you want to use it for sure!The multiplayer is amazing(no problems until now) and for those who like "tension" this is the perfect game. Always be careful and never try to be the owner of every resourceor you´re gonna get: (nuke/EMP/dynamite/many others)ed and believe me you do not want to be that guy on the match.And thats pretty much the concept, of course that it´s not fully explored or working perfectly and that´s why it is an Early Access game.General:Now:7/10When released:8.5/10 or (hopefully) 9/10

This game was definitely worth my time It's fun and challenging, and the campaign mode really adds the layer of depth to merit its otherwise hefty price tag. My main issue is that the games don't last longer. I pictured the game being more of a drawn-out management game like Civ, rather than the relatively short gameplay sessions (which are still totally awesome by the way). Also, the 'voice acting' when important events are triggered makes me want to drive screwdrivers into my ears -- just a small complaint.   Overall, it's relatively polished, and stands out from other early access games due to its potential as a new franchise.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								So my friends and I have  been waiting in anticipation for this game to launch for weeks now and so far, definetly not disapointed! While this game is pretty fun in single player it really shines in multiplayer. As someone who plays a lot of 4x and strategy games with friends, this game is a blast. It's something completely different which I'm always on the hunt for.The game is you play a company on mars and you are trying to snag the resources you can and make money, all while buying out the other players. But it goes deeper than that. You only have so many claims for resources, and distance from your base makes a serious difference. Sabatoge adds a whole other layer to the game as well and is probably my favorite part! Nothing like completely shutting down another players supply chain and listening to them curse. It still needs some balancing, for example, the off world trade center seems almost too powerful, and a save function and maybe a minimap would be nice.  But the game honestly feels finished and if someone didn't know it was EA, I don't think they'd guess.

Early Access Review
								Its an alright looking game but it's not ready as the early access title describes. There is potential for a space based trading game but I feel that they limit themselves too much; Pirates are scarce, there are no "aliens" or life forms to disrupt resource mining, only one planet and the difficulty levels are too extreme for casual players. If you want a nice and relaxing game then this is not for you as rapid expansion and seizing of choice mining plots are essential to win with no room for error on the "minimal" difficulty setting. Oh and the other corps are constantly sabotaging you, kind of looses its novelty after the 40th time in a mission. This game is near impossible to win a single match which will turn casual players away. On the other hand if you like your @$$ handed to you multiple times and squeezing out a win then you are a sadist and this is the game for you!

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Not sure why I bought this. So you know how some RTS games with an economy focus let you sell off spare resources to get other stuff you need? It's basically that game, except you win by selling enough resources to buy out your opponents. There isn't any reason to build an economy beyond that goal. As a free-market capitalism tutorial I guess it's educational, but it probably would have made a better board game than a videogame.As for the state of the alpha right now, balance is pretty wonky, such as lower-valued companies can easily and unpreventably buy out more valuable competitors off the back of a single off-world shipment plus a little commodity selling, and the framerate is both unlocked and badly optimized enough that my computer tries to melt a hole in the floor just on the main menu. The game has ran stably for me but I don't know how they're going to bulk out the gameplay to make this an interesting thing to play. It is tuned so the commodity production and everything else can be done very quickly, so twitch plays a factor and you can't play this with anything but undivided attention, which is unfortunate since I find it quite boring. If it were slower paced and less hectic I could at least listen to a podcast or something while I played.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												The graphics are excellent and the gameplay is great (so long as you like frantic and short), and replayability is the whole point. The soundtrack is neither bad nor inspiring. So why the "Not Recommended"?What there is of this game is good, but I can't help but to think that other developers must be looking at it and thinking, "Wait, people will review a game this well even though it's basically one scenario, without a campaign, over and over again, as long as that one scenario is *really* well polished?" There just isn't enough game here to warrant a recommendation, especially not for $40. I think I paid $20 for it. It would be a good game a $9.99. The game is not even very deep, contrary to what others have said. You get whatever your specific group needs to grow, and then you get whatever is rare, and you win. That's every single playthrough, each of which takes maybe 20 minutes. There is no story, no campaign, no reason to play any more than a few matches as each faction, which I have already done in a whopping 17 hours (according to Steam). This is technically a strategy game, but, since each playthrough starts from nothing, plays frantically, and ends quickly, it plays almost more like a board game with good graphics. It feels more like a mini-game from a AAA title than a game in and of itself. On the plus side, I swear that's Jeffrey Combs (Weyoun from Star Trek Deep Space Nine, among other things) doing the various announcements, so there is that.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an interesting game. The fact that it is non violent is a clear plus. The economic twist to it is a plus too. But considering its current state it is overpriced and the 10% discount is a joke. I would recomment buying at 15-20€ even for an early access (shouldn't early access games be cheaper than finished ones ?)The main con I find to it that the graphics are really slow (or it requires a graphic card too powerful) especialy when one considers the quality of the graphics of the buildings.Oh, sorry, the first con is actually the fact that you cannot scroll on the map and there is no minimap. You use the keyboard to move. Or maybe I missed something which could be included in the absent documentation.The second/third con is the lack of diversity for the decor. The maps are diverse with regards to the resources, but the red mars tend to be a bit boring on the long run.If you can overcome these issues, the game actually turns out to be... ok (I din't say great or anything similar). It really is about trading so you can afford to loose money on cheap resources that you don't produce as long as you earn more on expensive resources that you produce.The number of tiles (aka buildings) that you can build is very limited so you should be careful about how you use them and how you place them. You can scrap a building to build another but only at the same place.Finally, once you've built the offworld market you've more or less won. This is how I won the scientific scenario that some others claim to be unfeasible. By the way, I won all the tutorials without using the engineering. I still don't know what it does but it does not seem very useful so far.One should also note that this a rather fast paced game especially at the beginning (or maybe it is just the game lagging that prevents you from playing fast enough).I haven't done the multiplayer part yet. Hopefully, this will be intersting.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have never played anything like it before. Someone wrote, it compares best to the classic M.U.L.E. The basic idea is, that you found a venture on mars to grab ressources, manufacture goods, and sell them for a profit.There is a dynamic price mechanism based on supply and demand. This is nothing new. But it plays out in real time and feels like an RTS. (Sidenote: One of the designers mentioned Company of Heroes when talking about OTC! The game is totally different, but it "feels" as action packed as CoH while being all about economics).So you have to make decisions all the time - and since it is real time, there is a cost for not deciding: Do I claim a nice tile of land on mars to put a new factory there? Or do I make my existing stuff more efficient? Do I buy up someone elses stock? Or do I pay back my debt to prevent someone else from buying me out? Do I want to produce something that will guarantee small profits, or do I take a risk and switch to a potentially more profitable strategy? And .... WHO THE HELL has sabotaged my power supply again?!? The content and scope of this game is limited, but beautiful. Thats why I think, this game should set for a price of about 25 USD. The mechanic is fresh, the presentation is nice and the playstyle is rather unique.And I love the music. It will probably change a lot of times... I hope they include most of it in the final soundtrack.My impression:- Single Player: Skirmish and Daily challenge are nice play modes. The campaign mode feels like an addon - but it will need a lot of polish if it wants to compete with games like Anno 1401. - Multiplayer: Intense! Currently you might have to wait a few minutes to get a game going. This will get much more popular the closer OTC gets to release date.Good points:- Fresh playstyle and interesting scenario.- Nice and fluent visual presentation and music.- Cutthroat multiplayer robberbaron capitalism.- Music and sound.Not so good points (yet!):- Statistics will need more work. (I assume it gets it)- Almost no storytelling. (I don't expect too much changes here)- You win by clicking a button. This isn't the most exciting way of a finale (yet!)I would not expect a huge package that offers anything near the variety of a Civ V. If you are ok with the limited but exciting scenario, then you should grab this game now!

content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												It looks like an RTS but plays closer to a real-time version of a board game, specifically, a worker placement game. Whereas worker placement games tend to fall under the Eurogame umbrella (i.e. boring abstract pieces of uninteractive garbage) Offworld Trading Company thankfully doesn't fall into that trap.You're on Mars to make mad dosh and prevent your fellow corporations from doing the same. The black market exists for you to fry their steel industry at key points with EMPs, to hire pirates to prey upon their shipping lines, and to cause energy blackouts.Every decision has heavy weight, especially the decision to spend claims, which is the game's territory system. You can't endlessly expand your borders like Civilization. Every time you upgrade your HQ you gain 4-5 tiles' worth of claims which you can then spend to create facilities on land. The level of long-term strategy is high here because you can't refund those claims; the most you can do is destroy the building, which may not even help you if you need a building with a different resource.I would recommend this to any strategy gamer who has grown bored of traditional manifestations of the genre. Don't forget to make lodse money!

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												If the idea of an almost purely economical RTS "battle" appeals to you, then this is a game you definitely should own. However I feel like the 40 dollar price tag is too steep for what it is.First off, where this game really shines is multiplayer. Small battles, even just 1v1 with a friend, are really fun. Everything is about speed. The game is different from most traditional city builders. There's not a whole lot of "city building" going on. That is to say, the way that you decide to lay out your "town" is not overly important to the game. You can get certain bonuses for having some buildings next to others. For instance, placing any building next to another of the same type gives you a production bonus that is stackable, and buildings touching your HQ don't need fuel for transporting goods. Other than that, city design isn't a prominent aspect. Instead, the gameplay is all about speed. Claim territory, make money, and claim more territory as fast as possible.More often than not, the person who manages to claim the best territory the fastest will end up winning. Because of this, games can often be decided in the first 5-10 minutes. They also usually don't last more than 20-30 minutes. That is part of what makes the game so cool. If you're looking for a quick multiplayer session with a friend, it can become a natural choice if you're both good at it. Skirmishes are very fast paced and don't last long so you can squeeze games in whenever you feel like it. However it's also one of the game's hindrances.I think it could do with a good deal more content. Games almost feel too fast. You rush to figure out what the key resources on the map are and acquire them, rush to build some factories, rush to research some technology to give you advantages, always keeping an eye on the fluctuating prices of various commodities and having to deal with your opponents sabotaging your production through various "black market" means. There's so much to keep track of that games can flip around on you in an instant. One second you can be on top, well ahead of the game, next thing you know WHAM game over you just got bought. It can often leave you going "what the hell just happened?"This is part of what makes it so fun and deadly, but at times it can feel somewhat lacking. So much of the game is just looking at numbers on the sidebar, constantly guaging prices, resources, buying, and selling. The actual graphics are very nice, but the funny thing is you don't actually spend a lot of time looking at the graphics, because winning is all about crunching numbers quickly. In my opinion the game would be better if there were some more layers of strategy that involved the actual graphical, planet of mars, city building related stuff. That would make this game a 9/10 for me at least. Alas, it does not, but if the devs keep developing it as they are it will get better.If you get it on sale, it's definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very fun multiplayer economic strategy game.  It feels like a spiritual successor to MULE, though with quite a bit of added complexity that I welcome; in MULE you had just three (technically four) resources:- Food, which gives you time to work during your turn- Energy, which is required to operate your MULEs so they can produce resources- Smithore, which is required to build your MULEs in the first place- There was also a fourth (rare) resource, Crystite, which was purely valuable as a commodity to sell when the price randomly fluctuated to a high level.Despite being very simple system, the three main resources worked well together and a shrewd player could, at great risk to themselves, potentially corner the market in one resource and leave all the other players out to dry.  Offworld Trading Company allows similar risky maneuvers, such as cornering the silicon market and preventing other players from producing glass and electronics, or cornering the water market and preventing other players from producing food, fuel, and oxygen.  While MULE was a local multiplayer game (it was the 1980s, online wasn't a thing), Offworld Trading Company is online, which allows for large player counts and real-time play instead of turn-based.  There are a lot of other differences, many of them positive, a few of them negative.There are still a few things I think need to be worked on; the ability to collude with other players to cooperate against another player by directly trading resources instead of putting them on the stock market would make a tremendous improvement and is one of the few vital game mechanics I really miss from MULE.  I'd suggest adding a new building which gives the ability for players to directly trade resources with each other with the caveat that like in the original MULE, the other players in the game should be made aware that these players are colluding.  It wouldn't necessarily say what specific transations took place, just that they made a transaction.  Transactions could range from a constant pooling of a certain resource or transferring resources in specific amounts, to temporarly lending ownership of a structure to another player.  Another thing I'd like to see is the ability to license patents to another player in exchange for a lump sum of money or a percentage of their profits.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												This game surprised me. It is very polished, the mechanics are well thought and the single player experience includes tons of variables to keep if fresh for a long time. When I got this game I was expecting something akin to Civilization, but it is much more closely related to Starcraft. Although I dislike RTS games like Starcraft, this game still captivated me, and I believe the best explanation as to why comes from the Designer Notes that comes bundled with the game: Originally posted by Soren Johnson: However, just because unit selection is so frustrating doesn’t mean that RTS games should die. RTS games are the best place in video games for players who want to think. They require difficult choices between short-term gains and long-term goals. They require reading an opponent’s mind and predicting her moves. They encourage formulating a plan and then learning when to deviate from it. They are endlessly replayable as every dominant strategy has a counter-strategy waiting to topple it. They are the only way to make multiplayer truly work in a strategic game, avoiding the intractable problem of having to wait for one’s turn. Most importantly, real-time games must be played intuitively, by feel and experience instead of the painfully slow analysis possible in turn-based games. Thus, RTS games should live. Unit selection, however, should die. An RTS game is, at its core, about making strategic choices in a real-time environment, about not just making interesting decisions but also about when and when not to make them. Unit selection is just not a necessary part of that formula and often keeps the player from engaging with the game’s actual design.I just loved that I don’t need to manage units and become a clicking machine. For that alone this game would already deserve much praise.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												So far I am enjoying the game.  If you are of the analytical mindset like me and into economics/the markets, you will enjoy it alot.  I also have always really enjoyed strategy games.  That said I would imagine such people is only a small subset of most gamers so I wonder how the player count will hold up over time.I like how the typical match does not feel too short or long.  Maybe a half hour or so.  There is not too many APM but at the same time there is plenty to think about and manage.My biggest issue with this game is that the graphics to performance ratio is in my view lacking.  Meaning, even with an overclocked Geforce 1070 and 6600 process and 16 gb DDR4 ram I am seeing my frame per second dip sometimes below 30.  Now granted for an overhead strategy game based more on numbers and thinking this is not as critical as say a first person shooter or racing game.  Nonetheless, the optimization should be better, especially considering the graphics are nothing to write home about.  Honestly the graphics are no better then starcraft 2 which is how old now?  Considering this game came out in 2016, they should of optimized it better, I get better frames per second on witcher 3 at ultra!  To further expand on the graphics, for example all deposits whether it be water or silicon have the same exact symbol!  The only difference is the color.  Couldn't the developers of thought of something a bit more creative to represent the deposits?  The "landscape" is so bland you barely recognize it outside vaugely referencing it to what may produce better power or where you can't build.To sum it up.  I think the actual gameplay mechanics are pretty well thought out and pretty fun to play.  But i think the graphic innovation and optimization seems to have gotten the lazy end of the stick especially for the price this goes for (though I got it on a steam sale for half off).  I would give it a 8.5 out of 10 but that is only because I am into stock markets and economics personally, for most people it probably would be around a 6.5.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												If the idea of an almost purely economical RTS "battle" appeals to you, then this is a game you definitely should own. However I feel like the 40 dollar price tag is too steep for what it is.First off, where this game really shines is multiplayer. Small battles, even just 1v1 with a friend, are really fun. Everything is about speed. The game is different from most traditional city builders. There's not a whole lot of "city building" going on. That is to say, the way that you decide to lay out your "town" is not overly important to the game. You can get certain bonuses for having some buildings next to others. For instance, placing any building next to another of the same type gives you a production bonus that is stackable, and buildings touching your HQ don't need fuel for transporting goods. Other than that, city design isn't a prominent aspect. Instead, the gameplay is all about speed. Claim territory, make money, and claim more territory as fast as possible.More often than not, the person who manages to claim the best territory the fastest will end up winning. Because of this, games can often be decided in the first 5-10 minutes. They also usually don't last more than 20-30 minutes. That is part of what makes the game so cool. If you're looking for a quick multiplayer session with a friend, it can become a natural choice if you're both good at it. Skirmishes are very fast paced and don't last long so you can squeeze games in whenever you feel like it. However it's also one of the game's hindrances.I think it could do with a good deal more content. Games almost feel too fast. You rush to figure out what the key resources on the map are and acquire them, rush to build some factories, rush to research some technology to give you advantages, always keeping an eye on the fluctuating prices of various commodities and having to deal with your opponents sabotaging your production through various "black market" means. There's so much to keep track of that games can flip around on you in an instant. One second you can be on top, well ahead of the game, next thing you know WHAM game over you just got bought. It can often leave you going "what the hell just happened?"This is part of what makes it so fun and deadly, but at times it can feel somewhat lacking. So much of the game is just looking at numbers on the sidebar, constantly guaging prices, resources, buying, and selling. The actual graphics are very nice, but the funny thing is you don't actually spend a lot of time looking at the graphics, because winning is all about crunching numbers quickly. In my opinion the game would be better if there were some more layers of strategy that involved the actual graphical, planet of mars, city building related stuff. That would make this game a 9/10 for me at least. Alas, it does not, but if the devs keep developing it as they are it will get better.If you get it on sale, it's definitely worth it.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												For those potential buyers trying to make sense of this game: What this game is: a business game. What this game is not: 4X Sim City cloneMilitary RTSIf you're still with me, then know this is a fantastic business sim set in a near-future Mars colonization setting.  The premise is that Humans are colonizing Mars (Yay!) but the overwhelmed colonies have privatized their resourcing operations to Earth coprorations (Oh no!).  That's where you come in - You're basically the Mars regional manager for a corporation trying to get a foothold on the planet, before the competition can woo the colonies away from you. PROSThis is fast-paced day trading coupled with supply chain management.  On Mars.  The sheer amount of stuff you can customize for each run (patents, optimization, contracting/hiring staff, etc.) allows for a myriad of strategies you can try against the different competition and conditions in each colony.  With campaigns, you have to plan and budget ahead of time for the future, because the competition gets starts to get fierce after you win several colonies.CONSA little pricy for what the gameplay actually is, which is basically a ledger and a map of resources to manage.  The graphics and sound are only a few rungs higher than what you'd expect on a mobile app.  Would recommend getting it on sale.SIMILAR GAMESI can't really think of any.  Factorio is more about the tactics and design of supply chain management and there isn't a market.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												Not worth over $30 considering all the content that's only accessible by buying the DLC. The options to select the content are built into the game menus but can only be picked if you pay an extra $30. I recently paid $20 for DLC for a free-to-play game with as much value and playability as OTC and felt like every dollar was worth it. These guys should include all that "DLC" for the price they charge for the game. OTC is a fun game for all skill levels. It has polished graphics and a dynamic economy. As mentioned elsewhere though, the games end far too quickly because opponents can buy each other out early. All of the game modes feel like this in some way. Whoever gets the early lead is likely to win while everyone else continues to play without a chance. That kills the fun a bit...Also the game uses long lessons instead of in-game prompts to teach you to play, so don't expect to turn it on an start playing right away.Now that the workshop is open, I'm sure a lot of cool mods are going to come out!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16
												TLDR: a must-try for people interested in strategy games, unless they absolutely hate rtsA very ingenious RTS design. Instead of watching and micro units and  unit-production , you watch prices and resource flows, trying to stay ahead of the competition  in building your economic engine. You spend your time racing for patents (usually a gamechanger in one of the supply chains), prime resource nodes, managing  stock purchases and of course sabotaging your enemy with different black market actions. This may sound boring to non-economically minded people, but it exceeds the usual rock-paper-scissors complexity many strategy games feature and does get hectic. There are four "factions" with different strengths, the puzzle is finding a good setup for a given map/resource distribution and anticipate price/supply shifts to profit from them before conditions change. Or maybe you find a way to force them to change in a beneficial manner? 96 hours in i dont have the sense of having mastered the mechanics  yet. There is a good variety of gamemodes: skirmish with different rules and maps, a daily challenge with a leaderboard, a campaign mode with lots of different options and factions and of course multiplayer. The later was clearly the design focus and i think works best. I think the campaign mode is weakest part of the game. After a  series of different scenarios and chances to build up your economic faction, you arrive at a climatic skirmishbattle to buy out your competition. In practice you often end up with  an overwhelming advantage or occasionally as if theres no chance to keep up.  Overall: people who enjoy strategy games, should check this out for many interesting and different ideas. Dont be put off by the economic theme!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												It's fun with literally any number of players except 3.It's in the same vein as other economic hostile-takeover games like TTD but it's much faster-paced, so instead of a game taking days to complete, it's over in 20-30 minutes. This is a good thing. The time between "It's obvious who the winner is" and "The winner is declared" is very short. Games don't last very long after the first buyout, so if you're playing multiple rounds with friends, you won't have to sit out long.The basic premise is to acquire resources and sell them to get money to repeat the process. Resource prices change accordingly every time something is bought or sold, and there are various market manipulations that can be done. There's plenty of ways to mess with your opponent there, and you can buy usable-once-only sabotages for further shenanigans.It has its problems - the first buyout practically doubles your stock price, so in a 3-player game the first buyout determines the winner; the remaining player has a 0% chance of catching up and should just concede immediately. The Offworld Market is a necessary evil on Mars (as otherwise all resource prices drop to 1, but whoever has them is basically guaranteed to win) and utterly useless on Ceres (as all resource prices eventually become 1000). The AI is WAY too good at the game, as it makes no attempts to hide that it can and will react instantly to situations, inputting commands faster than any human possibly could.Overall though, it's an excellent strategy game that doesn't take nearly as long to play a round of compared to others in the genre. A good game to grab if you like economic games or quick strategies.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Not for everyone, but good frantic RTS fun.Off the bat, one thing needs to be made clear, this is an RTS, not a 4X game. Matches are fast paced, hectic affairs, rarely lasting more than 30 minutes, even with a bunch of players. This isn't Sins of a Solar Empire, where games can stretch 4 hours, but Starcraft, with rapid strategy shifts in response to opponent actions culminating in a chaotic every man for himself finish. From the very first second of the game, when you're choosing where to found your HQ (and which HQ to choose, you don't have to make that selection before the game starts), you're shoved into direct competion with other players. I've purposefully built my HQ over some High Carbon deposits when playing against a couple Scavengers. It's a♥♥♥♥♥♥move, but it drives up the price of Carbon, and the market is an unforgiving battlefield. You need to be prepared to seize advantages and exploit weaknesses. Even playing on Slow speed, there's not a lot of time to think things through. You make decisions on the fly, relying on intuition as much as anything. There is no optimal strategy in OTC, as what works in one game might backfire in another. There are certainly things to learn, strategies to master, but there's no top to bottom plan that will lead to victory. You'll learn when it's worth expanding your HQ, what buildings synergize well, when to research and how to exploit the various Patents, etc. Most importantly, though, is learning how to "feel" the market. That Water surplus, is one of your opponents attempting to stockpile before researching Water Engines or Cold Fusion? Are they attempting to reduce their life support bill? Are they trying to reduce the value of another player who has a large stockpile of Water so they can buy them out? Or was it really just a random event? Whatever it is, react fast, and you might just be able to take advantage of it.There are people who play online in the Ranked Multiplayer, and OTC certainly has what it takes to be considered a competitive game. However, personally I have had the most fun playing with people I know, so, if you can, find some friends to get this game with. The Deluxe edition comes with some DLC and an extra copy, if you split the cost with someone it's cheaper than buying it outright. Unfortunately, the cost is a major sticking point with this game. As much as I like it, it's not worth $40, or even the $30/copy with the Deluxe edition. I picked it up for a little over half off, and I'm happy with that.TL;DR: Wait for a sale, but definitely pick this up if you enjoy fast paced RTS games.

Posted: February 20
												Offworld Shipping Company can best be described as a child of Sim City, Civilization and Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri. The premise is simple enough - you have to build a Mars-based resource exploitation and trading company, grow it faster than your competitors, and eventually buy them out in a hostile takeover via the stock market. Anyone who has ever played Civ and tried to go for non-military victories is going to appreciate what this game has to offer.I would say that the only downside is that the game is quite cognitively straining because it requires the player to to juggle a lot of numbers and economic variables, so this is not something you want to play if your goal is to blow off some steam after a hard day at work.Caveat emptor: the game is very addictive!

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Economic strategy game? More like Business Wars!!Offworld Trading Company does a good job capturing the essence of managing a corporation and trying to push out your competition by buying them out.  Simplistic yet detailed.  Though there is a lot going on, everything can easily be learned.  For example: Iron needs to be mined for your refineries to create steel.  Steel is then required for a lot of other buildings and reduces the overall cost to build more if you have a bunch in stock.  Or you can sell it on the market and make a tidy profit.  Smooth gameplay. Short on supplies?  The game automatically purchases what you need and increases your debt thus making the gameplay flow smooth.  Indicators also let you know when your facilities are not working and also lets you know what materials you do not have.  Corporate espionage.  Though you cannot directly attack the other corporations, you can cackle to yourself twisting your long mustache as you sabatoge your opponent's greatest money maker.Ranked Multiplayer.  The AI is more than enough challenge, however there is a ranked multiplayer you can jump in challenge other individuals to see who is the master of economic warfare.There really isn't much negative things to say about this game.  Except that maybe this game may not appeal to those who wants to bring out their troops and order them to attack.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												I've been staring at this game since early alpha debating whether to buy it and finally bit the bullet.  I should have done this when it was first offered.  If you like the idea of a super fast paced game of domination that is different every time, buy this.  Every thing you do can be countered by your opponent, and likewise you can counter everything your opponent does.  actions per minute helps but isn't necessary; playing smart is infinitely more important.  Every action your opponents take will have direct consequences on your products and prices, can you figure out what the demand is going to be?  will you be caught in a competitive market with your profits steadily dropping?  Will you just dominate through overproduction of your opponents?  Will you lock down technology that lets you skip their profit margins and go directly back into your product?  Will you find a niche that no one is competing in and exploit it?  There are so many paths to victory or defeat in this game and its so simple yet complex at the same time.  If you are still on the fence watch a few lets play videos until you get the gist of it, then figure out how the patent lab, off world market, blackmarket etc. make it infinitely more intricate.  Minutes to learn, lifetime to master.  Excellent game design.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								In short:A slightly weak 7/10 for now, but overall worth the money if you believe in future improvements (given the Early Access as well as overall game design).--------First off, this is NOT my kind of game. I'm the kind of player who prefers to spend time investing in one persistent game (as in Cities:Skylines, Dark Souls or an MMO), rather than a match-based game like this one.That said and given the premise of the match RTS subgenre, I have to say it's a very refreshing IP. No combat whatsoever, but instead an all-out trading system where you manipulate the market and make sure you produce, buy and sell the right kinds of resources for maximum profit and the detriment of your opponents (who share your market).As for resources, they do feel a bit few and "slapped onto" the game. There's no explicit tree structure or overall design that makes me feel like I should care (possibly because of the said match-based gameplay, which makes everything feel rushed).I guess I just wish that this kind of trade-focused game would be more fleshed out, with greater array of goods, upgrades, services, alternatives and just general depth. The game feels like a one-man indie game project.Overall, I have to say that the idea is pretty good and, for its premise and its price, the game plays decently (but not excellently). I can recommend this game, although just barely (I wish there was a third choice haha). The game does have major potential, and I do think the devs may deliver on some of that. I also haven't seen any major bugs with this game yet, but I haven't played it too much either so idk. But I do wish the game was just a few notches better than it is.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16
												TLDR: a must-try for people interested in strategy games, unless they absolutely hate rtsA very ingenious RTS design. Instead of watching and micro units and  unit-production , you watch prices and resource flows, trying to stay ahead of the competition  in building your economic engine. You spend your time racing for patents (usually a gamechanger in one of the supply chains), prime resource nodes, managing  stock purchases and of course sabotaging your enemy with different black market actions. This may sound boring to non-economically minded people, but it exceeds the usual rock-paper-scissors complexity many strategy games feature and does get hectic. There are four "factions" with different strengths, the puzzle is finding a good setup for a given map/resource distribution and anticipate price/supply shifts to profit from them before conditions change. Or maybe you find a way to force them to change in a beneficial manner? 96 hours in i dont have the sense of having mastered the mechanics  yet. There is a good variety of gamemodes: skirmish with different rules and maps, a daily challenge with a leaderboard, a campaign mode with lots of different options and factions and of course multiplayer. The later was clearly the design focus and i think works best. I think the campaign mode is weakest part of the game. After a  series of different scenarios and chances to build up your economic faction, you arrive at a climatic skirmishbattle to buy out your competition. In practice you often end up with  an overwhelming advantage or occasionally as if theres no chance to keep up.  Overall: people who enjoy strategy games, should check this out for many interesting and different ideas. Dont be put off by the economic theme!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												For those potential buyers trying to make sense of this game: What this game is: a business game. What this game is not: 4X Sim City cloneMilitary RTSIf you're still with me, then know this is a fantastic business sim set in a near-future Mars colonization setting.  The premise is that Humans are colonizing Mars (Yay!) but the overwhelmed colonies have privatized their resourcing operations to Earth coprorations (Oh no!).  That's where you come in - You're basically the Mars regional manager for a corporation trying to get a foothold on the planet, before the competition can woo the colonies away from you. PROSThis is fast-paced day trading coupled with supply chain management.  On Mars.  The sheer amount of stuff you can customize for each run (patents, optimization, contracting/hiring staff, etc.) allows for a myriad of strategies you can try against the different competition and conditions in each colony.  With campaigns, you have to plan and budget ahead of time for the future, because the competition gets starts to get fierce after you win several colonies.CONSA little pricy for what the gameplay actually is, which is basically a ledger and a map of resources to manage.  The graphics and sound are only a few rungs higher than what you'd expect on a mobile app.  Would recommend getting it on sale.SIMILAR GAMESI can't really think of any.  Factorio is more about the tactics and design of supply chain management and there isn't a market.

Posted: December 21, 2016
												Not worth over $30 considering all the content that's only accessible by buying the DLC. The options to select the content are built into the game menus but can only be picked if you pay an extra $30. I recently paid $20 for DLC for a free-to-play game with as much value and playability as OTC and felt like every dollar was worth it. These guys should include all that "DLC" for the price they charge for the game. OTC is a fun game for all skill levels. It has polished graphics and a dynamic economy. As mentioned elsewhere though, the games end far too quickly because opponents can buy each other out early. All of the game modes feel like this in some way. Whoever gets the early lead is likely to win while everyone else continues to play without a chance. That kills the fun a bit...Also the game uses long lessons instead of in-game prompts to teach you to play, so don't expect to turn it on an start playing right away.Now that the workshop is open, I'm sure a lot of cool mods are going to come out!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												It's fun with literally any number of players except 3.It's in the same vein as other economic hostile-takeover games like TTD but it's much faster-paced, so instead of a game taking days to complete, it's over in 20-30 minutes. This is a good thing. The time between "It's obvious who the winner is" and "The winner is declared" is very short. Games don't last very long after the first buyout, so if you're playing multiple rounds with friends, you won't have to sit out long.The basic premise is to acquire resources and sell them to get money to repeat the process. Resource prices change accordingly every time something is bought or sold, and there are various market manipulations that can be done. There's plenty of ways to mess with your opponent there, and you can buy usable-once-only sabotages for further shenanigans.It has its problems - the first buyout practically doubles your stock price, so in a 3-player game the first buyout determines the winner; the remaining player has a 0% chance of catching up and should just concede immediately. The Offworld Market is a necessary evil on Mars (as otherwise all resource prices drop to 1, but whoever has them is basically guaranteed to win) and utterly useless on Ceres (as all resource prices eventually become 1000). The AI is WAY too good at the game, as it makes no attempts to hide that it can and will react instantly to situations, inputting commands faster than any human possibly could.Overall though, it's an excellent strategy game that doesn't take nearly as long to play a round of compared to others in the genre. A good game to grab if you like economic games or quick strategies.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												I am absolutely horrible at this game. I don't think I've won anything outside of the tuturial missions, but while I don't play it much because of that, I can definitely recognise the amount of quality there is in this game.OTC is a RTS game, but instead of combat being the focus, it's economics. There is no military in this game, the game is built entirely around buying, producing and selling resources in order to become the best trading company on Mars. The economics, from my understanding, is easy to learn, hard to master. Essentially buying increases value, and selling decreases value, so the main layer of strategy in this game is balancing income, making sure you're not in too much debt, and keeping the economy stable. There's also the more questionable side of business, involving buying extra land off the black market, sabotaging competitors, and hacking the market to directly increase or decrease the value of goods.It's pretty hard, and I don't think I'll ever get how to play it well, but it's interesting and I would definitely recommend it to people who like RTS games, but want something with a unique twist.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ever since I was taken in by Race to Mars (you know what I'm talking about), I have been ultra-leary of Early Access Games.  I am glad that I broke my own rule and took the plunge with Offworld Trading Company.  For a game that isn't even touted as a Final Release version, it is amazingly well along.  I have played many games so far and have enjoyed them, even when I lost to the AI.  I have yet to try the multi-player, but this game has given me faith.  I tried to make a list of Pros & Cons but found it difficult.  The only Con I can really give this game is that it isn't done yet!  :P  Big thumbs up to the team behind this game.  I can't wait for the finished version and to the DLC I know is coming!  (hint hint, DLC in the future please!)I would advise investing in this game despite the Early Access tag.  Even if they stopped right now, its still WAY better than Race to Mars ever will be I fear.As a side note...I did wait until it was going for $20 USD instead of $40. As another side note:  I read some of the negative reviews (about 10% of them) and found that alot of people complained about 'shallowness', the Black Market and the AI's tendency to pile up money and buy you out.  I was perplexed by all of that.  The supposed shallowness allows for games that don't take an entire day of my life while allowing for a pace that kept me busy until the end.  If I want on 'in-depth' experience, I'll play Civ or something like that.The Black Market...nope, no problems with that either.  I like the fact that not only can I sabotage the competition, they can also do the same to me.  The costs increase not only when you use it, but when the AI uses it.  So if you can catch it, you can get an idea of the general plans of the competition.  Couple that with keeping an eye on Share Prices, it's not hard to figure out who just bought what.  And as for the AI buying you out...that's what it's supposed to do.  And if you have played correctly, you have made it hard for them to do so...which drives the tactic of storing up the $1 Million+ it will take.  The best business deals are the ones that surprise everyone else.  Why would that be any different here.

												Plenty of other reviewers have shared their two cents. I'll keep my review on the leaner side.If you enjoy fluid, real time, dynamic strategy games you should consider Offworld Trading Company. There are no invading forces, no armies, no tanks. It's a about cunning and guile. Trying to read the market, trying to manage your company while discerning your opponents strategy. Skirmish games can be over relatively quickly (under an hour) and usually leave you wanting more. This is a nice change of pace from a game like Civilization where even on the shorter end of the spectrum games will last 2-3 hours. That said, I do love the Civilization series, which is part of the reason why I purchased this game.In terms of learning curve - the game is easy to pick up, difficult to master. I say give it a go.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Offworld Trading Company is an intense economic macro-oreiented RTS. But don't be fooled by the lack of military units, the game won't be easy. There's a lot to manage, other players to worry about and futures to predict (or create). Those of you who've played M.U.L.E. will find this extremely familiar, but in real-time rather than the turn-based style of the original.The game itself is relatively simple to pick up, but there's a lot of depth and interacting complexity to master. You'll be deciding which resources to focus on, which buildings are cost inefficient, picking between the two research options, deciding whether to double short the or just to rush into Off World Markets, not to mention who to wreck with blackmarket tech and when.Of course, it's not perfect being that it's in Early Access, the UI needs polish, and I find the game can be sluggish at times, especially in the end game (though, that's likely my fault for running it at 1440p), but overall the game is ridiculously fun, and the core mechanics are extremely solid, and the multiplayer community is really strong and friendly (though, they may still wreck you at first, no hard feelings, of course). Absolutely worth picking up.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok,  as a disclaimer strategy games of any variety  I typically enjoy in some ways; that said I'm really fond of the angle they've taken here but... I'm not sure its remotely worth 40$. In todays day and age I understand inflation and general quality of life insists we pay more for our games but I simply don't understand why we pay 40$ for what should be, in its current state, a 20$ game.  I am all for early access even being burnt by df9 like others, I'm very inpatient but why not pay 20$ to have access to the alpha and a buy in of 10$ for the full game when your done and 35 for the person who didn't try it before release? games like planetary anhilation that set that alpha price to rediculous ammounts really dont want your feedback just your money.-rant over- The gameplay at this point is really unique , I liked it alot. I, like always, jumped right into the game campaign without doing the tutorial and got obliterated. repeatedly, something about the reasource grab in the begining can be very unforgiving. its definately more of an rts than those turnbased lovers of civ. That said I'd like to point out all 'popular' rts's tend to have a decent chunk of campaign to play through. I lowered the difficulty after a few losses and found myself beating it too easily but I was really intrigued by the sofar bare bone campaign so I figured I'd see what it was all about. Much to my disappointment that was it. after a few missions with no real plot or explanation of your conquests on mars you easily finish the campaign ina couple hours... praise the lord they arnt done developing. after a few missions you generaly get the idea of how to take the reigns, you quickly learn all the buildings and how to place them well; there doesnt seem to be quiet enough... even with 16 resources or w.e there was specialization was never really an option even on rare resource missions supply always exceeded demand  far to easily and demand never rose fast enough... I think there are some resource balancing tweeks to be done and alot to desire game wise but in its current state its VERY playable with only a few little bugs.  I want more; I will be watching this one.

												Great game. Id say its a cross between the Anno series (trading & management) and ticket-to-ride (short-round boardgames where you can manipulate opponents).The game revolves around being the last man standing.Build a few mines/farms/other structures and supply the local colony with goodsIf a rival is getting a bit too far ahead, sabotage them.Build various special buildings to manipulate prices or conduct research for patents or efficiency upgradesStart aquiring other company's shares and then buy them out (While ensuring you are not bought out!)The base game only has this single goal though, so the winner can seem obvious near the endEach round is reasonably quick though (maybe around 20-30 mins) so its not too badIf you get the deluxe edition from some sites (Not available directly via steam), you can get two steam keys!

Posted: October 15, 2016
												Offworld Trading Company plays like a bizarre cross between an RTS and a board game.  If you were to take the core mechanics and fashion them into a board game, you'd have a pretty good game.  But this?  It's not very good at all in my opinion.  The fact that the game plays out in real time doesn't mesh well with the game mechanics, and the UI is dreadful.  The tutorials are kind of odd, definitely too long, and they don't really teach you how to play the game.  It isn't difficult to understand how to play, but since there is no manual and this is a strategy game, it would have been nice to have tutorials that didn't suck.Though the time I spent playing this game was brief, it was unpleasant and I cannot recommend the game.

Early Access Review
								This is a fast paced and energetic RTS set in some not so distant future on the Mars.  Tha main thing I like is that "Offworld Trading Company" is the only modern competitive game I know which is not about killing people or other stuff. It's purely economical: one develops the company base, sells resourses and fight for the shares in other companies — buying out competition is the only way to the victory! Grafics are cute, performance is OK even on my 2013 Macbook Air, Early Access status is recognizable but makes only a little impact on overall gameplay.AI is fucused and unforgiving and while it's easy to jump in the game concepts then there are quite a few challenges on the way to perfection. All in all, if you like Civ's economics and ready to the demanding chess blitz tempo, please give this game a try!

content:
Posted: April 20
												Greetings!  This game is an odd one, a mix of strategy and business sense I definitely found some moments of glee as I trapped my opponent into bankruptcy and quickly bought all their shares. There was some enjoyment and ‘ah-ha’ moments, but is there longevity?  No, at least not for me.Those Bloody Robots:  In my two hours of play I encountered a few crashes, an odd bug that prevented me from playing (a red x appeared as my cursor and I couldn’t get it to go away and it wouldn’t let me exit the game) and disastrous frame rate (going as low as 5 fps).  I’m not sure if optimization is the problem or something else I didn’t see but this did not help my lack of enjoyment of the title.Class of its own:  This game is unique, no doubt about it, an odd mesh of verses with more traditional management style game and a dash of RTS.  Someone had a very specific idea for this game and I think they achieved it here.  There is something beautiful and unique here, you build a base like that of an RTS until you realize you have no tanks, no soldier.  Money and resources are your soldiers, they are used to slowly buy out your opponent or bury them in debt.  To be honest, I loved the notion, the execution isn’t bad either.  But it unfortunately didn’t take me long to get bored.Masterpiece of Engineering:  This game is well built (aside from the mentioned bug), from the factions to the environment and immersion.  Even the mechanics are well designed and developed, there really was a vision here but just like some abstract painting that some don’t get it I am left with the question:  Where is the fun?  I’m not saying this game isn’t fun, but it isn’t fun for me.  I get the concept, the pathing and the process.  I follow along and make the correct decisions but to me it feels more robotic, meticulous, almost like a job or a project to complete.  One of my friends watched me play for a bit and he said it was a ‘beautiful spreadsheet simulator’ and I feel that is kind of the point.  There is a game here and I’m sure it is fun.  I’d probably dump a few more hours into if it would stop crashing and bugging out on me but long term, no, I think even if the game worked perfectly I’d rather use my time for a more enjoyable game or something productive.  I hope I’m wrong for all of you out there and I hope you enjoy it!

								It's important to say when playing this game that we are talking the earliest days of early access so much isn't polished and there are a lot of niggles to iron out. But... this a truly original game with a lot of potential. Soren Johnsen is a great game designer and this could be a major new gameplay franchise. This game has the real potential to be next on the list of great Early Access games following from Kerbal and Prison Architect.

Early Access Review
								I'd say this game is quite good. So far as I can see from the negative reviews, they're mostly there because they expected a long strategy game like Civ, which it is not. This is quite a fast game comparitively and it notes in the trailer that most games are expected to be 30 minutes. I have mixed thoughts on the AI, as sometimes they make very stupid decisions, but to be fair most of the time they get it right. A lot of people are complaining that they quickly get bought out by the AI, but this is merely a strategy that is available in the game due to it's fast pace, and if you cannot deal with it then you should not be playing 30-40 minute RTS games, but rather something like Civ (Which is personally one of my favorite game series). The tutorials in this game are quite lacking, and they are basically just throwing you into the deep end, so some people may find it hard to pick up. Overall, I'd say that before you buy this game, realise it is fast and you can't get comfortable before you start taking action against other players.

content:

Early Access Review
								Even in alpha, this game is already excellent and challenging. Plus, there's so much more the develpers (and modders) could do with it. It has that rush RTS feel the entire game, with a great blend of strategy (choosing which resources to focus on, which research to do, which kind of ecomony to focus on, considering which faction you are) and tactics (black market sabotage, market manipulations, and selling/buying strategies). It may not look like it from the screenshots, but you feel like you're in constant combat with your opponents.Economic and market considtions are constantly changing based on the given map's resources and player/AI behavior; however, it doesn't change so fast that you can't find trends and predict how resource demand will change and make decisive, bold moves to crush opponents.I see a near-limitless potential for deep strategy, counter-strategy and evolving meta-strategies for this game. Extremely excited to see where this game goes!

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
Product received for free
												Offworld Trading Company is a rather interesting take on Real time strategy games. Instead of blowing up enemies with machine guns or explosives #Offworldtradingcompany takes a new look at things by using Economics!The game actually has a lot of content as well. My video is based on all of the DLC and honestly Im not sure where one DLC starts and another stops so Ill be talking as if you have all the DLC.The tutorial for offworld trading company shows you the basics then walks you through a set of scenarios with increasingly challenging computers. By the time you complete these challenges you should easily be able to jumpy right into the multiplayer side of things if thats your cup of tea.If not there is plenty to do vs the AI which is NO slouch! Skirmishes like any other RTS allow you to just jump in vs a certain number of opponents where your job is to out perform them financially with the end goal of buying out their business.There are a variety of resource gathering options, factorys that produce different luxury goods, devious blackmarket sabotage moves, and if all else fails access to an offworld market that you can launch missiles to exploit.Campaigns bring an interesting twist to the game. You get the core game with a twist in the rules the restricts who can do what. This forced specialization completely changes your focus. Also instead of straight buying out your opponents you must support a colony. The person who does the best on any given week gets a bonus for the following week. Make a few mistakes and your opponents can snowball. Once a certain week has passed you again have the ability to buy out your opponents like normal.There is also Daily scenarios very similar to binding of isaacs dailies. You are given a set scenario blindly, forced to adapt, and you are scored with eveyone else for that day. Quite a bit of blind competition the person who adapts quickly gets a better score and the leader board ensures bragging rights vs your friends or the world.Finally if playing against an AI bores you there is a rnaked multiplayer option.I ran out of time in my review but ranked and custom matches were both available. If you'd like a more indepth review here is my first impressions video!


YouTube™ Video: My Opinion On - Offworld Trading Company + DLC 

			Views: 650		

			My Opinion On - Offworld Trading Company + DLC We take a look at Offworld Trading Company today in our MOO! Big shoutout to Uncommon Hero for providing me the DLC for the game I was missing!

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												I really thought I was going to love this game, and I did, during the first couple of tutorial missions. I thought to myself "wow, this is amazing! I can't wait to colonize Mars! I'm going to spend hours and hours spreading across the planet!"Sadly, after the first couple of tutorials they start introducing mechanics that make the game less fun. Once you really get into the game, you're no longer focused on colonizing, because you get an extremely limited amount of buildings. Once they're built, you need to watch a little stock ticker and sell off your spare resources. You can't do it all at once though, because selling dips the price, so you need to pause the game every 30 seconds or so to do it. It gets really tedious.There's a goofy stock mechanic where you dump all of your extra money into your own stock (which doesn't seem to do much because people can and will still buy you out) and other people's stock, where you buy them out. If you get bought out (which can happen with no warning if you're not paying attention) it's instant game over.This is a well made game and I'm sure lots of people will find it's what they're interested in playing, but a 30 minute game of micromanaging silicon prices isn't what I want to play. Maybe that's my fault for not looking into what this was more thoroughly, but I can't think of anyone I would recommend this to.Weak thumbs down. Sorry game.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												Offworld Trading Company is an economic warfare based real time strategy game. That makes it quite an interesting take on the RTS genre. How does the 'warfare' work? Well, you and your competitors mine raw materials and produce goods - and sell it on the shared market. And if someone else has a building you don't want them to have, it may accidentally explode.. or you 'borrow' it for some time to win the race to one of the juicy patents (buffs only one player can have). In the end, you want to make money more quickly than the other people (and avoid debt!), in order to buyout their companies. And .. sometimes you may have to manipulate the market prices a tiny bit..So how does the strategy layer of OTC look it? Well, one important aspect is that space is limited. Every time you upgrade your HQ, you can claim some more (4-5) tiles on the map. These normally are tiles either next to your HQ or tiles with resources on it. Since (good) resources tiles are limited, you can create the situation where you nearly have a monopoly on a raw resource. And if everyone has to buy from you (via the market), you can make quite a profit by actively generating this situation. Doing so is tricky though, since at the start of the match, the map is covered with fog of war - and only when your HQ position is selected, the whole map is revealed. Might turn out that whole map is covered with silicon.. but there barely is any carbon! Time to change long term plans!Once you own a tile, its yours for the rest of the match. This is where good positioning and foresight comes into play, because whatever buildings you are going to use, those have to be on these limited tiles. Got those now-useless mines on the other end of the map? Well, just put factories there instead. However, transporting goods costs fuel, which requires water to make, which drives up prices and reduces profit. All producing buildings get adjacency bonuses (each +50% for 2 buildings, +75% for 3). So your first idea might be "well, get some mines in the middle of nowhere and a big cluster of tiles at my HQ to maximize adjacency". However, this leaves your production very vulnerable to area of effect sabotage by that dude that doesn't like you. Ouch. The market prices rise and drop depending on what all players do. This requires you to switch up production on the fly. You produced food? Well, turns out over the last minutes prices for the required water skyrocketed, so you don't make a profit anymore. Better replace those farms with something better. A classic example is that no one cares to produce energy in the early game (not profitable; not helping to upgrade HQ). This causes the energy prices to rise in the midgame, which you can actively abuse by then dumping energy on the market (while sabotaging everyone else who tries that). The game has four factions, each with a spin on how they work. -Expansionists get more claims and cheaper buildings, allowing them to be more flexible-Robots don't need life support supplies - and get adjacency not only for same type of buildings, but also if a supplier is next to a factory.-By the power of science, factories can use the resource tiles below them!-Real Scavengers don't use steel like everyone else, but use carbon - which allows them to pull off above play with energy production very effectively. Also they love sabotaging.So would I recommend the game? Like I said, I think it's a very interesting take on the RTS genre. It has a lovely soundtrack (Christopher Tin, aka Baba Yetu/Civ 4 Main Theme). I'm personally not sure about the 40 Eur price tag though.. ouch.. When it's on sale for 20, I would say pick it up. Since I can't comment on the multiplayer and its longevity and dynamic yet, I'm not sure whether I personally would give 30 for it. Then again, I'm a very conservative buyer.I honestly fear that the maximum strategic depth may be much shallower than say Starcraft (1!) or the Wargame series - but I think that can be expected, since market mechanics and its potential generally probably aren't fully explored yet. SC and WG are in their 4th+ iteration, in the more classic multiplayer RTS style and thus strategically much more refined. I'm very curious how they'll expand on this mechanic, though.

In the end, you want to make money more quickly than the other people (and avoid debt!), in order to buyout their companies. And .. sometimes you may have to manipulate the market prices a tiny bit..So how does the strategy layer of OTC look it? Well, one important aspect is that space is limited. Every time you upgrade your HQ, you can claim some more (4-5) tiles on the map. These normally are tiles either next to your HQ or tiles with resources on it. Since (good) resources tiles are limited, you can create the situation where you nearly have a monopoly on a raw resource. And if everyone has to buy from you (via the market), you can make quite a profit by actively generating this situation. Doing so is tricky though, since at the start of the match, the map is covered with fog of war - and only when your HQ position is selected, the whole map is revealed. Might turn out that whole map is covered with silicon.. but there barely is any carbon! Time to change long term plans!Once you own a tile, its yours for the rest of the match. This is where good positioning and foresight comes into play, because whatever buildings you are going to use, those have to be on these limited tiles. Got those now-useless mines on the other end of the map? Well, just put factories there instead. However, transporting goods costs fuel, which requires water to make, which drives up prices and reduces profit. All producing buildings get adjacency bonuses (each +50% for 2 buildings, +75% for 3). So your first idea might be "well, get some mines in the middle of nowhere and a big cluster of tiles at my HQ to maximize adjacency". However, this leaves your production very vulnerable to area of effect sabotage by that dude that doesn't like you. Ouch. The market prices rise and drop depending on what all players do. This requires you to switch up production on the fly. You produced food? Well, turns out over the last minutes prices for the required water skyrocketed, so you don't make a profit anymore. Better replace those farms with something better. A classic example is that no one cares to produce energy in the early game (not profitable; not helping to upgrade HQ). This causes the energy prices to rise in the midgame, which you can actively abuse by then dumping energy on the market (while sabotaging everyone else who tries that). The game has four factions, each with a spin on how they work. -Expansionists get more claims and cheaper buildings, allowing them to be more flexible-Robots don't need life support supplies - and get adjacency not only for same type of buildings, but also if a supplier is next to a factory.-By the power of science, factories can use the resource tiles below them!-Real Scavengers don't use steel like everyone else, but use carbon - which allows them to pull off above play with energy production very effectively. Also they love sabotaging.So would I recommend the game? Like I said, I think it's a very interesting take on the RTS genre. It has a lovely soundtrack (Christopher Tin, aka Baba Yetu/Civ 4 Main Theme). I'm personally not sure about the 40 Eur price tag though.. ouch.. When it's on sale for 20, I would say pick it up. Since I can't comment on the multiplayer and its longevity and dynamic yet, I'm not sure whether I personally would give 30 for it. Then again, I'm a very conservative buyer.I honestly fear that the maximum strategic depth may be much shallower than say Starcraft (1!) or the Wargame series - but I think that can be expected, since market mechanics and its potential generally probably aren't fully explored yet. SC and WG are in their 4th+ iteration, in the more classic multiplayer RTS style and thus strategically much more refined. I'm very curious how they'll expand on this mechanic, though.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been a RTS fan since the first warcraft game. Generally I favor the more military focused games like warcraft, starcraft, red alert, age of empires; so I was a little wary of giving this game a try. So glad I did.I really enjoy the pacing of this game. Yes, it can move quickly, but for the most part it doesn't require the twitch reflexes that starcraft 2 and other modern RTS games demand. For those who say this game is too shallow, I couldn't disagree any more. Yes, it's true there are less building options and tech trees to work with, but Offworld has more than enough to keep the game engaging. When dealing  with an ever-changing economy you don't need tiers of tech to have content that is hard to master.Mastery in this game is learning to predict your opponents' market schemes, adapting to the chaning economy, and knowing when to take risks in certain investments such as a new patent, claim or black market. While predicting, adapting and risk taking aren't new skills to the RTS genre, having to master them in a passive setting rather than an active go-attack-em setting makes for some new challenges that I've really enjoyed trying to learn.More Thoughts:It is true the tutorial could be a little more thorough, but after a couple of hours, you should be able to figure out the gist. This is just me, but I think the Black Market takes the fun out of the game. I'm sure with more experience I could make better use of the black market, but for now the cost/benefit ratio doesn't seem to justify any purchase except for the new claims.  My biggest beef with the black market is that it takes away from the game's best feature, a rts focused primarily on economy. With the black market enabled it can get really annoying when your production is stopped, especially because it doesn't really hurt you, it just slows the game down. Thankfully there is an option to disable the black market, which i've found myself doing on every game now.8/10

												Biggest surprise of the year so far. It is *almost* relaxing yet at the same time very tense when the market heats up! The soundtrack is fantastic. It is very satisfying to build a nice economic engine and there is just enough spite between players that you can't just do your own thing and ignore the other competitors... unless you build a real powerhouse that you can shrug off mutinies, saboatge.. erm.. incidents I mean, etc.  Nicely done, Mohawk. Who could have thought buying and selling could be so fun (capitalists all over the world scream in extasy).

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Offworld Trading Company is exactly the kind of game I want to see more of. It reminds me a bit of a resource based board game (Power Grid, etc.) but done in real time. A really nice blend of chin stroking strategy and frantic moment to moment tactics, all without guns and combat! There is dynamite though..There are some problems. The biggest issue by far is the abruptness that games end, at least in the default game mode. It's very possible to be humming along, building your successful empire, and then all of the sudden an opponent completely buys you out and bam, you lose. Uhh, ok.. gg?This comes down partially to the stock purchasing mechanic and partially to the UI being somewhat rudimentary. If the fact an opponent was about to buy you out was somehow *much* more visible maybe everything would be fine. As it stands there is no late game tension unless you know where to look for it. Compare this to combat based RTS games where its obvious your base is under attack and you are about to lose.This game /is/ in early access so I do have hope that the above problem can be addressed in some fashion. Until then, you do get used to if after a while.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Review for mac users:Offworld Trading Company (OTC) barely runs on my Macbook Pro Retina, despite my rigs' specs being well above the recommended. It runs so poorly that by the later tutorials (that's right, tutorials!), it turns into a slideshow, at low settings and 1440 resolution. We're talking isometric graphics here! The developers have ackowledged performance issues on Macs in the past, but the latest patch from June 2016 has not sorted that out, so I would strongly advise Mac owners to wait before purchasing this game until they see some clear indication these issues have been addressed. On the plus side, the little I have seen from the tutorials I have played looks indeed very interesting, with traditional resource-grabbing mechanics being nicely updated by the new trading setting (no direct confrontation besides sabotage and a bit of piracy), a nice variety of factions, and serviceable graphics. Obviously, I would need to be able to play at much more length before being able to talk about long-term playability...

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								In this game you are the CEO of a company that is trying to establish a foothold on Mars. You balance managing resources and growing your company with nuking your opponents mines, tampering with their water supply, and buying shares in their company with the ultimate goal of acquiring all of your competitors businesses. You buy and sell resources on the open market, and the price of goods is reflected by the supply from you and your competitors, their demand, the distribution of resources on the map, and the demands of the Martian colony.It's a very tense "economic RTS" from the designer of Civ IV. This is an RTS more about timings, resource management, and awareness than micromanagement. If you love the city building, economic portion of strategy games like Civilization, but you also like the cut-throat, edge of your seat action of games like Starcraft or Warcraft (but weren't always the best at managing hudndreds of units) then this game is amazing.There is a very distinct feel to every game, and I don't think I've ever played another game quite like this. I think it's a blast, and I can't wait to see where this game goes in the future.
