content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												With a unique and highly addictive concept the lead designer of Civ 4 (Soren Johnson) has made his own mark on the strategy & resource management genre. This Sci-fi base builder replaces the copy and paste idea of armies and units with varying buildings like hacker arrays (which artificially deflate and inflate price). Additionally units are replaced by an increasingly expensive black market to destroy, steal, and decrease production on competing companies.Offworld is a game that I love winning and still enjoy losing with a campaign and multiplayer ranked system the game overdelivers in game modes, and I HIGHLY recommend this to ANYONE that plays RTS and fast pased competetive games!

You can suddenly, and randomly lose the game, and there is no foolproof way to prevent it, nor a warning that it will happen, and once you have lost, you half to start over -- there is no save. Early Access Review
								If you're looking for a long drawn out "saga" then forget it as this is "wham-bam thank-you ma'am" stuff in comparison to Eve Online (mentioned in a Community thread) OK there's no attacking/ destroying apart from sabotage etc.Point and Click building style game and a "stock market" screen to buy sell on and that's the bones of the game.For me, there's no satisfaction playing this game at present, even when you do win, it's devoid, and lacking that certain something that gives you satisfaction when playing a game especially this one given its current state.Go read the Community threads and see for yourself. it has some good feedback and some real negative ones too.This game, for me, has potential and hopefully it will be vastly improved on over the coming months.Hopefully there will be a full planetary map available with a more sites to choose from as ice is only at the polar caps on Mars and so it seems daft to stick to the small maps you are given to play on at present, given the size of Mars.One major gripe is the on-screen text size with regards to game info, it would be nice if the text was more legible, as you could miss some relevant info about the game. I'll give it a 6-10 for now. Given that this game is being worked on and updated and improved on I can see this could be a good game and getting, hopefully, a good following but for now I'd give it a miss and wait. So I won't recommend it to people. For now that is.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								So, you came here most likely wondering: "Should i buy this early access game? Is worth it?" Well, the short answer to this is: "YES". I'll review some of the game features here and, if you're in a hurry, there is a tl;dr section at the end. What's the game?You're in charge of a trading colony on Mars and you compete with other companies to gain monopoly on the planet. It fits really nice with all the talks going on about an actual manned expedition to Mars. How to win?You have to buy stocks of the other players and gain control of their company. You win the game when you have bought all the other companies. If your own company gets bought, you instantly loose the game.What's the gameplay?You start off with a little cash and ressources (or none, there are options to set it before starting a game). You'll then have to build some buildings (like a mine or a steel mill) to harvest some ressources, be it iron or steel, etc. You can then transform these ressources into building materials or goods which you use or sell on a global market. All the players affect that market; if someone sells a lot of a product, its price is going to go down and, on the contrary, if someone buys a lot of a ressource, its price is going up for everybody.With the money and the ressources, you can expand your colony, buy some stocks or use the black market (i'll get back to it later). In order to build more, you'll need to spend some claims. Claims that allow you, and only you, to use a tile in the game. So, especially at the beggining of a game, the fastest to find and lay claims on ressources is most likely to have the better spots. Those claims are obtained by expending your HQ or bought on the black market. So, the twist of the game is, you'll be struggling with few claims and you'll have to prioritise what building you need. Are you going to try and be self-sufficient? Or maybe invest in a pricey ressource gathering infrastructure? That's the kind of questions you'll be dealing with most of the game.You HQ and your ressource transforming building will need some base ressources that you can mine yourself, or buy on the market (thus making it pricier). When you're lacking a ressource it increases your debt, which affect the value of your stocks. If your stocks are cheap, it's easier for other players to buy and you might loose the game. So watch that debt carefully.Is that it? A ressource harvesting/transforming game?Mostly, yes. There are some researches and upgrading you can do in the game, but you'll spend those hard-earned claims mostly on harvest/producing more. What's the blackmarket?You can't directly attack other players, at least in a classic RTS way. There are no soldiers and you can't steal a nice spot claimed, but you can affect their production with the help of some saboteurs available on the blackmarket. For some money, you can dynamite one of their building or launch an EMP that will freeze their buildings for sometime. Of course, you can also be the target of such attacks and, if you're not defended (with goons also from the blackmarket), you won't know who hit you.Of course, as it is the goal of the game, you can buy other players stocks and then win the game.Is it a good early access?Yes. I haven't add issues with the game crashing. It's working really well on my end and all the features are there. Of course, some elements are still to be updated. As an exemple, there are no dedicated servers provided for multiplayer games, making the game quit if the host leaves the game. Like in the good old days. But, for the rest, everything is there and you'll be able to enjoy all the mechanics.Any other notable feautres?A few. This game has a lot replayability, every map is random generated so no game is going to be like the previous one. A complete game lasts around 30-45 minutes, providing that you're the winner. A few options available before starting the game like a tighter debt or masquerade can add a little something to a game.There must be some downsides, no?Sure, but I would insist that they do not compromise the quality of the game mechanics. Except for the dedicated servers I spoke about earlier, the voiceover is actually horrible. You can't understand half and there is no clear logic in them (like, one faction gets a robotic male voice, then there is a female voice that speaks for them, no apparent reason why). Also, th UI might get a little more responsive, the buttons especially. Events are shown in a small text log on the right, but they should appear bigger since they can greatly affect your game (a shortage or surplus on a ressource can be a random event that will influence the price of said ressources, for exemple).And the price, for about 500mo of game, not that nice graphics and all, is a bit high. But, in my opinion, it is worth it. TL;DRPros: Great gameplay mechanics Actual subject Excellent replayability Fun multiplayer Indirect attacks with blackmarket Out of the box strategy gameCons: Voiceover No dedicated servers PriceIn the end: really great game that will get you an alternative RTS we don't see much these days. If you like strategy games, wargames and ressource management games: this is for you. I recommend it without any doubt. 9,5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								OTC is an interesting concept. Right now I do find it enjoyable and I look forward to the addition of leagues and ladders. Gameplay is already quite polished and it looks nice. It's an interesting take on the RTS genre and I would love to see more games like this.If I could select one change off the bat, it would be more market information and more dynamic markets. Right now the only truly dynamic resources is energy. Global prices are, it seems, driven by either player stockpile purchases or running deficits, which someone else could capitalize on. I'd like to see the markets function by net contribution and less stockpile driven, so rather than attempting to accumulate valuable goods and selling them off in bulk to buyout opponents have running market contribution. There seems to be a bit too much "random invisible supply and demand we dont know" driving market function. Giving us some idea of ambient demand and supply balance or even "global stockpile" that determines pricing would be nice, and then introducing exogenous price shocks to randomly shift market prices would be cool too. Something to give the pricing a bit more depth. Similarly, the share ownership function could also gain more depth, giving extra utility to ownership would be quite interesting. Defensive ownership blocks provide no real benefit if you're behind, and spending that cash on buying yourself only means you can't spend it on further expansion which I could see leading to increasingly snowbally gameplay. It seems like it would always be better to build ownership blocks in other companies. Finally adding more depth to the debt system would be quite cool. Right now debt seems like it works primarily as a death spiral - if you don't get your basic resources up and running you just enter a fixed debt growth and unless market prices (which we dont know enough about) swing your way you won't be able to get yourself out of it. Allowing players to manually take on debt in order to boost their economy would be a nice idea. None-the-less its an interesting and enjoyable game on to play on early access release which is a rare find, and with additional work it could become a genuinely deep and interesting competitive game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												Offworld Trading Company is easily the most exciting new real time stategy game I've played in years. I haven’t had as much fun as this playing a new game since the original version of Starcraft came out over 15 years agoIt's seems to combine the fast-paced gameplay style of Starcraft, with the strategic ups and downs of a game of settlers of Catan (including hexagonal tile grid!), all set on a futuristic Martian landscape with cool background music and sound effects. In Offworld you aren't directly attacking other players, rather you are competing with them to make the most money. Therefore you aren't susceptible to the plethora of cheap rushing strategies that seem to plague military-based RTS games. (such as zergling rushes in Starcraft)The single player campaign is pretty basic, although with the developers allowing the ability to mod the game there is a huge scope for different game modes and challenges to be worked on. Daily challenge mode is currently available for those too nervous to test themselves head-head to online.However it is the multiplayer of Offworld that is one of the most intense, engaging and challenging of any RTS I've played.The action in a multiplayer game starts immediately with an initial frantic rush to grab what you think is the best spot for your base. This is analagous to the start of a game of settlers (the board game version) on steroids, where you literally have about 15 seconds to weigh everything up as the debt counter plummets, before placing your building and getting started. If you are too finicky in deciding the absolute perfect spot, you will often be punished by an opponent taking that spot just as you go to click on it. This puts you on the backfoot immediately, unless you've already planned a back-up spot to land. There are so many variables to weight up simultaneously, in so little time, that even top players can get caught out at this early stage. Is there one large deposit of carbon that would be ideal for a scavenger base? If so, do you think your opponent has spotted it and how long do you think you can afford to wait for the initial debt level to come down before you grab it (hopefully before your opponent). Is there only one small area of silicon on the map that if you can monopolise you will effectively win the mid to endgame by hacking the prices of silicon, glass or electronics up and your opponents will be powerless as they watch you rake in the cash and buy them out. Or maybe the map has barely any water, in which case you plunk your robotic headquarters over that one little oasis, destroying most of it in the process, and slowly sell the remaining water to your opponents at an exhorbidant price. The gameplay is fast-paced, engaging and always full of surprises. It appears to be extremely well-balanced between the 4 factions, with very few strategies that are obviously nerfed. In the midgame you have the choice between 5 advanced buildings which can have a dramatic effect on gameplay depending on which you choose to invest in. I'd recommend this game to pretty much anyone. Go Offworld!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												This game can be a serious challenge. But unlike other difficult games, this one will not turn you off.PROS: You got to place structures. That's fun, right? I'm not being sarcastic. I mean this. You can choose where to place them (with certain rules of course). Whether it's a combat RTS or an economic one like this, doesn't matter; how often do you get to do that these days? There's a very subtle Sim City feel beneath the surface, which someone of my age appreciates.Smart play is rewarded.It requires you to think. Yes, this is a PRO.It was developed by a man who was an important piece of the Civ III and Civ IV team (say what you will about IV, but I'm one of the IV lovers, and III was fantastic).CONS:While billed as an economic simulator (and it is, that's not a fib) the Black Market mechanic I feel is a bit overused, and makes it seem like a low-key combat type RTS as a secondary. I wouldn't mind doing without it.Learning curve. But don't let that scare you away. If you like to use the Steam discussions forum, there's very little response going on from players, and the few who are regulars can get a little... bothersome sometimes. (But as a PRO, the man behind the game itself responds in the forums!)In general, I am very pleased with this game. It might seem boring and too casual on the surface, but believe me, once you play it, you will see how exciting and tense things can get. Watch as you lose shares in your business! That's a big deal! Better secure your shares! Buy in to the competitors! But how? What can you produce for a profit? What can you ship? What can you take the hit on for having to purchase? You better decide what you can produce and what you have to buy, because if you try to do it all, you WILL FAIL. I give it a 7/10. 8s with me are rare, 9s rarer still and the day I give a game a 10 that's been produced after the golden age of PC gaming is the day Hell freezes over, so my 7 means a lot more than you think.My number 1 tip: Do not give up. Do not get frustrated. Accept when you screw up. There's always something to learn.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Refunded...A cool premise destroyed by a plethora of bad design decisions.  (this all mostly about MP, it fairs slightly better in SP)1) there is NO need for this to be RTS instead of turn-based... in any way, shape or form.  it has ALL the problems every other RTS game has... as far as MP is concerned, it just comes down to who clicks a little faster...2) repetitive - you can not enjoy the mechanics of the game or take them in, AGAIN, because it is an RTS instead of turn-based.  You spend the entire game furiously putting down buildings withut being able to take a step back and make strategic decisions or view your opponents moves... this is ALL you do...3) a horrific tutorial that tells you all of nothing...4) MP games last like 30 minutes... dont know ONE gamer who wants their strategy game, whether it be RTS or TB, to be that short.... not one.5) Feature-wise, it is a $14.99 - $19.99 games, tops.For me, a massive let down.  What bothers me the most, is that all of this could have been avoided with intelligent design decisions.  It is a GREAT premise and eventually someone else will clone this game and do it right... and it will be a massive success.  I suggest waiting for that to happen.  Soren shot himself in the foot here.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Basic RTS game except you can only build buildings. After dropping an HQ building down you can then put down resource collection and/or processing buildings. Once you build something you're stuck with that tile, so if you later decide you want to build something else you can't move to construct to another tile. Like simcity the game features random events, most of the time they are beneficial like a solar flare increases the power production of solar panels. Other times resource shortages or excesses cause price fluctuations. some events don't make sense like the random auction for a tile no one has built on. Game play basically boils down to finding the rarest resource on the map before anyone else, while tring to not get screwed by the overpowered almost infinite blackmarket attacks from the AI.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												I put in my time with this game and really enjoyed the tutorial missions. However, once you try against bots higher than "newbie" level, the game becomes impossible. This game also fails to be about economic competition, really. You are very handicapped in the information available to you so you can't really read the markets or predict other player's stances. The most powerful competitive edge given players in this game are special attacks you purchase from the black market. With these you can freeze their structures, blow them up, take them over, etc. That's where the most manipulation comes in. The game is really about breaking even then using sabotage to get the advantage. I wanted to like this game but now I despise it. There also should be a turn based mode to remove the "i can micro better than you" element that so many RTS games have. There's no reason why this couldn't be a fun turn based game it's set up perfectly for it.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a fan of RTS game, Offworld Trading Company has definitely been a refresher for me. It feels very different from the conventional RTS (examples: StarCraft, CnC), but it still plays very solidly as a game in the genre. While it may feel bland at first to know that there is no martial combat aspect in the game, it compensates for that empty space very quickly by bringing pressures in macro decisions. As the name of the game suggests, this game puts you in the position of a decision maker for a trading company on Mars, with range of actions from claiming different plots of land on Mars and trading the goods, to tampering the markets to your advantage (or your opponent's disadvantage). Your goal is to buy out all of your opponents and become the monopoly on Mars's resources.The game is fully focused on macromanagement, which may make the game feel a bit slow. However, that does not mean that it is not exciting. Game gives you a lot of options with very limited number that you can actually choose, so you have to really plan a bit ahead on how you are going to work things out. As time progresses, your choices grow, but you will see that you will constantly be hassled by your opponents and may start facing the danger of being bought out. Your only friends will be your wits and your guts, as you make your own moves to press down your opponents and take control of what they own once and for all.While the game is enjoyable in many aspect, I feel that the snowballing effect may become an issue as people become more familiar to the game mechanics. I guess that will be another thing that will be countered, either by evolution of player strategy or developer intervention. I am just bringing out the possibility.Overall, I would give this game a 9.5/10. Half point off for not enough music. =D

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very nice RTS. The only RTS I'm playing now (so I finally abandon AoE and Rise of Nation). So i think the idea worth the price (I've bought it on sale, though). The realisation as well is expensive (good AI, stable code). So I was surprised to see just "mostly positive" as a summary of user reviews. I really want this game to be fully published.Point by point:1. No blood. You do not have to rise and command an army. Still, you are able to be offensive and there are plenty of things you do have to command.2. True fast-paced RTS - you can limit your gaming time to one round - to 30-50 minutes. You do not have to do low-level micromanagment, you have to be fast as well as smart. However, there are meditating moments as well.3. Very original. I had to spend an hour just to learn what are the rules. And these are very interesting rules. There are simularities with Civilization (and Catan as well). Still, this is something new for me. Basically, you have to buy opponents' companies. There are different strategic decisions you have to do - which type of base to build, whether to invest or not into intellectual property (patents), wich materials you have to mine, which you are able to buy in the market, which type of energy to choose, do you want to use lending or not. There is a lot of tactics here as well. So.. The rules are balanced and there is a lot to master here. However, they still tune the balance so you might find one day that the game had changed and you have to adopt.4. The rules are tunebale. So you can turn off some of the things people are complaining about in other comments and make the game more balanced and make the "rush" stratagy more hard to implement.5. The AI is strong. So offline is challenging as well. Looks like there is online option - never tried that.6. Nice GUI, music and animations. No crashes - high level of coding for early access.So if you enjoy economic part in RTS games or if you enjoy both RTS and Civilization-like games, you defenitely should try this one. This is a new kind of experience.

content:
Posted: March 26
												This is a fairly different game, and good.There are a lot of considerations with what the impacts of where things are and what pressures that places on supply/demands.Being close to resources means you will consume less fuel and get the production up faster, for example. If you're collecting resources from far away, you might be paying a lot for fuel. Maybe you decide to make your own fuel, which takes up water and power, but then you'd end up paying for power or have to make power. If you decide to make the power too, is there room left for a profit? Maybe you were better off paying the price and taking on debt. There are similar scenarios to this with building resources, but it's not immediately apparent what the impact of what you're doing on the market actually is. It's easy to look at the $ price of net in/out and say "okay this farm will cost me $1500" but it's also putting upwards pressure on construction resources, so if you decided not to go into construction resources, those prices go up. You get production boni for having the same resource production adjacent to each other, so you want to concentrate on a few resources initially, and diversify a little later.There's also the impact of patents (technologies that only one player can get, whoever makes it there first) which can change the game a lot, auctions (where you can take on debt to get a quick bonus), and the black market (the only direct player-player interaction is here). There's also hacking and optimizations, which are straightforward and another player-controlled element that places pressures on market prices (if you produce more of something, the price goes down, and is that really something you want? But if it's something you consume and don't create, maybe it is - but that might encourage others to buy the raw resources and compete in the refined goods you're creating).Patents have the potential to completely change the market (if that person shipping all the resources across the map gets teleportation, the fuel market might crash, and if that's a primary moneymaker for you, then maybe you better take off the market)Black market effects are various things, which usually have something that negatively (or positively) impacts production in an area - which directly goes back to that clustering that the adjacency production bonuses impact - do you hedge a little and spread production a bit so that shutting down all your stuff is less damaging? An interesting one - if you use adrenaline boost, which doubles production of your buildings in an area, also doubles consumption, so you might want to stock up on inputs before using it because your rivals might cut off your supply of the input when you use it.The game has more subtleties than most basically anything else played in realtime, and is a very interesting take on RTS as opposed to the smash armies at each other approach that every other game in the genre does.I haven't bothered with the multiplayer, but I can see it being a very good multiplayer game.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								The best market based RTS I've every played. Of course it's the only market RTS I've every played, but that just makes it unique. The best I can describe it is a mix between Civilization and Starcraft. The current state of the single player is okay. However the multiplayer is superb. The extreme competition of trying to buyout the other players has all the thrills of a Star Craft match, without the need for twitch reflexes. This provides a very different experience from other games. Scratching an itch I didn't know I had. I would suggest getting it for the multiplayer alone. In particularly, it makes  a good LAN/group party game. There's nothing quite like gaining a monopoly on a resource and price gauging your friends.

								This game is all about multiplayer. The basics are quite simple, but still offer a lot of variation when combined. The length of games (usually 30 minutes or less) feels perfect for good MP fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game was a huge surprise in 2 ways...1. It plays different than i thought. (even after watching videos)2. It's ALOT of fun if you dig into it.It doesnt play like i "thought" it would play after watching the videos... yes you have to stare at numbers and if you're not into trading games maybe you should just keep walking and give this one a pass. But the game is just so much fun nevertheless, i had teethgrinding moments against the CPU in the very original campaign (which isn't really a campaign, it's more a series of skirmish maps to see who's coming out on top). Which is everytime different so the replay value is already immense.I also thought it's going to be a bit on the dull side since it's a peacefull game. But the oposite is true, you can sabotage your enemy in many ways that you only start to understand a couple of hours into the game and you're constantly on the verge of an economic breakdown. If you understand what's going on on the market and understand the enemies base you can cripple him where it hurts the most.Your enemy just bought patents so all his energy comes from waterpower ? Let's have pirates camping his watersupplyroutes, or even better nuke away his shiny Waterdepot...There's alot to do constantly and the game revolves in a very fun way. If you play aggressive as in sabotaging your enemy constantly you will be on the map alot to find out what your enemy is planning to do before you can do it to him.I have not found any bugs yet and it's hardly noticable that this is an early access title at all.The game is obviously in early access but it works already really good, so if you like economic games with a little twist you should give this one a go and stick to it. It's surprisingly good.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								1-Hour, First Impressions, Early Access, ReviewA good, fast-pased but relativley relaxing economy game.In it's current state, this game litterally throws you into the deep(ish) end. Non-intuitive game mechanics and lack of any true and thorough tutorial makes searching up a guide on build orders and tips almost essential. To give you an idea of the situation; I failed the first tutorial twice because it's not clear, nor does it explain that you have a "claim" limit. (more on this later)Once the surface is scratched, and mechanics are better understood, the game becomes much better. Many things in the game will appeal to fans of mass, streaming-economy RTSs. Real-time indirect agression against the enemy player is very remeniscent of other games such a Sid Mier's "Trains".The game can be very punishing towards mistakes made, a single wrong move in the early-mid game can spell disaster for your company. One such example is the "claims" mechanic, which gives you a limit on the number of tiles you can take before progressing. Take the wrong tile, and even if you remove the building there, you cannot unclaim it, leaving you with an incorrect, useless tile for the rest of the game.Despite it's unforgiving nature, Offworld Trading Company is already (despite being early access) an excellent game with great potential for hours of fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is very challenging to play and currently has a pretty steep learning curve, but it is a really engaging experience. It is interesting how it deals with financial takeover of your opponents (through buying out their stock) as the win condition. I'm not sure I've played another game that used a mechanic quite like that. As I've learned how to play, I've slowly been increasing the AI difficulty and the game has remained fun and addicting. I haven't tried online multiplayer yet, but will probably play against some friends once I've got the strategies down a little better.At the time of my review, the game was early access, and it feels like a finished experience. I'd say the most work could still be needed in the tutorials as they were not the most friendly to learn what to do. I had to checkout some developer video tutorials online to really get the hang of the later (and harder) tutorial levels.I definitely recommend this game though if you are looking for an interesting twist on the old real time strategy / resource management game type. They are doing a lot of cool things with this!

content:

								I waited for a good discount before I bought OTC. That's what the reading the market is all about, right? Now I'm a very satisfied customer. I like the idea of economic domination of Mars. Of course the big money comes from shipping resources  back to the earth. It took me many days to get into the league where the big boys are playing. Or maybe I'm not there yet, but I've certainly gained more insight in the past few days from playing and taking notes how the good players are playing.Even though the game is still in beta, it feels like a finished product. Some people say that Mohawk hasn't added enough content, but I think that's what this game is all about. Finding the best stratety with the tools you've been given. And yeah, Soren Johnson, the brain behind this game was heavily involved with Civ IV, so you can't go wrong with getting this game.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a RTS. And it's about economics. It's fast. So it's not quite high frequency trading yet, but close. This is about actions per seconds. Not round based empire building. I bought it during the sale for 18 EUR and refunded it after playing for 1½h (a 2h run time limit is just too short in that case, should be also 2 weeks in my opinion).It's okay for what it is, it's just not what I expected to be. For a RTS there are just too many things happening at once in different places other than the map, the most deceiving part that the screen space would be better used for fullscreen info overload and stock charts for each resource. The map itself turns out to be not that important since besides adjacent boosts, the location on the map seems to have little importance. Also would have liked it more, if prospecting played a bigger role.The whole claim and HQ upgrade process just kinds of breaks the flow for me. I really would have liked to like it, but I don't see this evolving into fun for me any time soon.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								A solid game that breaks away from the normal RTS collect 1-2 resources and then send your army over to the enemy to kill their workers because that hurts them the most. In this game you're tasked with laying out a plan to develop your resources in a solid production line. Against the AI you don't have to deal with many hiccups, but unlike what the negative reviews have said about 0 depth, when you get in to multiplayer skirmishes you've now got to build efficiently, and take in to account what they might do to you.For instance, there are 4 factions, each different than the other, if you can keep in mind the resources that each needs, you can punish your opponents my stealing them, or stealing their building, but this may leave you open to similar attacks. Then further from that you have to manage your debt, you might have a short term victory, but if they cripple you at the right time, they can send you spiraling in to debt which will stop you from further attacks or defense tactics.So, to those who wrote "0 depth", try winning some multiplayer matches.The pros:- One of the most intelligent queueing systems I've seen, you can practice against the AI while waiting for a 1v1 skirmish, and it saves your game, so next time you're in queue, you can pick up against the AI where you left off.!!- Varied gameplay because resources change and other players playstyles and decisions change per match.- A unique (afaik) game style that focuses more on the resource management side of RTS rather than militaristic side.The cons:- Fewer than I'd like number of players online at any given time, this can make finding matches a headache, and yes playing against the AI becomes less and less satisfying.- If you want to play a match unveiled like a normal multiplayer 1v1 against the AI, you have to start it outside the queueing system, but  from the tooltip it looks like this will change, so it could be an Early Access temporary con.- No queues other than 1v1, (Missing 2v2, 3v3, 4v4, or FFA queues)Compared to many early access games this game is quite polished, I feel like this is how early access SHOULD work, you've got the solid core game, but the blemishes are showing.Neutral things I attribute to early access:-- Lack of player base (Steam Early Access has burned a lot of people)- Voices are mostly Google reader sounding things, except the director who says "Uhhh, your stock is being sold" :)- Other mapsTL:DRIt's a solid game, great gameplay, replayability if you're in to multiplayer. It's early access, and behaves like one. Implemented the gameplay first, now it puts on the polish.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								A virtual economy where you create things; sell things; and buy out your competitors. So heres the crazy thing: Its shockingly complexFirst; the AI.the AI knows what its doing but it doesn't seem to want to over-saturate the economy as I'm so keen on doing. Dunno if that was intentional but if you can make a product not at all worth the actual product; it makes it harder for them to earn the money needed to buy your stocks. Second; the black marketIt would be hilarious to blow up someone's mine on a skype call; but otherwise you can basically shake it off. They never really get you to a choking point. Pirates kept stealing really pathetic amounts of water from me, for example (about 30-50 water a minute or so) and it didn't even matter because my production supported beyond that. The worst ones are the magnet storm and emp. The rest (save for nukes which I always buy just to get it out of the game if its being auctioned) doesn't even matter. If you are producing and you're staying afloat; go ahead and laugh. Otherwise its a minor inconvenince.Third; the economy itselfIt's a simple Supply/Demand type thing and is constantly checking itself and I love that. Things feel as if they have value despite being totally meaningless just like in real life.Forth; gameplayThe game is smoothish on my laptop and is graphically pleasing. Its in early access but that's not going to excuse anything. A mine looks a mine and a transport looks like a transport. Each faction looks very different from each other.Fifth; the 'realisim'Each faction has its own voice; but is as well quite robotic. Think Hal 9000 but just slightly less human sounding. Its a bit hard to put into words. the Robotic faction sounds like a male GPS voice, the scavenger faction sounds like a british robot, expansive sounds like a female GPS voice, and so on. Each mine reproduces whatever item its tile says and each tiles material stacks (0-3 but 0 is just a blank tile) and the amount of stuff that exists keeps it interestingMy biggest issue is the games one limiting factor; claim titles. all tiles on the game are fair game but you can only grab x amount of until you level up your hq (up to level 5 and that comes quickly; trust me) And, if you place something down by mistkae; and so you go to destroy whatever you placed on it; well you just wasted material. That tile is yours son. Congrats. Didn't need that carbon? Too bad.  The only way to get rid of a tile is to auction it and the game never actually tells you how to auction things. It just introduces it maybe 10 mins into one of the tutorial missions. Never tells you how; just lets you particpate.My other issue is how the game handles debt. You got two big numbers; the current money you have, and a possible accurued debt. The idea, of course, is to not need to buy things, and if you need to, rather than subtracting it from your current cash; it just created debt that you can pay off whenever you feel like. While that's nice it doesn't feel like a negative. Its not pressing.The game doesn't remind you of the hole you're digging for yourself; it just points it out with a red number and that's it. Each new day it'll go up by x percentage but what does it matter? The only real negative is you don't make any profits (all profits made through like, selling power is funneled to your debt rather than your cash pool) but you can still make money by selling materials; and you can then pay the debt back 1k per click.But why when I don't feel the need to because nothing bad happens.I don't feel punished by the growing red number and I feel that might be an issue.7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great game! I managed to get 3 hrs of gameplay out of just the tutorials, without doing any multiplayer or campaign mode. So that to me is a great start. The graphics are pretty and the interface is really easy to use. For an Early Access game its suprisingly complete and polished. Unfortunately I did encounter some graphical issues, but I feel that is more because my computer is at the low end of the (mac) system requirements, and not because of the game. The whole game just slowed to a lag fest by the end of tutorial 4 and 5 (so much is going on, onscreen), and the text was fairly unreadable in some areas from the start. Changing the settings didn't help much and made it worse at one point. So if you are reading this for opinions on tech specs, note that game is pretty resource intensive (pun not intended) so you might want to check your system requirements are closer to the recommended than the minimum.That said, I still recommend the game! Its a great resource management game, and if you like that kind of game you will love this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								I enjoyed this game. The UI was a little puzzling at first, but eventually with the help of the tutorials I figured it out and went on to play campaign games. The game sessions themselves last 20-25 minutes, and 8 of them strung together make a campaign, so you can finish a campaign in a couple of hours.If there's a downside to the game, it's that once you're done with Mars, you're done. The game model cries out for an asteroid campaign, a europa campaign, and so on. I also think a longer campaign model with more objectives would make good use of the persistant personnel you can buy in campaign mode and help you make a more custom faction.I'd say this game is worth $10-15 US dollars.

												Well I am very much a newbie as I only have 14 hours of game time so far but it is thoroughly. It's a real time trading game. So it was the RTS feel without unit micro. I've watched several videos of Soren and the top level players and if you want to do well you have to micro the resources you are collecting and making but unlike a traditional RTS these don't move around. Makes it a more enjoyable game to me. Anyway, I would recommend this game to others. I have been enjoying it.

												This game is so brilliant I am dumbfounded. If you like to read your enemies this is for you. I would with out qualm recommend this game. The game is based around the ideal that you will be able to turn a profit in a highly intense and tightly planned situation. I have played in the November Tournament and it was great fun! The real show begins when you start to use the multiplayer potion of the game. Please do not get me wrong, the AI is pretty good but the Player on Player engament is very well done! Without reservation this is a 5 of 5 kinda game!

								Neat game!Intersting approach to RTS. There definitely is combat, in a indirect way through the Black Market. The meat of the game is analyzing and exploiting market trends in real time. There are a lot of elements from Sid Meier's Railroads, which is much more visually friendly than this game.This game's AI is quite difficult. I was not able to beat the later tutorial missions. There is a LOT going on, and a lot of it seems hidden from the player.The game definitely feels like it needs polish, but that is what Early Access is really all about, so I am not too concerned there. Currently the UI is extremly laggy and the game itself feels very sluggish, unoptmized on a technical level.I will probably update this review after I play more.UPDATE:After just a couple of days ther ehave already been two patches that address balance and performance issues! Pretty good show from Mohawk games, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a RTS. And it's about economics. It's fast. So it's not quite high frequency trading yet, but close. This is about actions per seconds. Not round based empire building. I bought it during the sale for 18 EUR and refunded it after playing for 1½h (a 2h run time limit is just too short in that case, should be also 2 weeks in my opinion).It's okay for what it is, it's just not what I expected to be. For a RTS there are just too many things happening at once in different places other than the map, the most deceiving part that the screen space would be better used for fullscreen info overload and stock charts for each resource. The map itself turns out to be not that important since besides adjacent boosts, the location on the map seems to have little importance. Also would have liked it more, if prospecting played a bigger role.The whole claim and HQ upgrade process just kinds of breaks the flow for me. I really would have liked to like it, but I don't see this evolving into fun for me any time soon.

content:
Posted: February 17
												Still learning the game, here is what I think could be cool to add though. 4 new sectors:1) Merchant Banks. Provide 3 services to the economy.I.	Market makers. That is they buy and sell commodities from the Mines and try to be first in line in competition with other merchant banks, speculating on the price of the commodities’. II.	Bond Speculators. That is they buy corporate bonds from the corporations looking to secure more finance in exchange for an annuity / interest payment, then sell the bonds to investors at a retail volume with a small margin. If the price of the bond looks like good value in comparison to the yield and maturity value investors buy, but if the corporation hits difficult times the high risk (junk bond) falls in price but the interest rate goes up. III.	Venture Capital. That is investing seed capital into startups and IPOing them after they are established.2) Insurance Firms. Provide 2 services to the economy. I.	Collects premiums in exchange for a lump sum payment in the event of damage of PP&E. II.	Sells Corporate Bond Default insurance to banks. a.k.a. Collects premiums from Merchant Banks in exchange for a lump sum payment in the event the debtor forfeits on his/her obligations. 3) Logistics Corporation. Provides 1 service to the economy. ( I know this is not a Mars version of Port Royal 2… but why not? It could be the best space version of a Shipping company game). I.	We see the little cargo ships appearing from the mine and going to the factory but who do they belong to??? Could you own and operate a fleet of cargo ships.4) Wholesaler Retailer. (Still on the Port Royal 2 theme)I.	In some ways similar to Market Maker but with a Wholesale Retail + Inventory management + competitive pricing + Marketing and Advertising Budget to win market share at the colony spin added. 5) Private Security Contractors. (What’s a shipping game without privateers and pirates?)I.	Secure Tender contracts to patrol corporations propertyII.	Escort Cargo shipsIII.	Join the dark side, be hired to raid competitor corporations and sell anything you can salvage on the black market.IV.	Intercept competitors cargo ships, throwing their supply chain out of whack (if they are operating on a JIT system of inventory management) and sell the commodities on the black market.Just a few ideas.

												Offworld Trading Company is a fast speed game where every little action and timing counts and will decide if you get owned or not. The positive side is that the way the game is conceived (A single HQ and 5 levels maximum) allow to play great online multiplayer games, an aspect completely boring or unexistant on more slow pace games.Knowing that, I think Offworld is a great addition to your library !

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												The game looks neat... but that's about it. Don't get me wrong it has a unique game style, and it is pretty fun for a few to a couple of hours, but not more than that.GAME INFO- Unlike other RTS games, where the player builds and gather resources to buy armies. Offworld Trading Company is mostly about economic RTS. The player has to claim certain lands, which consist of natural resources, and manage those resources by buying and selling on the market. Each player has a share in the stock market and the prices for the stocks will range on how well the players are doing (The better income the higher the stock price will be). There are special abilities that the players can buy from the Black Market and interfere the progress of other players (I will not give the details but players need to buy this abilities to help win the game). Whoever buys all the stocks wins the game.. and that's, that is how to win the game. It Sounds complicated but it is not. You get the hang of it when playing the game for a couple of hour, but that's the problem. When you start to understand the mechanics of the game it gets boring because the game itself feels very... linear unlike other RTS games. Most RTS you have to strategize your moves and attacks to win the game, and there are so many ways and routes to plan and play which makes you hooked to it for days, months, even years. However, Offworld trading company has limited strategic gameplay... you just manage your resources in the best way to make you profit.MY OPINION-+Fun game :D for couple of hours. -After that not fun :(+If you are into this type of game go for it.-If you are not into this game don't buy it because you will regret it when the game is sitting in your library for years and realize that you had only 20 hrs+ or less of in-game.+Why did I buy the game? Because of Quill18.+Why did I thumbs up? I had fun even though it was for a couple of hours, and I recommend this game for those who are into Economic RTS. -But it is too expensive... So +I recommend this game when the price is low and those who are into this game:p

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												So far, I like the game concept and the strategic element.  However, I can't even get past the tutorials due to the fact that the game keeps crashing at random times for no apparent reason.  Yes, in the tutorials.  My rig exceeds all minimum requirements, and most of the recommended ones.  I've played the game for less than 90 minutes, and in that time it has crashed 9 times, sometimes being ok for 25 minutes at a time, other times crashing within 2 minutes.I really do think the game has potential, and if you can get it to run without experiencing this bewildering instability (one of my friends has no problems at all), I'd recommend it for sure, especially if it's on sale.  As for me, I have no choice but to wait and see if the devs can patch the stability problems.  If not, I'll have to get a refund -- who can play a game that crashes every few minutes, especially one that has obvious multiplayer intentions?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Short version, I liked this game.Longer version;At 5 hours of play I loved this game.At 10 hours of play I thought this game rocked all out.At 15 hours of play I was wanting more.At 20 hours of play I probably wont play this game very much anymore.Offworld Trading Company is an excellently balanced economic/base building/strategy game.  But in some ways it is too well balanced in that while there are 4 different styles of play based on the base you choose, those 4 different styles of play have very little opportunity for variation within themselves.Even on the mid-range difficulty levels I found that you had to play a particular way determined by your base type and too much variation was usually a quick way to lose.On the upper difficulty levels forget about trying something new, either you play a flawless game with a very specific and particular build order (and hope you don't get disproportionally screwed over by the black market) or you might as well not have bothered starting the level.Now none of the above makes it a bad game, but unless you are the sort who has a hard-on for the multiplayer experience or grinding out every "Do X 100 times" achievements OTC has limited replayability.   I enjoyed my 20 hours of play and have no regrets on the purchase but probably will never reach 25 hours of play.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I like this game and I think it uses a market system beautifully. However, I think allowing the player to set a starting price for their own sale of goods might lead to a more competitive edge in terms of pricing, because the value of goods are not worth exactly what the seller says they are, its up to the buyer. So in a way the market in the game is not a truly free market where the price mechanism reflects the condition of the market because often times you are encouraged to instead sell things that might lend a good profit instead of selling things that ARE returning a good profit. The price of a good refects the entirey of its condition meaning the availability of the materials and the ease of production, and of course, its demand.Other than that minor thing I think the game is solid, however I dont think its worth $35.99. Maybe $29.99.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was skeptical because this was early access, I liked the developers other works and I figured I'd give it a try.  The Economic RTS is really a big change as♥♥♥♥♥♥moves and market forces can really change a game around.   I really like how maps start unexplored and it is slowly releaved.  You can choose and deploy your colony at any time but waiting till later also has its advantages, if you deploy too early and spend a lot of resources trying to corner the aluminum market you might miss the massive deposit on the edge of the map.  OTC is really about picking the best tradeoffs to get you where you want to go, which is fitting as it's an economic game.   Each colony type has different advantages and needs. expansionists are good at the early game land grab, Scavengers don't need steel and get early warning for random events.  Robots don't need food, but take power instead; and scientists can skip some of the early steps of the production chain by putting factories right over resources.  The early access parts show in that some units don't have detailed textures yet, and they use text to speech instead of voice acting.  There were also a few minor issues I had like not getting an opponents patents after buying out his company.  Overall the game is stable and looks better than most early acess games on steam.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								An economic RTS sounds boring, doesn't it?This game, however, is not at all boring. Strangely enough, I feel more engaged as each buy and sell is incredibly significant. Every action you do will have impacts for the entire game, from where you place your initial base, to every limited parcel of land you buy, to what resources you will produce. Each decision impacts your viability against the other companies. Having to decide quickly which resource to forgo as you try to ensure the quickest and most efficient rise to glory is tense. Deciding when to pour your money into other companies to eventually buy them out or buff up your own stock to shore up your financial defenses is tough.If you've played MULE a long time ago, or played Meyer's Railroads! not that long ago, or any of the Anno series more recently and enjoyed those types, this game is definitely the next successful iteration of this very small economic game market. Fast paced and replayable thanks to different factions, tech avenues, and resource availabilities, it comes highly recommended!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								So far, I have under 2 hours in the game. However, I've found it to be quite entertaining and deep enough for me. It would be nice to have some more resources to manage and different supply/demand chains, but there is still a full year to go. It isn't a game like Anno 2070 where you build and try to survive, but a faster, leaner RTS where the market is king. I've read a lot of reviews about the game where the AI gets ridiculous at a certain point which should be worked out at some point (it is early access). Watch some of the developer in-house games and tutorials and see if you like what they say. I know I did.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is great.I'm not sure why people are hung up on the game being in Early Access/beta.  How polished the game is in beta has more to do with the company you're dealing with rather than a universally-accepted standard of development.  For example, Blizzard games in beta are already polished to the level of release.  EA, on the other hand, had no problem with Battlefield 4 being unplayable for several months after release; BF4 would crash constantly on both new and old computers alike.Offworld Trading Company has all the graphics and core gameplay complete.  At the moment, the developers are finalizing the balance among the types of companies and completing alternative modes/winning conditions.  The only main feature that is missing is central hosting by dedicated servers, which is scheduled to be completed by release.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Okay, my first experience of this game is very similar to board games like Settlers of Catan. I try to find nice places to harvest resources, I expand and try my best to gather the most points. Unlike Settlers, there is more to this game that only resource gathering and expansion, aspects I haven't understood or learnt yet. So I lose... But losing doesn't feel like failure, it feels like learning. And that I think is because of the game. It beats you but only to make you learn. Me, I like that. It is a mechanical game, it's mostly about making the right decisions long term vs short term. When I link my only two sources of power I get bonuses but become vulnerable to sabotage. I gamble that I can make it. Afterwards, I get sabotaged and lose some time later, I'm bought out and lose. I play on "employee" level (low difficulty) and still I get my♥♥♥♥♥wooped. What I'm trying to say is that this is a challenging game with no easy path to victory, even on a low difficulty and after three playthroughs. Hopefully multiplayer will be equally enjoyable or more. So far I'm very satisfied with my purchase! =)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like Anno, Civ, Starcraft, and construction/citybuilding games, you will like this game. I've never played a more pure economic RTS, and it does its job exceedingly well. There is a small and manageable set of well-defined mechanics which can be combined in endless combinations. It's hard though. You need to be able to predict the future, act on your predictions, and react to competitors at the same time. Try and corner the market. Watch what happens when you have the only good silicon resource and use the hacker array to drive up the price of glass. Suddenly everyone takes our your ability to make power and you go into huge debt. But now you can boost yourself up to the next HQ level and seize those last good carbon resources so you will have an advantage in electronics production and win the game.Unless someone destroys the only good silicon mine on the map. Your entire strategy depends on that one tile. Better hire some goons to protect it.Don't forget...The AI won't.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								OK! This game is from its feeling and from the handling more like C&C than Civ. But it still has Civ components. It is, from a gameplay perspective a revolution. Taking the RTS genre into an area that is normally occupied by build up strategy like the ANNO Series or an 4X Game like Civ 5, Offworld Trade Company brings a unique and fun gameplay that is, in itself, quite a revolution. What is it aboutYou play one of 4 factions with small changes to gameplay but no great differences like in Star Craft and land on the face of Mars. Your job is to gather resources, turn them into products and sell them to your competitors or to the Offworld market. The market on the ground changes. If Iron is rare, the price goes up. You win against your opponents by outsmarting them, sabotage them and, in the end, buying their stocks from them. It's quite challenging in the higher difficult levels and provides loads of fun. Even for early access, the gameplay is solid, only few bugs are there at them moment. Due to a lack of single player gameplay I would recommend this game for Multiplayer Use only a the moment. A good campaign can change that, however.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								To be honest, I was a skeptical when I first saw this game and read some of the reviews here, though I've wanted a developer to pick up this very concept for years. Thank God Mohawk Games has taken on this title! The price felt a little steep at first, but it's actually reasonable given its replayability, how unique each game is, and the fact that it's not yet a finished project. If you love economic simulation, this game is absolutely for you! The AI is challenging and each win feels earned. While games don't last that long, they're usually intense and full of action. I have literally spent 1/3 of the past day playing this game, and I regret nothing!(Notes to developers: I have found only one glitch in the game- when Goon Squad icons are placed next to eachother they sometimes overlap as though they are projected on a thumbnail and cover up parts of icons in the background. Also, the scrolling mechaning was somewhat difficult to get used to, and though I am used to it now, I think you should consider edge-scrolling would be greatly appreciated by new players.)All and all, really great game. I give it a 9/10, even as is. I am sure that by final product it will be truly great.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a true strategy game, where macros and preplaning make little difference. Quick thinking and good knowledge of what is effecting the prices are the keys to winning each round.You can produce aluminium and steel to upgrade for free or take advantage of cheap prices from other players selling off their excesses, however you won't know which is the better move until the game has started and you see what resources are available.Resources are on a first claim basis meaning that you can miss out quickly or shoot yourself in the foot by claiming them too early.The only thing I hated was that you could be bought out too unexpectantly. If you have 5 shares in your own company you start to feel safe, however someone can buy you out all at once and you wouldn't see it coming.This is already being addressed by means of a warning when an oponent is close to having the funds to finish you off however it's not implemented flawlessly at the time of my writing this.It shows its signs of being an early access but for the most part playes like a full release.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								I would recommend the game. My best friend also owns it so we have spent plenty of time buying out computer players at this point. I see high replay value with both single and multiplayer. The games I've played were played at snail pace with my friend and I against 6 computer players. Each game lasts about an hour or so with either one or both of us claiming victory (I guess it's time to try a higher difficulty). If you are on the fence about buying the game and looking for a close relative to compare it to, try Sid Meier's Railroads. You take raw resources, convert them into something else and prepare to flood the market. Offworld adds price fluxuation, espionage, and rockets to melt down into a pretty kick♥♥♥♥♥game. As with most games, there are things I would like to see done differently. They are:     Being able to move claims. Once you claim a spot it is your forever. So you put out an iron mine, iron will carry us forever- right?? WRONG! Iron tanks and you are left with a claim in the middle of nowhere. So now you are stuck with an iron spot and torn between adding to your already robust power production and bring in an extra $1.00/hour or have a randon electronics factory making peanuts becuase it is all alone.     When buying a computer player out, it would be nice to be able to adopt or use their building principles. For expample. If playing as an expansive player and you buy a scientific player, you should be able to build a scientific steel mill directly on top of an iron resource. Other than that, the game is very good and I would recommend buying it if you are interested in economic type games.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a "like" from me, but a *very* weak like.  TL;DR - it's fun, but has some definite flaws, and is probably overpriced.  Giving it a 'like' because I still enjoy it, warts and all, but it's definitely not for everyone, particularly at the current price point.This is not a grand strategy game; this is a short and simple "economic RTS" that's probably closer to M.U.L.E. than anything else (but not nearly as fun).  Games are played on a small, randomized map, and finish in anywhere from 15 minutes to an hour or so.  The core gameplay is simple: claiming a limited number of resources, game the market and hobble your competition enough to buy out their stock before they buy out yours.  Some resources get consumed as upkeep, many of the rest are required for upgrades or advanced buldings, but at some point you reach a point of self-sufficiency, at which point everything surplus is for sale.What makes it interesting is the various ways in which you can try to kneecap them by limiting resources, either by throwing one of a very small set of 'black market' attacks at them to disable buildings or resources, or by manipulating the market somehow.  Cut off their oxygen supply; don't sell surplus power; sabotage their mines; flood the market with the commodity that they rely on as a cash source.  The supply chains are long enough that there's usually a weak point in everyone's, and finding and attacking your opponents' while adapting to attacks on your own is the main challenge of the game.What makes it not interesting is that there's a strong self-reinforcing going on; if you start out ahead, you have the resources to keep your competitors under your heel.  If you start out behind, it can be almost impossible to get ahead.  By the time you've hit the mid-game (base upgrade level 3-4 where you start becoming self-sufficient) you usually know who the winner is going to be.  The bulk of the interaction between players happens in the market at one remove, so it's sometimes hard to tell that you're competing against other players rather than an arbitrary resource cost.  It feels like more of a race than a fight.There's also some interface issues; it's very sluggish, particularly towards the end of a game, the text is too small, and the graphics are perhaps best described as 'functional'.  So all that said, it's entertaining, but perhaps not at the price point.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Love this game. Each game is similar in duration to something like Settlers of Catan (except real time). As other have said, it's not a Civ type game where you spend weeks developing a civilization across the world. These matches were made to take about 45 min, and meant to be played comptetively online. That said, the AI is very good if you don't want to play others.Essentially, it plays out something like a Catan match would. You mine resources and then fight for the exclusive production of them. You also buy/sell from/to the 'bank'. Prices of resources are determined automatically by how much people are buying and selling. This means you can take strategies that short a resource you have a surplus of, and when the prices goes up you can sell your stash for a profit (the other players would hike the price up, because they must buy from the bank if they can't produce).You win by purchasing all of the stock of other players. Stock price is calculated by your total value (debt, cash on hand, production rate, HQ level, stock assets, etc.).The gameplay is great. God, I hope the voices get a makeover...

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me start off by saying that I pretty much hate most of the RTS genre, I don't care for them at all most strategy games I prefer are turn based like Heros of Might and Magic, Fire Emblem, etc.With that said I find this game fantastic from what I have played of it so far. It still is very much an RTS but with the only three real ways to be dicked over being someone sending pirates your way for a short time to steal your resources, flood the market with a resource right before you sell yours driving the price way down, and someone building a building right next to your stuff to prevent you from being able to get an adjaciency bounus. It has all the elements of strategy games I like without the annoyance of people being able to destroy your buildings or units.If you don't like RTS games but like other types of strategy games, you may very well still like this game.  If you do like RTS games then you may or may not like this game since it is heavier on the self strategy side and lighter on the being able to screw your opponent strategy side, so depending on why you like RTS will effect if you like this.For being atleast 10 more months away from being not in early access (currently Feb 2015) since its not schedualed for release till sometime 2016, it feel really well polished with a fairly enjoyable single player campaign and a good multiplayer game as well.  Is it worth $40 in it's current state? Umm probably, I mean if development where to stop today and there be no more updates I think I would get $40 worth out of it, but it's still one that you may want to wait a bit to see how the updates go or see if it goes on sale (I picled it up on sale), but its definitly worth atleast keeping an eye on even if $40 is a bit high for you for something that is not a finished product, it's not like a lot of early access where it feels like a tech demo and then never progresses, it feels like a full game even in its unfinished state. (Though I have not completed the single player campaign yet and so it may need more to it but still).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is a unique RTS game where instead of crushing your opponents with armies you crush them with boat loads of money! You might be sceptical at this and think this will make the gameplay lack complexity and make it numb and boring, and this was a sentiment I held until I've played for a few hours and started understanding the complexity of the game.While the resource amasing in most RTS games is secondary to the warfare aspect and hence simple and mostly automated, this game revovles around its resource system and it works better than I first thought. The reason for this is that there's a dynamic resource market that's central in the game; simply put, if all players harvest iron and aluminum and other metals, the prices of these will drop and further harvesting becomes pointless. If that's the case you want to be the guy that's harvesting the precious food, oxygen and water, and making big $$ while buying the cheap resources the other players conveniently has overproduced. You're a daytrader, buy what's cheap and produce and sell what's expensive. This also means that adapting quickly is the key, and given that's it's played in real time it reminds me more of a high-octane game like starcraft than say the relaxing civilization series.In essence there's an ever ongoing interaction with the other players that you don't see as clearly in war based RTS, where it's all about big clashes between the armies and each player does their own thing in the rest of the time. This interaction makes the multiplayer games super fun, while the play vs the A.I. ("quick play" and there's some sort of simplified campaign at the moment) is not quite as entertaining but still works well. A comparison with board games like Risk is fitting, and it is perfectly suited for LAN's.There's some additional strategical elements to the game that adds depth; there are ways to sabotage an opponent and there's four different "classes" to choose from, a you should make depending on your strategy and the map.It is, however, what I consider to be on the expensive side for a game of this dimension. With some more work done on the campaign, and a proper tutorial (the one in place now doesn't teach you very much), it would be reasonable though, and given that it's in early access maybe that's what will happen.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								I reccommend the game with the following caveats:- The price is high for an early access game (I paid $44 because of the weak Canadian dollar)- The gameplay is stripped down to include only economic forces. This is not Civilization or Anno 2070.- The tutorials are weak, with merely a popup explaining each faction at the start of each game.- I have not completed the campaign, so no comment there yet.- The interface is currently dominated by a lot of fast-changing numbers. You will spend more time looking at the numbers than you will at the playing field- The useful charts (stock price over time, resource price over time) are hidden in another menu that you have to switch out of the game view to get to.- Learderboards and leagues are not implemented yet- The game menus and buttons are not totally polished yet- Fonts were sometimes difficult to read on my laptop screen (1366x780)- Games tend to be one-sided as soon as a player begins to dominate. Last minute upsets are possible, but require skill and timing.-Late-game becomes entirely unnecessary once you get the hang of the mechanics (after playing a few skirmishes), this game desperately needs balancing.The overall game is very fun and fast-paced, much like Monopoly. This game essentially purifies the economic victory modes (domination) common to other RTSs, elevating resource gethering and market tactics to its own strategy genre.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is great.I'm not sure why people are hung up on the game being in Early Access/beta.  How polished the game is in beta has more to do with the company you're dealing with rather than a universally-accepted standard of development.  For example, Blizzard games in beta are already polished to the level of release.  EA, on the other hand, had no problem with Battlefield 4 being unplayable for several months after release; BF4 would crash constantly on both new and old computers alike.Offworld Trading Company has all the graphics and core gameplay complete.  At the moment, the developers are finalizing the balance among the types of companies and completing alternative modes/winning conditions.  The only main feature that is missing is central hosting by dedicated servers, which is scheduled to be completed by release.

								I like this game and I think it uses a market system beautifully. However, I think allowing the player to set a starting price for their own sale of goods might lead to a more competitive edge in terms of pricing, because the value of goods are not worth exactly what the seller says they are, its up to the buyer. So in a way the market in the game is not a truly free market where the price mechanism reflects the condition of the market because often times you are encouraged to instead sell things that might lend a good profit instead of selling things that ARE returning a good profit. The price of a good refects the entirey of its condition meaning the availability of the materials and the ease of production, and of course, its demand.Other than that minor thing I think the game is solid, however I dont think its worth $35.99. Maybe $29.99.
