content:
Posted: April 26
It's clear to me that just like in the game, the developer's goal is to rake in the profits.Game is not worth it's asking price, especially when things like difficulty is a DLC. Even the map editor is a DLC. But let's forget about that for a second, after all, the quality of a game isn't defined by it's studio's greedy practices.So is OTC a good game? Well, it's average. You play as a CEO of a company, and your job is to setup a production pipeline on Mars. Along the way you'll have to compete with rival companies, and should you win, you basically monopolize Mars. Sounds pretty cool on paper, but in reality it's underwhelming.Some people might say there's a deep tactical aspect, but that is a lie. The company mechanics will dictate your playstyle, and it won't be long untill you figure out that there is only ONE playstyle, and that's the intended one. Robots pump out power, Scavangers can build with ductape and gum, Expansive can, well, expand faster, and Science are nerds that think they can do things better by skipping resource mining, when in reality they are gimped.The way this works is that every "race" has their strengths in different stages of the game, scavengers take the early, bots take the mid, expansive take late, and science take endgame. Obviously depending on the map and resource availability, this changes depending on the player. Unfortunately that's as far as the depth of this game can take you.At the end of the day, every game plays, and ends, the same way. Even after buying some DLC's (things that should be features of the base game) that added some variety to the game, it was hardly engaging. A lack of units hurts the gameplay, at times forcing you to sit and wait, even if you max out the play speed. The endgame is another thing that never changes, eventually the local market gets saturated by all the companies producing pretty much everything, requiring you to build some rockets and export your stuff offworld.Whoever buys the most shares at a colony/oposing company, be it by building modules, fullfilling wholesale orders, or by burying your competition in debt, wins the game. Along the way you can utilize some special "skills" which will cost you depending on how often it's used. The price of these skills is shared between players, so if everybody decides to nuke each other's resources pools, the price will skyrocket pretty fast. This is probably the first game that made a NUKE, boring. Like everything, these skills are mostly underwhelming, so don't expect to be blasting things to bits, or building an army. Your one and only weapon is the market, and while certainly a capable and formidable weapon, it's not enough to hold this game against other, more fairly priced and more feature packed products.So ultimately, is the game FUN? That's after all, what counts. Assuming you don't buy any DLC's, you'll have it all figured out in about 4-5 hours of gameplay. It'll take you about 6-7 with the DLCs. After that, it's rinse and repeat. The rest depends on how much endurance you have for the same thing over and over again.I really gave this game a chance, went as far as looking up some of the more intricate mechanics, trying out all the races, in all 3 campaign modes. Unfortunately, as unique this game is, it's also as uniquely boring, at least for me. If you get suckered into buying it based on the thousands of positive reviews, you'll only have yourself to blame when you get disappointed.People are having difficulty distinguishing between unique that is new, and unique that is entertaining.

												I don't get the hype about this game at all. It's NUTS hard but with no payoff, no big "Ah-ha!" moment where the big picture or mechanics click into place in your mind. It's mostly an RNG machine of doom with wild fluctuations in market prices and vengeful players lobbing extremely frustrating hurdles at you until you get bought out after almost half an hour of "how the ♥♥♥♥ did he upgrade that fast?". I'm an SC2 and MOBA player and really, really wanted this game to be a moderately peaceful "macro" style of game with some kind of rhyme or reason to it but there's so much going on under the hood that is ill-explained or just completely out of reach. The A.I. will kick your♥♥♥♥♥and you won't understand how to counter or even continue. I tried to brush up by reading wikis and the like but it's always a shrug of the shoulders and much touting of the game's intricate market management, which can be read here to mean a flying strategy monster instead of a FSM; a mythical beast pretending to offer some form of planning but instead giving out nothing but frustration.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								It is extremely interesting....for the first few minutes to hours. Its tutorial is...not the best. Very very simplified, and doesn't even explain the mechanics. You buy the game, and it throws it at you and says "here, understand it. Now play." The economy market is one of the only good things in this game. It's not resource management. It's not even management. It's just dumb luck. No skill is involved. Not much variety is shown between rounds. This thing happens. Next round, this thing happens. The AI is not hard to beat, on any type of difficulty. As I've said, this game is just full of dumb luck. You can find a good spot to start, or someone else can find a good spot and you will be left with nothing. You don't know where everything is. The game just starts off, putting you in a place where you know nothing. The actual gameplay is also a bit quirky. I find it that half the time I'm just waiting for the prices to change. Now, I'm not the best of gamers, so don't take my opinion as too serious. I just find that this game is not exactly worth $40. Maybe it's worth $15, or even $20, but not $40. So, that's my opinion.Overall ratings:Graphics: 9/10Gameplay: 7/10No Lag: 10/10The game runs very well even for a well designed game like this. I'm no proffesional reviewer, so again, don't take this as a serious opinion.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								An old Civ gamer here and Civfanatics follower. I have played one game so far, and decided to refund it. To be honest, this game has some very good ideas and also it's very nice to see something not combat related in the market. But during the gameplay, I cant shake the feeling that this is more like a visual representation of a spread sheet mechanic. At this stage, it needs to get a longer gameplay (too short at the moment) to be fun and a less simplistic approach (main stream will never play these type of games, you do not need to dumb down your ideas or the mechanics.). Also the end game is mostly decided by what you do at the very early, almost impossible to overcome the mistakes done at the beginning. Regarding depth, the game needs more strategic elements, less mobile-game like mechanics, more things to manage in both macro and micro, and the espionage/sobatage needs to have better visual representations, including some strategic ways to counter.  Environment being mars or somewhere else would have no effect in this game at all.  At this stage, this game is just like an iOS/Android game to have some quick fun but nothing more. It has a lot of potential, but seeing that it has been released on February and mechanics not chaning so far, I am not much optimistic about its future. More or less, in the core, this looks like what you will be getting when the early access ends.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								It needs work. I mean, you basically rush to buy each other out each game. There's almost no point. You get all the way to the end, finally pay off your debt, and finally start making profit, and then the AI buys you out - even though you own majority share of the company. Because the game is fairly retawddeed. I mean, you can't just outright buy a company if you don't own enough shares. So why does that happen man? Frustrating? You're damn right it is. It's not even fair warned, it's just out of nowhere a popup window that says you we're bought, and gained 3 trillion dollars that you'll never spend because the game is over, the end, period.And on that note, why is it that we have to buy shares of our own company. I own it right? Or am I just leasing the property... Thought I was the CEO.I like the fun of it, it has potential, it really does. But right now I can barely sit and play more than 2 matches. The buy out feature really kills it.And it needs combat, direly. Lawsuits and disgrunteled employees with guns, at the least. Because by the end of the match you wish you could just run through their company office with a tank and smoke a cigarette afterwards. Virtually, and literally.The "underground nukes" are only as rewarding as the sound effect, and that fades, quickly.I'm only upvoting/recommending the game, because I think one day it will be better.And the first 10 matches are really invigorating, until you realize the above mentioned things.Also, be aware that the UI lags. I have a core i7 3930k and a gtx 670, all overclocked, running on an SSD, and it still lags pretty hard - still in beta, to be expected. Just an fyi.It's a bit funny, as a programmer, because they just need to run the UI in a separate thread. It's a simple fix, they just haven't figured out how do it right yet. I personally would never, ever, put UI loops in the frame or frame buffer loop, it's just bad design. If one lags, both lag. Man I wish I had my degree already, so I could get hired by companies like this to fix their games for them. I'm not arrogant, but damn like how hard is it to make a game like this correctly. It's barely 3d, no combat, just numbers and sprites.The AI is probably one massive set of If..Else statements, IN A LOOP. gawd.Great concept, terrible deployment. So far. I will wait for the final release.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												If I had to describe what Offworld Trading Company is like, the closest games to it in terms of feel and gameplay are those from the Starcraft franchise, minus all the combat units. That sounded like a good sales pitch to me- I've played a bunch of Starcraft and Starcraft 2 and enjoyed them thoroughly.The problem with this is that if you analyze a Starcraft game, the first few minutes are always the most boring ones- you (usually) just execute some well-rehearsed build order before you get to the more interesting and exciting parts where your units interact with your opponents'- and Offworld Trading Company never gets to that part, by design. There are no units, no army compositions, no micro-management. The entire game is like those boring first few minutes of every Starcraft match, but there's no payoff afterwards.The Free-for-All nature of the game's standard game mode is problematic. The optimal move is to invest in raising your income and buying as much stock for your own company as possible and not waste any money buying your opponents' stock until endgame where the Offworld Market gives you (or your opponents) enough money to win the game. The extremely passive gameplay that the game rewards makes getting to the lategame feel like a chore, and victory does not feel very exciting. You can mess with your foes via industrial sabotage, but it doesn't feel very satisfying when you use it (whereas it does feel annoying when it gets used against you).There is a frustrating lack of clarity as to the game's systems. Last game I played, I had bought out 2 of my 3 opponents, had the most improvements to my production buildings and the most patents, plus the most total land claims... and yet my remaining opponent's stock value was somehow 50% higher than mine. Why was it higher? I have no idea. But his higher stock value meant that he managed to buy me out first, so I lost- and I have no idea what it was that I did wrong, or how to do better next game.I'll end my review by saying that Offworld Trading Company is a very innovative game. I haven't seen another game quite like it and I'm glad to see new concepts like this one take form. That said, for all its innovation, Offworld Trading Company is not a good game. I never really enjoyed any of it, and I would not recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								From lead designer of one of the highest-rated games of all time (Soren Johnson, Civilization IV) comes an entirely new kind of ♥♥♥♥ UP!I was really looking forward to getting this game and when i did i was surprised to find at first it did not dissapoint.  I played through the training missions which had their own learning curve and difficulty and was beaten several times but its all part of the learning to play this game.  However after i finished the training and went into the campaign the problems started.Firstly you choose your team and any purchases you would like to make before the mission begins, things like extra engineers and stuff and then its all go you and up to 3 NPC players battle it out.  You can imagine my complete surprise and shock when i was 10 seconds into the first mission and i get a heads up telling me that the enemy HQ has been upgraded to stage 2 already, ALREADY, they have the exact same buildings i have built so far yet they have aqquired the neccesary 80 aliminium, 80 steel and 40 glass in a matter of seconds, but it does not stop there.The NPC has an unlimited supply of money on hand always buying up stuff from the black market that costs thousands of credits and giving the starting conditions they could never amass in such a short time, as i am writing this the game is minimised in the background still going and all i can hear is scientific colony expanded, and all this banging and crashing as their launching emp after emp after dynamite attack after pirate attack on me again and again and these are again thosands of credits and the cost goes up with each use.Everything you build puts you in debt you buld one thing to cover one debt and another starts draining your resources so you build to cover that and another will start so you build to cover that and the first ♥♥♥♥ing thing you were trying to control is drainging you again, its just a viscious circle of shear repition and failings but your opponents are buying this and that and upgrading at a blinding rate and then like i mentioned earlier attack after attack after attack, your left with not much enjoyment at all.Then theres the heads up you have lost this amount of whatever to piracy.... piracy? when in the hell did the game mention piracy? Oh thats right it didnt, you sit there and watch these messages appear every second one after the other in the HUD you have lost this to piracy, you have lost that to piracy again and again and all your resource rates are firmly in the negative forcing you into this bottleneck of no recovery.  This game could be fun but when your being steam rolled every match due to an overwhelming NPC and its never ending trust fund, fun is then a very hard thing to find and the game becomes stressful and a complete horror to play. I want to like this game i really do but its broken, very badly broken and unoptomised i feel as if im just hosting an arena everytime i play so that a group of NPC's can battle it out and im just observing, hopefully future patching will sort things out but thats the problem with early access games you end up getting such a bad taste in your mouth from the game in question and alot of the time like myself, you never play it again.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I do not write reviews for games.  I will also say that I quit preordering PC games due to the fact that a lot are released with many bugs (SimCity) and/or are stripped of many dynamic features of its predecessor, such as recent Civilization games.  However, I took a chance with this game as it is the first early access game that I have ever purchased.  I am shocked at the stability of the game and how much fun this game is given the fact that it is early access and within two days of release.  This game is worth the cash, especially with more on the way in regards to content.  I have only crashed once in my 14+ hours of gameplay.  Yes, there are things that could be balanced or added to increase the length of each map.  Also, I believe that the maps could be bigger, but they are nearly the perfect size for the current content.  The tutorials could use some work with directing you, but I learned quickly outside of the tutorials in the actual single-player after the AI beat me a couple of times.  Regardless, this game is extremely enjoyable, especially the single-player campaign.The single-player campaign adds a new dynamic that I find intriguing.  You are against a number of AI opponents going for different locations on a planet.  You do not face the same combination of AI opponents, usually, on the different locations.  If you win the map, then you (or the winning AI) own the map and the perks/income associated with the map are the winners to use for the next location.  Also, the remaining AI battle for some of the other locations while you are playing your map, but never more than the remaining opponents can fill up.  For instance, if there are 8 players including you, then you choose the location that you want to play.  The location can have one-three AI players (2-4, including you, of the 8 total).  This leaves 4-6 AI to battle for 2-3 of the other locations.  After every match, new locations open up.  Depending on the victory conditions (how well you win), you increase in the leaderboard of that campaign.  As you move through the campaign, you use your income to buy new engineers to enhance or unlock buildings, same for the AI winners of other maps.  Each map is different in size, terrain, rules, and some have events such as “dust storm,” which lowers the efficiency of any solar plants built on the map.This game is definitely worth buying as is and even more so knowing that the game will have more content added due to how early in the "early access" we are.  I highly recommend this.For those interested, I am running on:i7-4790kGTX 780 Ti16 Gigs RamWindows 8.1 Pro

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								We're on Mars. Resources are limited, and trade is king. Who needs large armies or airforces? Not us. If we want to destroy an opponent, we can nuke their resources, buy up all their stock, or even EMP their bases. The more you play, the more you upgrade. The more you upgrade, the  more claims you have on Mars. Be warned, just because you have more claims, doesn't mean you will win. You still need to make use of those claims to the best effect. If you've gone and claimed a bunch of resource nodes, it doesn't mean you're king, without the ability to smelt things. Got that under control? But what about air, water, power, fuel? Miss out on those limited Geothermal Vents? Well instead of awesome power production, you'll be stuck with solar, which doesn't work at night, or wind, which is less than 25% as effective as the vents, when you first start out. This strategy game requires actual strategy. You can't zerg rush the enemy base and win.Conquer Mars using brains, not brawn.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game has a lot going for it. It isn't a military/war game so don't get confused by the Civ4 reference. I like the fact that it isn't a 2+ hour game, it's far less. There isn't much grinding in this game in single/multiplayer. More so in campaign on a low resource map.Single/Multiplayer is enjoyable but may get boring after sometime due to rush.Campaign seems to be more thought out and enjoyable. It has a lot more strategic game play.There are some small bugs but that is expected for a Early Access Game.All in all this game has a lot of potential, especially when single/multi becomes more balanced/finished.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								This review is written during Beta.OTC is an expansion/economics game which combines a procedurally generated map (replete with varying forms and quantity of resources) and a 'market' feature in which you trade the resources with other in-game players. The enjoyment of this game comes from using your awareness of the overall availability of resources on the map to predict which will become more valuable as the game progresses. Do well and your personal stock price raises; buy out 100% of the stock in competing players to win the game in the default play mode. Matches take anywhere from 10 to 25 minutes in my experience and are usually enjoyable all the way through.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								OTC is an interesting, if frustrating sort of economic RTS game.  Despite the fact that I have yet to actually win a skirmish vs cpu game (though, I think this is largely to do with finding my footing) it continues to draw me back in.  It feels a lot like a cross between Sid Meier's Railroads competition with a dash of Settlers of Caitan thrown in.  I found it enjoyable.There is no combat, so hostile actions are all indirect.  It's all about managing economy.This kind of game may appeal to you if you happen to like games like Banished, or any of the economy based Tycoon games.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								OVERALL REVIEW:8/10ABOUT:Offworld Trading Company reminds me a lot of a business simulation I played in college called MARKSTRAT. In Offworld trading company your objective is to buy out all of your opponents. There can be only one man left standing. You start and scan a planet for resources, and then select one of 4 factions: Expansive, Robotic, Scavanger, or Scientific. Each of these factions has several unique traits. Expansive has extra claims so they can build more, Robotic only needs power and electonics, scavanger gets early access to black market items and uses carbon instead of steel, and Scientific can put buildings that need resources on hexes that have that resource thus reducing the amount of claims they need to use: EX you can put a steel mill on iron without any iron mines and produce steel. My oppinions of the 4 factions are below. The game also has a black market where you can buy things to better your faction like extra claims/protection from enemies or undermine other factions with things like underground nukes. It also adds random auctions that go to your debt, which can really help if you need to save a geothermal vent for later in the game or are in desperate need of another claim. -Expansive: (Best)(1) This is in my oppinion the best faction. The extra claims they recieve make it much easier to be the first to get a HQ lv5. This faction will generally be the easiest to get the offworld trading export rocket, which is almost always a sure win. -Robotic: (Good)(2 Tie) No need for water, fuel, food or oxygen. Rush for electronics early and have some power and your society will almost never be in debt. -Scavanger: (Worst)(4) Inless the map has high carbon contents and low iron, this faction is a no-go. See what I said in cons about the black market issues. -Scientific: (Good)(2 Tie) Great faction for maps with a large amount of water or low iron. You can keep costs way down if you build your food supply and fuel/oxygen supply on this water. A great strategy is to build two steel mills at the beginning of the game on iron since you dont need an iron mine.PROS:-This is the most original game I have early access played since Minecraft. I think it has a ton of potential. -The game is pretty fun, and I think it will be much more fun when multiplayer isn't just player hosted.-To play a round takes generally around 30-40 minutes, meaning it won't take all day.CONS:-$35-$40 is just flat out too expensive for an early access game like this. This game should be in the $20 dollar range. I mean you could buy Skyrim for $40!-Big issues with the black market: No matter what faction you choose or how early you settle, the AI will always get the first action in the black market, meaning that by the time you get to it, additional land claims will be more expensive. This in my oppinion, defeats the point of going with the scavanger faction.-Random events are too extreme. In the real world an oversupply of a resource will not have it go from $100 to $1. I would like to see these events toned down. Perhaps a oversupply would lead a $100 dollar resource to become $40. -Offworld Export Rockets are ABSURDLY overpowered. The first person to build one will generally win the game. Generally this will be the expansive faction. -The game ends too suddenly. All of a sudden someone will get rich from the offworld exports and in litterally 2 minutes after this is built the game is over.

												The game can be fun in single player (after the ~10 hour breaking in period where you lose every match), but the AI has such an advantage in multiplayer games (just through being able to react instantly to anything that's happening, anywhere on the map) that it just winds up being incredibly frustrating when you can't pause/slow down the game to compete. content:
Posted: January 17
												Min-maxing, the game.Really dull, looks amazing and like a base building game but what you are actually doing is selling and rebuilding said base over and over again, so you can play a game of chase with a bunch of numbers down the side of the screen. There is no grand strategy to this game, just a perpetual micromanegemnt battle to min-max harder than your opponent and shift what you make and sell as the prices shift; a real one trick pony.The learning curve is also very steep for very little reward. Having payed for this game i've forced myself to play it and try to get to grips with it but it's been a miserable experience; the worst part is you pretty much always never know why they did better than you, their off screen min-maxing of the market was just better than yours.It's a strategy game where the enemies strategy is mostly hidden from you, no chance for counter attack, no chance for a change in strategy and the black market is just a win more tool for the best min-maxer.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Imagine the gameplay as being a sexy girl you hook up with in a bar.  You bring her home, and while getting laid youre thinking "this is great, im almost there!"  And then just before the climax, she pulls out, put her clothes on and leave while saying "you lost"This is how this game feels like.  Its a great game, its got a great recipe, but the core mechanics coupled with the victory condition (you buy all your opponent shares to win) makes it so the game stops really abruptly and you never feel like you could really achieve what you were meant to do. I still recommend this game as im pretty sure the developers are going to adress this issue since probably 572 out of the 573 reviewers are complaining about this issue, but as of now if id be you i would hold on until they get their♥♥♥♥♥♥straight or else, especially with the rather high price tag, it WILL feel like a luxury escort taking off with your money before finishing you off!

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												It seemed great at first, a economy / builder game. But then you see what it really is. A weak RTS that you play in twenty minutes flat. And a boring one at that. Pick a resource, hog it and hope others need it more than you need other resources.The only difference is some basic mechanics between the factions, and the black market.The black market gets more expensive the more you use it, and the only thing it does is delay or destroy things, or stop other from doing the same. A simple binary PVP system with exponential cost. BORING.The AI? Boring, the moment you look anywhere close to winning, the AI will nuke you into orbit with the black market, something you can hardly do anything against, and it just delays the inevitable. If you're not winning you still get annoyed by those black market shennanigans but it means that the AI will beat you anyway. Simply put, flat, boring gameplay, the only spikes are annoyance. Might be mildly fun VS human players, but then I'd go for a real RTS instead of this binary system where the richest wins ANYWAY.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												This game is near unplayable. I question the need for the core game mechanic Black market which give you the option of using underhanded means of targeting your enemies. The Black market makes the game near unplayable in certain circumstances like when enemy players or AI can work together or alone to disable large portions of your facilities. You won't be able to almost anything about it due the only sole defense option, Goon Squad, only works for about half or less of the black market attacks. This is under the assumption that you even got to use the Goon squad because sometimes it is unavailable for example during the campaign some missions don't include the Goon Squad. Even in the case where you have a Goon Squad on a facility that facility can still be attacked unless the facility is targeted directly instead of as a consequence of another building being attacked in the vicinity it will not be triggered. Even worse is that in most circumstances you have to put buildings of the same type close together to get adjacency bonuses. Otherwise the buildings effectiveness doesn't provide enough resources you need in enough quantities with some exceptions depending on what resources you are using the most. In the end considering that this game is not an early access game but a full release you can't count on these issues being fixed so I can't recommend that anyone buy this game.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												The game is not very deep in the sense that its pace and variety of game elements are designed to be more of a board game nature. On the positive side, that makes matches not as long drawn out and the mechanics easy to learn. The campaign is more a set of challenges the game generates, e.g. you can't build this building or that particular resource is very expensive.Fair enough. Brownie points for originality.But what really turns me off this game is the lack of traceability of why you lose a match.. Suddenly the AI just buys you out and that's it for you, while you stare at your ever growing debt, and wonder how the hell the AI keeps spamming out buildings and upgrades so fast even at the medium difficulty levels. It's very hard to recover from a bad start, no real gradient of improvement because once you optimised your base, the match is already overIt really feels like "Super Meat Boy" became a tycoon game. It's made for masochists, who want to start over and over again.

I don't get the point of this game, this would be better as a board game maybe 10 years ago.  Since you progress at an exponentional function, if you get too far behind, well there's no coming back.  I feel like this game is a "pick your strategy" and hope you luck out.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								NOT MAKING A RECOMMENDATION ISN'T A NEGATIVE REVIEW.With that out of the way, I like this new trend of using the RTS format to create a game of economic superiority. I enjoy the prospect of colonizing Mars, but I do have to admit that there only being four factions does somewhat seem like a limiting factor. Perhaps some other colony types along with a wider array of black market trickery and an expanded array of structure types?Overall, I like the concept and would definitely like to see more updates for the idea. Unfortunately, at the present I can't recommend purchasing the game for $40 until it leaves early access. I do enjoy the idea, and don't regret that this is the first early access game I've bought, but I suggest to everyone else that you standby until they finish polishing things up.

content:
Posted: February 20
												After playing this game for a few hours I think a better name for OTC would be "Mars - the spreadsheet".Lots of numbers, lots of tweaking numbers. I love playing strategy games but I don't OTC to be much fun. The references to the classic Dan/Dani Bunten game MULE had me fooled. I was hoping for an elegantly designed game with deep strategy, a modern take on MULE. There is nothing elegant about the design of OTC. If your idea of fun is trying to figure out whether paying a couple of thousand dollars to increase the price of a resource by five dollars for 20 seconds is the optimal strategy, OTC may be the game for you. So many choices to make but none of them are particularly interesting.If you want to get a feel for the level of mind numbing detail in OTC, read the free Almanac before buying the game. This poorly written document is chock full of formulas - this game must have been designed by a programmer. I'm a programmer myself, but I don't want to tinker with formulas for fun.I've heard of other Stardock games being referred to as spreadsheet games. I thought OTC might be different but it seems that Stardock lacks the creative energy that is essential for creating compelling games.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												I wanted to like this game.  It's very easy to learn and four different factions that each play differently is a nice idea for an economy game.  The problem is that it's just not fun.  You can max out all your buildings in about ten minutes and after that it's a game of fine tuning what you are producing and manipulating the market to drive prices up.  It's almost impossible to lose money so there's never any worry about that.  The only real point is to make money faster then your competitors so you can buy them out.  Offworld Trading Company is a good idea that just didn't work out.

Early Access Review
								I wrote an earlier early access review that called the game incomprensibile. Kudos to the developer for fixing that issue with a host of well designed tutorials that take the player through the learning curve and over to the other side.My main gripe with the game is that it comes across as... anti-business... maybe even anti-markets and certaintly as anti-capitalism. The tropes of greedy industrialists debasing resources is over played. I came back to the game with the intention of recommending it to an economics class for the market based resource management mechanisms, but unless the class is also linked to a Marxist characature of capitalism or induistrialism I wouldn't bother.Is it too much to ask for a game about economics, resource management and business to reflect those things in a positive light? It's like building a game about evolution and building in anti-science tropes. Still not recommended.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is the first game that I had to request a refund for - so that right there should set the tone for this review.For an economy RTS the game is very lacking in ingenuity and gameplay. It takes the consept of 4X gameplay and strip it to the absolute bare bones of the consept. You search for resourses, you claim the land, wait, repeat. The honestly is not a great deal more than that. Yes there are "upgrade" options and "special ability" options but the actions feel quite hollow. What also makes for a very big drawback for the game is that its tempo is very high and rounds could easily go by very quickly. I really do not see much hope for players in a multiplay enviroment who fall behind early (this part I did not experience, this is merely my impression). Essentially, from my perspective in any case, a player who falls behind by a step or two, they will be on a perminant treadmill until their demise with little hope of recovery unless the opponent makes a mistake or a♥♥♥♥♥♥break.Again to book-end a previous comment I made, this game is very hollow and a waste of money.

												The game could be so much more than it is.Building is not really enjoyable because you are limited to a small number of buildings. Plus there is no in-game advantage to building sensible supply routes, all route capacities are unlimited, local storage is unlimited.Trading is not really enjoyable because there is no real market, sold resources simply disappear you can sell more than the others are willing to buy. Buying shares is a joke and does not work like real shares at all.Combat is not really absent in that a key element of the game is destroying eachothers buildings. This makes the game unenjoyable to me. There is also (unrealistically) no advantage to being friendly to your neighbours, there is no AI dynamic in that view at all making your opponents feel like a bunch of 5-year-olds.All in all another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ time-busting game like candy crush.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												So Offworld Trading Company and me have had this "thing" for a very long time. I love RTS, always have since the mid 90's. I also love innovative games, well since games have existed. So when this game was announced, I watched and followed it like a hawk. Except I kept and maintained my distance. OTC was like a woman I'd see in a bar every week, it seemed love at first sight. She was beautiful, intriguing, like no-one I'd ever seen before.. But alas I was always drunk when I saw her and I had no courage to approach her, buy her a drink, get her number, maybe take her home.It was like this for months. The more I found out about her, the more character that she seemed to divulge, the more personality she put on display, the more I wanted her. Moving up the ranks in my little black book known as a wishlist. The more I came to the bar, the more she'd flash (sale), the more of her clothing (Price tag) she'd remove. It was at this point, I knew she was flirting with me, and it became apparent she's was now bundled in gold. So a weekend in mid-October she returned to the bar wearing 65% off... This time I was not drunk, I was no longer on the fence... I saw her for what she was, so after flashing my credit card, I finally took her home.After a 6 hour session with her... I have to say, she's rather intense. She showed me the ropes, showed me the many facets of her personality and showed me step by step what made her tick. Then she untied me and let me get to work on her...At first she was easy. I kept winning her charms, satisfying her needs... Things were going smoothly, she allowed me to tackle a single element of her, and then she ramped things up, adding more and more, asking for more and more. Things began to get more and more intense... Then she showed her true colours. The more you play her, the more she dares to push you. She becomes a shady, manipulative, dirty scheming devil woman who will push you into a corner, pin you there, and drain you economically for all you're worth.The thing is. You will not learn to back down. She leaves you wanting more, she wants to be dominated. Taken control of, but she isn't going to let you have it without a fight. In my case on a couple of occassions, she's kept up with me with everything I throw at her, and just when I'm about to get the upper hand, she will kick me down and laugh in my face... I should be humiliated. But I cannot get enough of her. I will keep going for the long-term until our relationship is exhausted. Until she has no more to give and finally submits to my own superior evil ways.. Just like she taught me...Offworld Trading Company... The game is indeed like a woman who wears the trousers, makes all the rules, is controlling of you... But wow, what a woman she is... My only regret is that I didn't take her home sooner.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												Game is bright and shiny and new, then after the tutorial you've seen everything game has to offer. they also kept place holder voices in the main game from EA, and speaking of EA.The EA peeps got all dlc for free but get screwd over for a free key for friend, and there isnt a discounted price to upgrade to deluxe for EA peeps (i understand that we should be thankful for free dlc) but if there would have been a heads up people would have bought deluxe instead of standard. especially since the price during EA was 40 usd and the deluxe is 39.59 usd which is less but not by much for the EA version. That in itself promotes hatred and discrimination to people who supported the developemnt when the game was utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ those who shelled out 40 bucks get jipped out of a key for friend due to there was never any mention of a deluxe edition containing dlc and key.Since it came out of EA the game hasnt changed much since, outside of a few graphic tweaks and asset changes for claims, and the new campaign UI it's still pretty slow paced unless you fast forward. MP got a wealth of maps today during release from the "Real Mars Map Pack DLC" which you have to pay (unless you were EA or bought deluxe) $4.99 USD ontop of the $29.99 sale going on till May 16th 2016 then it will be $39.99 + $4.99. But, it does add 30+ maps which can only be used during skirmish and MP. So the campaign wont be given a boost anytime soon(if ever).There really isnt much of a story unless you make one up in your own head pretty much I.E: "I just got promoted to CEO and the Investors want to see positive returns on their investments". or some nonesence. All you do is start small become big buy out everyone during rounds of mashed up skirmishes against the AI. A.I... well that is a joke actually the A.I. would rather fight itself till theres only 2 left plus your company dring each of the "campaign" missions then tries to buy you out but, cant because since you were left alone you accumalated the funds to buy out the other CPU's and bought stock in your own as a defensive measure.So, if you were looking for a Tactical rts or an RTT with combat and what not, well you wont get it here Off World Trade Co. takes the RTS genre and flips it over to peaceful times. Where you must expand your company on different parts of mars and take over your competitors one at a time till you own their claims on the map. There isnt a big difference between how the game is played from skirmish or MP or campaign (with campaign being a tiny bit different with upgrades you can buy before each round in the campaign) then end goal is still the same make money buy people out. Think of it as a futuristic version of the Family Board Game Monopoly on Mars. With the added benefit of a Black Market. This is where you can very very loosely say is the combat mechanic (if you want to call it that, i don't) you can buy extra claims to blowing up a mine of an enemy or just cause a riot and gain all the materials for yourself for a period of time. There are others, like pirates, and so forth but there really isnt anything there to keep you wanting to come back and play more. I got severely bored with OWTC around 5 hours thats me playing campaign skirm and MP. It feels as if they gave you an appetizer, burnt the dinner portion and was out of desert, which makes you unsure if you should even keep it installed onto your computer. As for myself i will because i got during EA. Also, if you dont care about the free key for a friend Don't buy the deluxe just buy standard and dlc and save yourself 5 bucks.As for a recommend or not i don't the game shows all of its cards too quickly and becomes rather dull after the ooos and ahhs pf shinynes, and there isnt much complexity once you complete the tutorials, you do exactly the same as tuts, just a little bit faster and you win everytime. MP just feels like a sped up version of tutorials make as much as you can, black market people, buy them out without being bought out yourself and boom thats it.

												Way too restrictive to the player.  The limitations of what you can build on a planet is just plain stupid.  Let them build where they want and when.  But oh no, you have to build close or stuff takes too long and you end up behind.  Then all your AI opponents gang up on the Player and shut down his economy with no way for the player to get out of it.  remove the ability to attack others or put a lock on it so gang banging can't happen.  Just make it so yopu can affect yourself only and not affect others.  That way you have to outwit them on a one to one basis and ganging up is never an option.  Losing because the other businesses use better tactics is fair and equitable.  Losing because they all bum rushed you early game makes this game one for the scrap heap.It's not that they punish you for mistakes, the AI can and will gang up on you at every chance and shut down your production and earning potential.  Then they get away ahead of you and there is not a damn thing you can do to catch up.  Get some cash ahead?  They come along and blast all your money makers into ZERO production and your back up funds disappear in seconds.  And when that attack ends, one of his buddies hits you again.  being constantly gang♥♥♥♥♥♥♥over and over just amde this another lazy♥♥♥♥♥crappy AI game that will spend it's life in the "Do not play this $&*&#* pile." After the attacks end, your back waiting till the AI gets far enough ahead to focus on something else.  By this time your so far behind, the only way to catch up is to cheat.  Since the AI seems to be programmed to do exactly that, it just makes this game terribly frustrating and no fun at all.Definetly not worth the $45 bucks.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you think Railroad Tycoon would be a better game with these game features, then Offworld Trading Company (OTC) would be for you:1. You can bomb your competitors' train stations, railroads and related structures;2. You can hire bandits to rob the opponents' train cargoes;3. You can use EMP to shut down the competitors' train systems; and4, You can sabotage the power supply of your opponents.I'm a fan of business / economic simulators and I don't think the above military / criminal / terrorist means of competing should be the gaming mechanics in a business sim. When I play a business sim, I want to use business / economic strategies to outsmart my competitors. I have no interest at all in using any military or criminal ways to win. Honestly, no matter how much AMD dislikes Intel and Nvidia, AMD wouldn't hire criminals to bomb or sabotage the opponents' fabrication plants, right? When I played Railroad Tycoon, I had the feeling of being the CEO of a growing railroad company. However, when I played Offworld Trading Company, I just felt like being the boss of a mafia business using criminal and military means to hurt my competitors. I don't like this feeling at all. The game description says there's "no military" in OTC but I think this's completely wrong and misleading. The in-game black market offers all the "dirty tricks" mentioned above to sabotage your competitors' businesses. I'm not sure whether this black market will change later, but, for now, I don't recommend this game to fans of business / economic sims.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								A definite change of pace from your typical RTS game, and actually quite relaxing on easy settings.There's a lot of interplay between the resources you scout for early and the market values.  Depending on how you start alone could change the entire challenge.  Right now, a game session is a relatively short experience, even on 'snail' pace.  But you're never too long waiting on anything to do, just that it ends quickly once you start steamrolling.  Personally, I do think there need to be some additions to make for a longer, more drawn out game.  Perhaps additions to the 'game market' as it were, such as land taxes, worker pay, and maintenance costs that scale with how much you expand in order to make that money you make more than just something you dump into a bank. (And we mustn't forget making those values something you manipulate that alters production and profit.) And of course, random events that further aggro those values.But overall, if you're the type that play an RTS in that way where you like to watch your forces build up into a mighty base rather than actually attack and crush the enemy as soon as you can.  Try this game out.  Its current brevity can even be useful if you want to kill time, but not a lot of it.Give it a shot.Also, someone needs to get on the dev team and get some better quality audio for the vocal parts...  Decent quality graphics and gentle music, and then literally the microsoft 'sam' and female equivilent for audio cues.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								There are few games in my opinion that warrant a good review beyoned a few simple words. This is one of them. RTS fans will love this game. Strategy and long term planning is a must. There are no tanks, no soldiers and no real weapons in this game. Everyone plays right on top of eachother in a mad battle for resources and stock. The objective is to Buy Out the other companies stocks. You will first chose a class, there aare 4. Each one is unique in what resources they require the most. You will build buildings and mine resources and sell them and balance your money. You will set yourself up to buy out all of the other players stock. While this may not sound like much fun, the game is extremely fun in my opinion. It is a different type of RTS that you will come to love. The first day I got it I played for 6 hours straight. Addictive personality aside, it is that much fun. Please buy this game and support the growing community as well as the dev's. They have released a bug free polished game which is a huge task for any dev. The game is easy at its core to learn, but deep enough to keep you wondering for a while. There is MP, SP & Skirmish. They have thought of everything. Give it a go and you will not be sorry. Hit me up for a game too!Peace!

Butplaying with a friend is very different. I have loved each match! Since the first one(me and a friend had not play any tutorial before) where we learnt together. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								For a game that looks like simple buying and selling this is surprisingly fast paced. You can't simply build a load of factories and sit on them, you have to keep an eye on other players and react to what they and the market in general are doing. There's that horrible moment where the buyout percentage starts appearing next to other player's names (showing that they're more than 50% of the way to buying you) and the scramble for as much cash as you can scrape together in a hurry. That being said if you're more of a casual and methodical player you can freely pause games with the AI to analyse your next move, which has helped me out quite a bit!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even though it says "Early Access" - this game is by no means an early access game. It is better than a lot of retail released games that I have bought in the past.There are three main reasons for this:1) Replayability - you play on a randomly generated map every time, so it never gets boring, you always have to be on your feet because you need to adapt your strategy based on the map.2) Fun - It is a fun game. It´s created by a top notch game designer with a great team behind creating the game. They organize community events and communicate with the players.3) Jack-of-all-Trades: No bugs, very informative UI, very nice graphics, fluid gameplay. The game has it all.Oh there is one more thing. The game features a brilliant campaign mode. I am usually not a Singleplayer gamer, I like to play against people. The only exception to this being Offworld Trading Company, and Paradox´s line of grand strategy games. The campaign is fun and challenging at the same time, putting a different spin on the game.---A word of caution though. The game is by no means dead, but it can be hard to find players at certain times. This may be due to the early access status and due to the niche category this title sits in, it isn´t a mass market game, as it does require a deal of intellectual capacity to succeed at the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								A decent RTS game with some novel elements. 5/10 (6/10 considering early access).Very close to the CIV, tile like RTS, with limited tile "claimability" which means the strategic element of tile selection very important. Resource system works very well - it does play a lot like C&C in that regard and may lend itself too much to systematic builds (i.e. there is an optimum build order, stick to it or loose). There isn't a huge level of replayability there which is why I chose to write the review early - essentially the resources available adjust the location of HQ and thats it, every game plays out very similarly. A bit more depth in the building system and more to the takeover mechanism would make the game more worthy.Currently a good game to give a go if interested in RTS/builders. Consider waiting for it to be on special - not worth the current price.PROS:*Novel importance of the resource system, buying and selling is what this game is about.*Limit to the number of tiles makes claim selection very important* Resource system works very well, straight forward to use.* AI seems to work fairly wellCONS:* The Black Market system is opaque and seems redundant. The features become very expensive very quickly, and it is difficult to see how they really assist the player.*Resource tiles are largely irrelevant for most building types - find proximate resources then clump buildings together (doesn't quite come across as worthy)* Some of the controls are difficult to use (for example selecting a building to bring up context menu for deletion it - it keeps exiting the interface!)*Takeover system needs more depth and more response posibilities once the count down starts.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game may at first seem kind of repetitive, but that's really what makes it fun. It's kind of like chess in a way, because even though it is the same game and same setup and same rules every time for some reason you just want to play it over and over and increase the difficulty to expand your skill. I hope that with future updates they add more cool features.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								So far so good. The economy still feels like it could use some tweaking here and there, but nothing seems to really stand out. At least not until the endgame.    I'm not too sure if the endgame should be changed or not. On one hand, you definitely don't want a game to drag on and someone should end up being a clear winner. On the other, there does seem to be a snowball effect where when one player managed to buy out another the guy's finances start to snowball and soon just starts thowing all that money around, making it darn near impossible to reverse.    Of course, that seems to be the way of most economic games, so maybe it's just me. Only played against the computer a bit, so can't say for sure that it's a 100% great game, but I'd say so far it's been worth the money. If you like the building/improving aspects from the 4X games *coughCivilizationcough* then this will probably be up your alley.    Summery: Not bad, seems a bit unbalanced in the endgame, hope things get better. Definitely looking forward to seeing how it goes, though. Not sure it's worth full price of the Early Access. I bought this when it was on sale for $20 and frankly, that feels about right for where the game is currently. Maybe $25 or so. Once it's finished should be worth a good full price, though.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crunchy economic simulation.  I haven't noticed any bugs in the game thus far.  Modest learning curve might turn off people who don't enjoy number-crunching.  Economic model isn't hugely sophisticated (try the board game Arkwright if you want a real brain burner) but timing really is everything --- in construction, auctions, using the black market --- you name it.  The AI is pretty aggressive, and will keep you on your toes.  I hope to see a bit more nuance added to this as development continues, but it remains challenging.

								It's a pretty engaging game, and runs ~okay~ on my backup laptop with HD 3000 graphics (~15fps on low settings, but hey, it's not like reaction time counts in this game). I agree with a youtube reviewer though: there needs to be a mode where price of stocks is modified so that the end-game takes a lot longer to reach. You can just be enjoying yourself and, all of the sudden, the game's over. I'd also say $40 is a bit steep to ask for, given what's available now. It is only early access, so maybe they're adding more later, but $20-30 feels like a more fair price as-is.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								For a game that looks like simple buying and selling this is surprisingly fast paced. You can't simply build a load of factories and sit on them, you have to keep an eye on other players and react to what they and the market in general are doing. There's that horrible moment where the buyout percentage starts appearing next to other player's names (showing that they're more than 50% of the way to buying you) and the scramble for as much cash as you can scrape together in a hurry. That being said if you're more of a casual and methodical player you can freely pause games with the AI to analyse your next move, which has helped me out quite a bit!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								This review is an early access one and even within days of me buying the game some significant changes were made, so I expect lots more changes to come.This is one really good concept and whilst there are issues with it (especially in teaching a new player how to play and how the systems and concepts work), there is soooo much to like here. The game does away with military conflict and the necessity to be able to hotkey or mouse-click quickly to win. Instead, it requires forethought, palnning, deception and a little luck to do well. I'll admit, it took me ages to get my head around some concepts and I'm not sure I'm there yet. I have yet to play a multiplayer game (this is my major criticism at this stage - no-one online at this point but hopefully numbers will grow) and have only just started a campaign, but I've already put in 14 hours at the point of writing this in skirmishe and doing the tutorial a couple of times. There are some really interesting game features too, such as being able to play a single player skirmish while you wait for a multiplayer lobby to fill (which helps avoid the hwole thing where people log on, check for ten seconds and then leave), a team based multiplayer option and a single player mode that works differently to the multi and skirmish modes.Pros:- Great amount of tension within the game- Replayablility Every game is different- Accomodates various playing styles (with 4 different bases/classes that are reasonably balanced at this point)- shrewed tactical gameplay- Various gameplay options across all game modes- Games last for between 15 minutes and half hour. Not a Civ styled game at all.Cons:- Tough to learn. The turoial is pretty much non-existant and many finer points that will have you scratching your head will not be answered without visiting the internets and YouTube- No-one on multiplayer yetOverall: I feel like I am only at the beginning of this journey with this game and  with updates that make the game a little more unique on each play, the game will go from strength to strength. It is fair enough to say that I am a fan!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								OTC offers a very unqiue approach to Real Time Strategy games. No armies that need to decimate your opponents base, but trying to out-trade your opponent so you can buy out their stock.There are some sabotage/offensive actions (known as the black market) where players can buy some one time actions that can destroy or freeze buildings, steal resources or protect you from such attacks. There is however a cooldown of one minute until you can buy the next such action, so while the Black Market definitely has a good influence on how to play out each game, it's not the only thing to focus on if you want to win.In a way the game works a bit like Settlers, where you build production chains for resources you need (you need Lifesupport for your colony (Food, Oxygen, Water), Electricity for your buildings and Fuel for transporting resources around. )What makes this game unique is that you can also simply buy these resources with money (that you make by selling other resources). So at any point and depending on the price, you might simply not get into these production chains and just buy the water cheaply, while producing expensive electronics or something.Of course prices change, depending on how much players buy and sell a certain resource which means you can't simply sit back and wait, assuming everything stays the same as when you first established a production chain.Then there's also dept, which means, if you need a resource but don't have the money you will accumulate dept, which you're gonna have to pay interest on every now and then. The reason this has an impact is twofold. One is that it makes your stockprice cheaper (and thus you're easier to buy out), the other is that there is a bond-rating that will fall further and further and make you pay more and more interest each time. And if your bond rating goes to "D" you can no longer use black markets, making you both an easy target, as you can't defend yourself anymore and you can't fight back. So on the one hand, dept is good for you, cause it saves you money, but let it go out of hand and it might singlehandedly lose you the game, which I find a very interesting mechanic.Prices are also one of the most intersting ways to "attack" and opponent. Did they skimp on input materials cause they were so cheap when they established production? Why not buy up a bunch and see how their production turns unprofitable?See that they try to monopolozie a market? Build a hacker array and make prices go down.What makes the planning so crucial is that you have a limited amount of claims (i.e. you can only build a certain amount of new things each hq level). So if you make a mistake planning it will come back to haunt you later.The last thing I want to mention is that multiplayer maps are procedurally generated, making each one a different experience as the last. On top of that, since you have 4 factions to chose from, each game starts with players having to analyze both the environment, resource distribution and black market to make the decision which faction to make and where to land. All of which have a huge impact on how you will play that particular game & map.All in all, there is already a lot of depth in the game that makes it worth playing (imo). However, I bought the game when it was 50% off and I'm not sure I would've bought it for the current 40€ price tag either. So maybe wait until release and see if the price comes down a bit (or if they add enough content to make it worth the pricetag).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm recommending this game.  I do so with a bit of reluctance.  I purchased it on sale, and for the price I paid, I think I got a good deal.  I personally believe every game is priced at what people are willing to pay, and those who whine about "not a top tier game" or "the devs should lower the price" are idiots.  Still, I think it is fair to say a game should be recommended if it gives value for the buck, and at the price I paid it did.  At the nominal price, I would be so happy.Pros:* It takes a bit to learn, and the tutorials are not that great at teaching.  But I could figure it out at the easiest setting, and then I read a user guide to understand the underlying strategy.  With just 8 hours of play, I can handle a moderate level of difficulty and have a decent challenge while using nearly all the available game strategies.* A single round can be played in 20 minutes.* The pace is interesting.  It is kinda of slow at fast, and then at some point you'll get the clear upper hand (or not) and the end game comes fast.* The pace means you can think about strategy, which is what I wanted from the game, but then you don't need to wait long to learn if you made the right decisions.* The graphics are decent.* The game has a good amount of complexity.Cons:* For such a complex strategy game, the pace is almost too fast.* Some aspects seem important, but I have yet to find them critical.  Without providing spoilers, I'll just say the transport of goods, the offworld market, and the patent system don't seem balanced correctly.* It is a work in progress, this is both good and bad, but for the price,  think it needs more progress.  I don't think it is as close as the devs suggest, but if they clean up the degenerate strategies, then this will become a pro.* The stock concept is a bit too simplified, and other than its role in the endgame, it is rather pointless.  This could be resolved if the parameters for the price were explained thus opening up strategies to manipulate shares.  One guide gives some suggestions of strategies, but if that's all it is, then stock system is a con.* What's the point of the town?  Is it only for the pleasure dome?  Because I can make nearly as much money putting the pleasure dome near my own base.  Is the town what is buying the goods?  If so, why only have transports to go to my base?   I have rockets to get goods to market off planet; what gets goods to the city?* I guess I'll have to look up how to start an auction.  At first I found them annoying, because they literally pause the game while you play them out.  I would jsut skp them, to get back to game play.  Then I learned some auctions should be won at almost any price.  And then I wanted to know how to make them start.  But this is a con because the few patent options should never be part of the auction.  I think it ruins the patent model, and it doesn't make sense.If you like strategy business games, then this is enjoyable.  For the price, you'll have more fun with civilization or colonization, but if you already played those and many other similar games; then buy this.  It is definitely different from those games and is fun.Tip:  While I find little value in the sabotage features of the black market, look over at carefully.  Some black market items are not sabotage items, and they provide key advantages in the game.

Posted: December 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Guild IN SPACE! Pro: Minimalistic and beautiful artstyle. Tense mining, trading and buyout action.Con: Not fleshed out enough for the full price. Too many sabotage acts become frustrating.A solid economy game which grows tense as bases are fully built and players race to buy enough stocks to take over other players. Tutorials and tooltips need more love. 40€ is too high, especially for early access. Do not go over 20€ on this one, if lower its a safe bet for fans of Anno and the Guild.
